0	Japan began the defence of their Asian Cup title with a lucky 2-1 win against Syria in a Group C championship match on Friday .	Japan ! location ; Asian Cup ! mix ; Syria ! location ;
0	But China saw their luck desert them in the second match of the group , crashing to a surprise 2-0 defeat to newcomers Uzbekistan .	China ! location ; Uzbekistan ! location ;
0	China controlled most of the match and saw several chances missed until the 78th minute when Uzbek striker Igor Shkvyrin took advantage of a misdirected defensive header to lob the ball over the advancing Chinese keeper and into an empty net .	China ! location ; Uzbek ! mix ; Igor Shkvyrin ! person ; Chinese ! mix ;
0	Oleg Shatskiku made sure of the win in injury time , hitting an unstoppable left foot shot from just outside the area .	Oleg Shatskiku ! person ;

0	Despite winning the Asian Games title two years ago , Uzbekistan are in the finals as outsiders .	Asian Games ! mix ; Uzbekistan ! location ;

0	Robert Galvin	Robert Galvin ! person ;
0	MELBOURNE 1996-12-06	MELBOURNE ! location ;
0	Australia gave Brian Lara another reason to be miserable when they beat West Indies by five wickets in the opening World Series limited overs match on Friday .	Australia ! location ; Brian Lara ! person ; West Indies ! location ; World Series ! mix ;
0	Lara , disciplined for misconduct on Wednesday , was dismissed for five to extend a disappointing run of form on tour .	Lara ! person ;
0	Australia , who hold a 2-0 lead in the five-match test series , overhauled West Indies ' total of 172 all out with eight balls to spare to end a run of six successive one-day defeats .	Australia ! location ; West Indies ! location ;
0	All-rounder Greg Blewett steered his side to a comfortable victory with an unbeaten 57 in 90 balls to the delight of the 42,442 crowd .	Greg Blewett ! person ;
0	Man-of-the match Blewett came to the wicket with the total on 70 for two and hit three fours during an untroubled innings lasting 129 minutes .	Blewett ! person ;
0	His crucial fifth-wicket partnership with fellow all-rounder Stuart Law , who scored 21 , added 71 off 85 balls .	Stuart Law ! person ;
0	Lara looked out of touch during his brief stay at the crease before chipping a simple catch to Shane Warne at mid-wicket .	Lara ! person ; Shane Warne ! person ;
0	West Indies tour manager Clive Lloyd has apologised for Lara 's behaviour on Tuesday .	West Indies ! location ; Clive Lloyd ! person ; Lara ! person ;
0	He ( Lara ) had told Australia coach Geoff Marsh that wicketkeeper Ian Healy was unwelcome in the visitors ' dressing room .	Lara ! person ; Australia ! location ; Geoff Marsh ! person ; Ian Healy ! person ;
0	The Melbourne crowd were clearly angered by the incident , loudly jeering the West Indies vice-captain as he walked to the middle .	Melbourne ! location ; West Indies ! location ;
0	It was left to fellow left-hander Shivnarine Chanderpaul to hold the innings together with a gritty 54 despite the handicap of an injured groin .	Shivnarine Chanderpaul ! person ;
0	Chanderpaul was forced to rely on a runner for most of his innings after hurting himself as he scurried back to his crease to avoid being run out .	Chanderpaul ! person ;

0	Ohio State left tackle Orlando Pace became the first repeat winner of the Lombardi Award Thursday night when the Rotary Club of Houston again honoured him as college football 's lineman of the year .	Ohio State ! org ; Orlando Pace ! person ; Lombardi Award ! mix ; Rotary Club ! org ; Houston ! location ;
0	Pace , a junior , helped Ohio State to a 10-1 record and a berth in the Rose Bowl against Arizona State .	Pace ! person ; Ohio State ! org ; Rose Bowl ! mix ; Arizona State ! org ;
0	He was the most dominant offensive lineman in the country and also played defensive line in goal-line situations .	end
0	Last year , Pace became the first sophomore to win the award since its inception in 1970 .	Pace ! person ;

0	Britain sets conditions to clear American alliance .	Britain ! location ; American ! mix ;
0	Edna Fernandes	Edna Fernandes ! person ;
0	LONDON 1996-12-06	LONDON ! location ;
0	The British government warned Friday that it would refer the proposed trans-Atlantic alliance between British Airways Plc and American Airlines to Britain 's Monopolies and Mergers Commission unless the carriers complied with a number of conditions .	British ! mix ; trans-Atlantic ! mix ; British Airways Plc ! org ; American Airlines ! org ; Britain ! location ; Monopolies and Mergers Commission ! org ;
0	Trade and Industry Secretary Ian Lang added that even if the conditions were met by both airlines , final clearance would hinge on an open skies deal between Britain and the United States to liberalise trans-Atlantic air traffic , which would create greater competition on the routes .	Trade and Industry ! org ; Ian Lang ! person ; Britain ! location ; United States ! location ; trans-Atlantic ! mix ;
0	Lang said he supported conditions proposed by Britain 's Office of Fair Trading , which was asked to examine the case last month .	Lang ! person ; Britain ! location ; Office of Fair Trading ! org ;
0	" I agree ... that without suitable undertakings the alliance would be likely to lead to a significant loss of actual and potential passengers , on those routes where BA and AA currently compete and for all passengers on the trans-Atlantic market route between the UK and U.S. , " he said .	BA ! org ; AA ! org ; trans-Atlantic ! mix ; UK ! location ; U.S. ! location ;
0	His comments came just minutes after the latest set of open skies talks ended in London with no deal signed .	London ! location ;
0	Industry sources said there was no new date for fresh talks and blamed the deadlock on uncertainty over whether the British Airways-American deal would be cleared .	British Airways-American ! mix ;
0	The conditions for clearance of the alliance were that British Airways and American drop 168 slots at London Heathrow airport , the busiest in Europe .	British Airways ! org ; American ! org ; London Heathrow ! location ; Europe ! location ;
0	American 's parent , AMR Corp. , said it did not view the terms as a " deal breaker . "	American ! org ; AMR Corp. ! org ;
0	However , it called the conditions " more severe " than those imposed by other regulatory authorities on similar airline alliances .	end
0	British Airways 's initial response was that " unconditional divestiture of slots is unprecedented and if done it must be on the basis of fair market value . "	British Airways ! org ;
0	It added that it would be " prepared to take reasonable steps to assist the introduction of additional competition . "	end
0	The government also wants British Airways to drop a clause in its agreement with USAir that bars it from competing on trans-Atlantic routes , and said both British Airways and American should be prepared to reduce services on the London to Dallas-Fort Worth route in the event that a new entrant wishes to enter .	British Airways ! org ; USAir ! org ; trans-Atlantic ! mix ; British Airways ! org ; American ! org ; London ! location ; Dallas-Fort Worth ! location ;
0	It also suggested losing some slots on the London-to-Boston route .	London-to-Boston ! mix ;
0	The Office of Fair Trade called for British Airways / American to allow third-party access to their joint frequent flyer programme where the applicant does not have access to an equivalent programme .	Office of Fair Trade ! org ; British Airways ! org ; American ! org ;
0	Lang said responses should be made to the Office of Fair Trading by Jan. 10 , 1997 .	Lang ! person ; Office of Fair Trading ! org ;

0	New York City on Friday said that it planned a $ 775 million refunding for January that will include its first floating rate issue of taxable debt for European investors .	New York City ! location ; European ! mix ;
0	A city official , who declined to be named , explained that Goldman , Sachs , which this summer was demoted to the second tier of the syndicate , proposed the floating rate issue and as a result was promoted to book runner for this offering .	Goldman , Sachs ! org ;
0	By selling the floating rate debt , the city hopes to establish a benchmark , the city official said , adding that it needed a large deal to accomplish this objective .	end
0	The city in late June sold its first issue of Euronotes , a strategy that it says saved it $ 500,000 in interest costs , and it has been trying to build on this strategy of expanding the pool of potential investors since then .	Euronotes ! mix ;

0	Brendan Intindola	Brendan Intindola ! person ;
0	NEW YORK 1996-12-06	NEW YORK ! location ;
0	Homestake Mining Co tops Wall Street 's list as the most likely white knight buyer for Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp if Santa Fe rejects unsolicited suitor Newmont Mining Corp .	Homestake Mining Co ! org ; Wall Street ! location ; Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ; Newmont Mining Corp ! org ;
0	Santa Fe is so far mum on the more than $ 2 billion stock swap takeover proposal from Newmont , announced Thursday .	Santa Fe ! org ; Newmont ! org ;
0	Wall Street , since the bid , has speculated that any deal between Newmont and Santa Fe would be a " bear hug , " or a reluctantly negotiated agreement where the buyer is not necessarily a friendly suitor .	Wall Street ! location ; Newmont ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ;
0	Newmont said the companies have had previous contact , though declined to detail the encounters .	Newmont ! org ;
0	Analysts predict Santa Fe will go to the highest bidder , and that if a rival buyer is found , Newmont may not be able to match its offer .	Santa Fe ! org ; Newmont ! org ;
0	They said the Santa Fe deal , which includes desirable Nevada mining territory , would only payoff for Newmont longer term .	Santa Fe ! org ; Nevada ! location ; Newmont ! org ;
0	Newmont , in fact , will not benefit from the Santa Fe acquisition on an earnings basis for at least two years , which also limits its capacity to raise its offer .	Newmont ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ;
0	Any deal , friendly or hostile , would almost assuredly be a stock swap , which is necessary to preserve the tax-free , pooling-of-interest accounting , they said .	end
0	Analysts and arbitrageurs immediately ruled out Barrick Gold Corp and Bre-X Minerals Ltd as Santa Fe saviors because they are locked in negotiations over their splitting Indonesia 's Busang vast gold deposit .	Barrick Gold Corp ! org ; Bre-X Minerals Ltd ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ; Indonesia ! location ; Busang ! org ;
0	Placer Dome Inc too was considered unlikley because it is focusing on geographic expansion in areas that do match Santa Fe 's Nevada , South America and Central Asia presence , they said .	Placer Dome Inc ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ; Nevada ! location ; South America ! location ; Central Asia ! location ;
0	A Homestake spokesman was not immediately available to comment on speculation that it tops the list .	Homestake ! org ;
0	Homestake , based in San Francisco , operates gold mines in the United States , Australia , Chile and Canada .	Homestake ! org ; San Francisco ! location ; United States ! location ; Australia ! location ; Chile ! location ; Canada ! location ;
0	Earnings in 1995 were $ 0.22 per share , or $ 30.3 million , on revenues of $ 746.3 million .	end
0	Santa Fe is headquartered Albuquerque , N.M. and reported 1995 earnings of $ 0.30 per share , or $ 40 million , on revenues of $ 350 million .	Santa Fe ! org ; Albuquerque ! location ; N.M. ! location ;
0	Santa Fe has mining and exploration operations in Nevada , California , Montana , Canada , Brazil , Australia , Chile , Kazakstan , Mexico and Ghana .	Santa Fe ! org ; Nevada ! location ; California ! location ; Montana ! location ; Canada ! location ; Brazil ! location ; Australia ! location ; Chile ! location ; Kazakstan ! location ; Mexico ! location ; Ghana ! location ;
0	PaineWebber analyst Marc Cohen said he lowered his rating on Newmont to neutral from attractive today because if Newmont merged with Santa Fe , investors would have to wait until the second half of 1998 to realize earnings accretion .	PaineWebber ! org ; Marc Cohen ! person ; Newmont ! org ; Newmont ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ;
0	" I think Homestake could come in as a white knight , but how much is someone willing to come in above the Newmont number .	Homestake ! org ; Newmont ! org ;
0	One would have to outbid by at least 15 percent , but there is going to be a ( Santa Fe ) deal with someone , " he said .	Santa Fe ! org ;
0	" Longer term , two to three years out , ( a Newmont-Santa Fe deal ) is positive , it does all the right things .	Newmont-Santa Fe ! mix ;
0	But in the near-term it is , at worst , neutral , " the analyst added .	end
0	Newmont proposed to Santa Fe a stock-swap merger at a ratio of 0.33 Newmont shares for each Santa Fe shares .	Newmont ! org ; Santa Fe ! location ; Newmont ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ;
0	In Friday New York Stock Exchange trade , Newmonth was off 1/2 to 46-5/8 while Santa Fe added 1/4 to 15-1/8 .	New York Stock Exchange ! org ; Newmonth ! org ; Santa Fe ! org ;

0	Jonathan Wright	Jonathan Wright ! person ;
0	NAIROBI 1996-12-06	NAIROBI ! location ;
0	The Canadian general in charge of a multinational force for eastern Zaire said on Friday he was going back to Zaire for more information about the plight of about 165,000 Rwandan refugees adrift in the countryside .	Canadian ! mix ; Zaire ! location ; Zaire ! location ; Rwandan ! mix ;
0	Lieutenant-General Maurice Baril told a news conference in Nairobi his main concern was for a large group of about 150,000 refugees living off the land in a valley about 65 km ( 40 miles ) west of the eastern city of Goma .	Maurice Baril ! person ; Nairobi ! location ; Goma ! location ;
0	If he decided it was necessary and safe for the aircrew , he would not hesitate to order airdrops of food for the refugees , even against the wishes of the government in Kinshasa and the Zairean rebels who control much of eastern Zaire , he said .	Kinshasa ! location ; Zairean ! mix ; Zaire ! location ;
0	" Tomorrow I 'm going into Rwanda and my intention is to go across into eastern Zaire and try to find out for the second time what the situation is on the ground , " he said .	Rwanda ! location ; Zaire ! location ;
0	General Baril saw rebel leader Laurent Kabila in Goma last week but the rebels told him the crisis was over because most of the Rwandan refugees have already gone home .	Baril ! person ; Laurent Kabila ! person ; Goma ! location ; Rwandan ! mix ;
0	The rebels do not want the multinational force to deploy on the ground , for fear it might help the Zairean army regain control of the area .	Zairean ! mix ;
0	Kinshasa opposes airdrops , apparently because the food could fall into the hands of the rebels and their local supporters .	Kinshasa ! location ;

0	" It does n't look as though they ( airdrops ) are going to be required in any significant way because the NGOs ( non-governmental organisations ) are in that area on the border between Zaire and Rwanda , " Young told reporters .	Zaire ! location ; Rwanda ! location ; Young ! person ;
0	But General Baril said it would be premature to rule out any course of action until he had more information .	Baril ! person ;
0	" We hope that if the front moves forward or stabilises then we will have access ( to the large group of refugees ) with reconnaissance or humanitarian agencies .	end
0	" If they ca n't move because they are too weak , then we will probably consider very seriously using air delivery means ( airdrops ) ...It 's complex , it 's dangerous for the air crew that fly in there and it will have to be absolutely necessary .	end

0	For synthetic rubber , production reached 68,200 tonnes in 1995/96 while consumption in the same season hit 134,085 tonnes , Matthew added .	Matthew ! person ;
0	" Though schemes designed to realise further increases in the production of natural rubber are being operated successfully , the demand-supply gap is expected to widen , " he said .	end
0	Indian synthetic rubber output is not expected to rise significantly in the next season but demand will rise to 145,000 tonnes .	Indian ! mix ;
0	Matthew estimates that by the 2000/01 season , the gap between natural rubber output and consumption will rise to 51,000 tonnes and 319,000 tonnes in 2010/11 .	Matthew ! person ;

0	14 years later , Florida man dies for killing .	Florida ! location ;
0	TALLAHASSEE , Fla. 1996-12-06	TALLAHASSEE ! location ; Fla. ! location ;
0	Fourteen years after he bludgeoned and shot a man whose trailer home he robbed in 1982 , John Mills Jr .	John Mills ! person ;
0	, 41 , was put to death in Florida 's electric chair Friday .	Florida ! location ;
0	As Glenn Lawhon , a rural Florida minister who is the victim 's father , looked on , Mills was pronounced dead at 7:13 a.m. EST ( 1213 GMT ) for the murder of Lester Lawhon .	Glenn Lawhon ! person ; Florida ! location ; Mills ! person ; GMT ! mix ; Lester Lawhon ! person ;
0	Speaking in Arabic , Mills made a final statement before an anonymous citizen flipped the switch that sent 2000 volts of electricity through his body , said Department of Corrections spokesman Eugene Morris , who was present at the execution .	Arabic ! mix ; Mills ! person ; Department of Corrections ! org ; Eugene Morris ! person ;
0	" I bear witness that there is no God but Allah and I bear witness that the prophet Mohammed is the messenger of God , " he quoted Mills as saying .	God ! person ; Allah ! person ; Mohammed ! person ; God ! person ; Mills ! person ;
0	Prison officials said they had no record of Mills ' official conversion , but they said that , on May 14 , 1991 , he had asked that a new name , Yuhanna Abdullah Muhammed , be added to his prison file , which is usually an indication of a conversion to Islam .	Mills ! person ; Yuhanna Abdullah Muhammed ! person ; Islam ! mix ;
0	Mills is the 38th person to die in Florida 's electric chair since the U.S. Supreme Court reversed itself in 1976 and legalised the death penalty .	Mills ! person ; Florida ! location ; U.S. Supreme Court ! org ;
0	Prison officials said Mills made no special request for a last meal and did not eat the steak , fried potatoes and orange juice offered him .	Mills ! person ;
0	He spent Thursday with family members and his spiritual adviser , Morris said .	Morris ! person ;
0	Mills was scheduled to die Wednesday but had his sentence temporarily postponed by the Florida Supreme Court .	Mills ! person ; Florida Supreme Court ! org ;
0	On Thursday , the 11th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals in Atlanta denied his appeal in federal court .	U.S. Court of Appeals ! org ; Atlanta ! location ;
0	In March 1982 , Mills and accomplice Michael Frederick knocked on the door of Lester Lawhon 's trailer in an attempt to rob it , police said .	Mills ! person ; Michael Frederick ! person ; Lester Lawhon ! person ;
0	Lester Lawhon was taken to a nearby airstrip where he was bludgeoned with a tire iron .	Lester Lawhon ! person ;
0	Mills then fired two shots that killed Lawhon as the victim tried to run away .	Mills ! person ; Lawhon ! person ;
0	Frederick is serving a 347-year sentence .	Frederick ! person ;

0	NYMEX natgas ends sharply lower on weather outlook .	NYMEX ! org ;
0	NEW YORK 1996-12-06	NEW YORK ! location ;
0	NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures settled significantly lower Friday , pressured early by profit taking and driven even lower late by the National Weather Service 's bearish six to 10 day forecast , sources said .	NYMEX Henry Hub ! org ; National Weather Service ! location ;
0	January ended 29.7 cents lower at $ 3.487 per million British thermal units after dipping to a low of $ 3.46 .	British ! mix ;
0	Feb settled down 22 cents at $ 3.186 .	end
0	Most others also were down .	end
0	" Weather forecasts have been sketchy .	end
0	Now the National Weather Service is calling for above-normal temperatures in more than half of the U.S. , " one futures trader said .	National Weather Service ! org ; U.S. ! location ;
0	In its forecast , the NWS said it expects above-normal temperatures " over the lower 48 states " from December 12 through December 16 .	NWS ! org ;
0	With more room to the downside anticipated early next week , traders said support in January was at $ 3.47 , then $ 3.35 .	end
0	The next backstops were seen at $ 3.11 and $ 3.04 , the low set on November 21 .	end
0	Resistance was pegged at the new contract high of $ 3.80 .	end
0	In the cash market , Gulf Coast prices were around $ 3.60 shortly before nomination deadlines .	Gulf Coast ! location ;
0	Midcontinent prices were similarly lower in the $ 3.40s. New York city gate gas slipped into the $ 4.40s , down almost 15 cents .	New York ! location ;
0	NYMEX said an estimated 35,662 Hub contracts traded , down from Thursday 's revised tally of 43,955 .	NYMEX ! org ;
0	NYMEX Alberta natgas remained untraded , with January settling at $ 1.65 , off 10 cents from Thursday .	NYMEX Alberta ! org ;
0	Physical prices for the weekend at the AECO storage hub were also down about 10 cents in the C$ 1.92-1.97 per gigajoule , or $ 1.52-1.56 per mmBtu range , pressured by unseasonably mild weather in western Canada .	AECO ! org ; C$ ! mix ; Canada ! location ;
0	NYMEX Permian natgas , also untraded , ended 10 cents lower at $ 2.90 .	NYMEX Permian ! org ;
0	In congruence with futures , Permian cash prices for the weekend fell more than 10 cents to the high - $ 3.40s.	Permian ! mix ;
0	On the KCBT , January finished 26.5 cents lower at $ 3.35 after dipping to a low of $ 3.33 earlier in the session .	KCBT ! org ;
0	February was down 22 cents at the close , while other deferreds were 4.5 to nine cents lower .	end
0	The East / West spread narrowed by 3.2 cents to 13.7 cents ( NYMEX premium ) .	NYMEX ! org ;
0	Physical prices at Waha for the weekend lost more than 15 cents to the low-to-mid $ 3.50s as milder weather moved into the Southwest .	Waha ! location ;

0	Half of dog bites provoked , says American vet .	American ! mix ;
0	CHICAGO 1996-12-06	CHICAGO ! location ;
0	As many as 1 million dog bites are recorded in the United States every year and half of them are provoked by humans , a veterinarian told fellow animal doctors on Friday .	United States ! location ;
0	The Humane Society of the United States estimates that between 500,000 and one million bites are delivered by dogs each year , more than half of which are suffered by children .	United States ! location ;
0	" Most bites can be prevented by teaching children how to respect a dog , " Michael Cornwell of the Glencoe Animal Hospital in Columbus , Ohio , told the annual meeting of the American Veterinary Medical Association . 0	" Let 's not let our kids jump on them or crawl on them .	end
0	Dogs and children do n't have to have an interaction .	end
0	Let 's respect their territories , " he said .	end
0	Cornwell said 50 percent of reported bites were provoked by a person and 60 percent were suffered by children .	Cornwell ! person ;
0	He also estimated that only 25 percent of bites were reported because medical attention was not needed .	end
0	Don Rieck , president of the National Animal Control Association , said aggressiveness in dogs was related more to gender than breed and a male dog that had not been neutered was three times more likely to bite than an unspayed female .	Don Rieck ! person ; National Animal Control Association ! org ;
0	The five breeds credited with the most incidents were chow chows , Rottweilers , German shepherds , cocker spaniels and Dalmatians . "	Rottweilers ! mix ; German shepherds ! mix ; cocker spaniels ! mix ; Dalmatians ! mix ;
0	The trends in dog bites by particular breeds have more to do with fad pets owned by individuals who need to have something unique .	end
0	Speaking strictly of dogs , 15 years ago the macho fad pet was a Doberman .	Doberman ! mix ;
0	Today , Rottweilers are on the way up , " Rieck said .	Rottweilers ! mix ; Rieck ! person ;
0	If approached by a stray dog , children should be taught to stand still with fists folded underneath the neck , elbows in , and gaze forward until the dog goes away .	end

0	The nominees , according to diplomats , are : Kofi Annan of Ghana , the U.N. undersecretary-general for peacekeeping ; Ahmedou Ould Abdallah of Mauritania , the former U.N. special envoy for Burundi ; Amara Essy of the Ivory Coast , its foreign minister and the U.N. 0	It was not known if other candidates would step forward .	end

0	Boutros-Ghali on Wednesday opened the door for other Africans to contest his job by saying he was suspending temporarily his candidacy but was not withdrawing completely from the race .	Boutros-Ghali ! person ; Africans ! mix ;
0	His supporters said this meant he remained a candidate in case the race reached an impasse .	end
0	The United States on Nov. 19 vetoed his bid for re-election while the other 14 Security Council members supported him .	United States ! location ; Security Council ! org ;

0	EU , Poland agree on oil import tariffs .	EU ! org ; Poland ! location ;
0	BRUSSELS 1996-12-06	BRUSSELS ! location ;
0	The European Union and Poland have resolved disagreements over a new Polish oil import regime , the European Commission said on Friday .	European Union ! org ; Poland ! location ; Polish ! mix ; European Commission ! org ;
0	The EU had objected to increases in Polish tariffs on imports of gasoline and gasoil products introduced on January 1 , 1996 , saying they contravened levels envisaged in the so-called Europe Agreement between the EU and Poland .	EU ! org ; Polish ! mix ; Europe ! location ; EU ! org ; Poland ! location ;
0	The increases were aimed at protecting the Polish market while helping to modernise the local oil industry .	Polish ! mix ;
0	" The EU and Poland have now reached a final settlement regarding issues related to the Polish import regime in the oils sector , " the Commission said in a statement .	EU ! org ; Poland ! location ; Polish ! mix ; Commission ! org ;
0	Under the agreement , Poland will abolish all oil import tariffs by 2001 , remove all oil price controls and end quantitative restrictions on imports by January 1 , 1997 .	Poland ! location ;
0	The agreement includes the early privatisation and modernisation of Polish oil refineries , which will be obliged to offer equal treatment to all buyers .	Polish ! mix ;

0	Cyberspace squabbles overshadow copyright talks .	end
0	Elif Kaban	Elif Kaban ! person ;
0	GENEVA 1996-12-06	GENEVA ! location ;
0	In a gloomy Geneva conference centre built before the dawn of the Internet , groups of staid officials made a first stab on Friday at rewriting copyright laws for the digital age .	Geneva ! location ; Internet ! mix ;
0	But critics at the first government-level meeting to revise copyright laws in 25 years said the officials and legislators might as well be trying to police the ether .	end
0	After four days of diplomatic wrangling over procedures , some 600 delegates from nations small and large got down to the nitty-gritty of setting the digital agenda for the first time .	end
0	Cyberspace squabbles overshadowed the debate on a stack of proposals covering literary and artistic works , the rights of performers and producers of music and producers of databases .	end
0	" If it goes on like this , we wo n't have enough time to finish all the discussions , " a frustrated Western delegate said . "	end
0	They announced they will start evening sessions next week . "	end
0	Attempts by copyright-based industries to ensure they get a cut from online works led to a storm of protests by Internet companies and critics who say the pacts would curb public access to online information from soccer results to stock prices .	Internet ! mix ;
0	" It 's not illegal to make photocopies of newspaper articles .	end
0	It 's fair use .	end
0	We can read sports statistics or stock prices .	end
0	But with the treaty , this kind of fact will be owned and subject to licensing , " said James Love , a consumer lobbyist heading the Washington-based Consumer Project on Technology .	James Love ! person ; Washington-based Consumer Project ! mix ;
0	" None of the treaties are ready to move .	end
0	These people do n't understand what they 're doing . "	end
0	At stake are billions of dollars and the future of the electronic information industry -- the coming medium for the distribution of music , films , literature , software and commerce .	end
0	Supporters of the three pacts say they are only an extension of existing intellectual property rights , covered by the century-old Berne Convention .	Berne Convention ! mix ;
0	But an array of opponents from the network industry to consumer , scientific and academic groups say the pacts will give sweeping powers to entertainment and copyright-based industries .	end
0	A quick survey at the conference centre found few officials who had actually surfed the Internet .	Internet ! mix ;
0	Mongolia 's state copyright official , Gundegma Jargalshaihan , said apologetically that he had just arrived from Ulan Bator and was not aware of the details of the digital agenda .	Mongolia ! location ; Gundegma Jargalshaihan ! person ; Ulan Bator ! location ;
0	" We do n't have money for Internet in Mongolia , " he added .	Internet ! mix ; Mongolia ! location ;
0	Alexander Bavykin , deputy legal chief at Russia 's foreign ministry , said Moscow had yet to formulate a policy on copyright in cybersppace .	Alexander Bavykin ! person ; Russia ! location ; Moscow ! location ;
0	He too had never browsed the Net .	end
0	" I 've never tried it and why should I ?	end
0	There are lots of other things in this life I have n't tried either , " he said .	end
0	A visit to the computer centre offering Internet services found a lone European official clicking away on his mouse .	Internet ! mix ; European ! mix ;
0	" Internet is a potential cash cow for copyright-based industries and we need roadmaps on the information superhighway , " said Marc Pearl , vice-president of the Information Technology Association of America , a trade association of U.S. network companies opposing the treaties .	Internet ! mix ; Marc Pearl ! person ; Information Technology Association of America ! org ; U.S. ! location ;
0	" But there are a lot of dinosaurs here .	end
0	People here do n't understand Internet technology .	Internet ! mix ;
0	Because they do n't understand technology , they fear the unknown . "	end
0	Before the Internet , those whose business was to protect copyrights knew where they stood .	Internet ! mix ;
0	Their enemies were tangible if elusive , such as the people who pirated music cassettes .	end
0	But the Internet , a global computer network where anything from music to software can be duplicated and distributed at the click of a computer mouse , has ripped up the rulebooks .	Internet ! mix ;
0	Network operators said the draft laws would hold them responsible for copyright infringements in the system and expose them to multi-billion-dollar liabilities .	Network ! mix ;
0	" There are 500 million messages transmitted through the Internet everyday , " said Tim Casey of the U.S.-based MCI Communications Corporation . "	Internet ! mix ; Tim Casey ! person ; U.S.-based MCI Communications Corporation ! mix ;
0	How can we control them all ? "	end

0	FEATURE - Singapore sees prestige in hosting WTO .	Singapore ! location ; WTO ! org ;
0	Ramthan Hussain	Ramthan Hussain ! person ;
0	SINGAPORE 1996-12-06	SINGAPORE ! location ;
0	Singapore 's winning campaign to host the World Trade Organisation ( WTO ) 's first ministerial meeting reflected its ambition to play a key role in shaping global free trade , the lifeblood of its economy , analysts said .	Singapore ! location ; World Trade Organisation ! org ; WTO ! org ;
0	" As one of the world 's most externally oriented economies , Singapore has a disproportionately large stake in the WTO , " said Desmond Supple , economist at research house I.D.E.A .	Singapore ! location ; WTO ! org ; Desmond Supple ! person ; I.D.E.A ! org ;
0	" Singapore stands to benefit more than most from continued global trade liberalisation as trade is the engine of its growth , accounting for nearly three times its gross domestic product . "	Singapore ! location ;
0	The city-state met U.S. opposition two years ago in its bid to host the meeting , expected to gather 4,000 officials from 160 countries from December 9 to 13 .	U.S. ! location ;
0	In a stand some analysts linked to controversy over Singapore 's caning of an American teenager for vandalism , then-U.S. Trade Representative Mickey Kantor had said the meeting ought to be held where the WTO was going to be headquartered .	Singapore ! location ; American ! mix ; then-U.S. ! mix ; Mickey Kantor ! person ; WTO ! org ;
0	That would have meant Geneva .	Geneva ! location ;
0	But Singapore had the support of other WTO members .	Singapore ! location ; WTO ! org ;
0	Derek da Cunha , senior fellow at the Institute of Policy Studies ( ISEAS ) , said Singapore 's hosting of the conference " carries a great deal of symbolism for the city-state , underscoring its commitment to free trade and its trading links across the globe . "	Derek da Cunha ! person ; Institute of Policy Studies ! org ; ISEAS ! org ; Singapore ! location ;
0	There is the international prestige Singapore would enjoy , but " more importantly there is a genuine national interest in fostering better global free trade and an open market " , said Tan Kong Yam , head of Business Policy at the National University of Singapore .	Singapore ! location ; Tan Kong Yam ! person ; National University of Singapore ! org ;
0	At the ministerial meeting , trade ministers will review the work of the WTO and the implementation of the Uruguay Round free trade commitments under its predecessor the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ( GATT ) .	WTO ! org ; Uruguay ! location ; General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ! mix ; GATT ! mix ;
0	In June , the WTO hailed Singapore for its open market policies but the European Union and other trading powers called on Singapore to speed up the opening of its services sector .	WTO ! org ; Singapore ! location ; European Union ! org ; Singapore ! location ;
0	Supple said the struggle that Singapore had to wage in vying to host the meeting would be repeated during the talks .	Supple ! person ; Singapore ! location ;
0	" There is tension at every step of the way , " since a battle line between the West and developing countries has been drawn over the issue of linking trade liberalisation with labour rights , he said .	end
0	Supple said hosting the meeting carried prestige for Singapore , " however , this is quite intangible as the prestige factor may not necessarily lead to any additional investment and trade flows to this region . "	Supple ! person ; Singapore ! location ;
0	From a commercial point of view , the meeting would be good for Singapore 's tourism industry , Tan said .	Singapore ! location ; Tan ! person ;
0	A large part of Singapore 's workforce would be mobilised to ensure the meeting would run without a glitch but the average Singaporean " would probably not be too concerned about some of the issues , " Tan said .	Singapore ! location ; Singaporean ! mix ; Tan ! person ;
0	" But the more educated public will realise that these kind of things are important for Singapore as a small economy . "	Singapore ! location ;
0	Supple said any political gains the Singapore government would get from the WTO meeting -- ahead of a general election due by April 1997 -- would depend on how successful it was in pushing its economic agenda .	Supple ! person ; Singapore ! location ; WTO ! org ;
0	" If there are any movements toward freer trade , then Singapore 's economy and the electorate would gain , " he said . "	Singapore ! location ;
0	But I do n't think it would be wise to play up the political aspect of this .	end
0	I think political issues will take secondary importance to all these economic issues that will be displayed . "	end

0	Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp ( NTT ) said on Friday that it hopes to move into the international telecommunications business as soon as possible following the government 's decision to split NTT into three firms under a holding company . 0	" We hope to start international telephone business as soon as possible , " a company official told Reuters .	Reuters ! org ;
0	The official said the latest government decision to split the company under a holding company would allow flexibility in NTT 's international phone business .	NTT ! org ;
0	Earlier , Posts and Telecommunications Minister Hisao Horinouchi told a news conference the government plans to split NTT into three firms under a holding company , but did not specify when the restructuring would likely take effect .	Hisao Horinouchi ! person ; NTT ! org ;
0	One of the three new companies will be a long-distance operator and the other two will be local-call operators , Horinouchi said .	Horinouchi ! person ;
0	One of the local firms will operate in west Japan and the other in east Japan , he added .	Japan ! location ; Japan ! location ;
0	The long-distance operator will offer international services , Horinouchi said .	Horinouchi ! person ;
0	The NTT official said the timing of the planned split-up was uncertain because more discussions by government officials were required .	NTT ! org ;

0	CRICKET - WOOLMER MAKES SENTIMENTAL RETURN TO KANPUR .	WOOLMER ! person ; KANPUR ! location ;
0	KANPUR , India 1996-12-07	KANPUR ! location ; India ! location ;
0	South Africa 's trip to Kanpur for the third test against India has given former England test cricketer Bob Woolmer the chance of a sentimental return to his birthplace .	South Africa ! location ; Kanpur ! location ; India ! location ; England ! location ; Bob Woolmer ! person ;
0	Woolmer was born in the northern city of Kanpur when his father worked there for an insurance compnay and was himself an active cricketer .	Woolmer ! person ; Kanpur ! location ;
0	" It 's been a sentimental journey ...	end
0	A visit to India is always an intriguing experience , " Woolmer , now the South African coach , said on Saturday .	India ! location ; Woolmer ! person ; South African ! mix ;
0	Woolmer , 48 , played 19 tests for England between 1975 and 1981 .	Woolmer ! person ; England ! location ;
0	His first cricketing sojurn to India was as a member of Tony Greig 's England side in 1976-77 .	India ! location ; Tony Greig ! person ; England ! location ;
0	His father Clarence Woolmer represented United Province , now renamed Uttar Pradesh , in India 's Ranji Trophy national championship and captained the state during 1949 .	Clarence Woolmer ! person ; United Province ! location ; Uttar Pradesh ! location ; India ! location ; Ranji Trophy ! mix ;
0	Now aged 86 , Woolmer senior lives with his son in Cape Town .	Woolmer ! person ; Cape Town ! location ;
0	Woolmer 's memories of Kanpur are few and blurred .	Woolmer ! person ; Kanpur ! location ;
0	" I do n't remember much of the place , " he said . "	end
0	I came here on zero and left at three ( aged three ) when my father was transferred to Calcutta where I spent another four and half years .	Calcutta ! location ;
0	" But I do remember we had a cobra snake in the basement of our house .	end
0	Also that my father bought a bicycle and when we rode over a hose pipe it broke into two . "	end
0	Woolmer said the hospital where he was born is close to the stadium where the India-South Africa test will be played .	Woolmer ! person ; India-South Africa ! mix ;

0	ALPINE SKIING-OFFICIALS HOPE TO SALVAGE WORLD CUP WEEKEND .	WORLD CUP ! mix ;
0	WHISTLER , British Columbia 1996-12-06	WHISTLER ! location ; British Columbia ! location ;
0	World Cup ski officials hope to be able to get in at least one men 's downhill training run on Saturday in an effort to salvage the weekend racing programme .	World Cup ! mix ;
0	For the third consecutive day , Friday 's scheduled training runs were cancelled due to heavy wet snow and fog on Whistler Mountain , leaving the scheduled World Cup events in jeopardy .	Whistler Mountain ! location ; World Cup ! mix ;
0	Rules call for at least one training run to be completed before a World Cup downhill race can be staged .	World Cup ! mix ;
0	Organisers hope to get that run in on Saturday morning , conditions permitting , and stage the race later in the day or on Sunday .	end
0	" There was no possibility today to make a training run , " said Bernd Zobel , the Canadian men 's national coach , citing too much new snow and poor visibility .	Bernd Zobel ! person ; Canadian ! mix ;
0	If organisers are forced to run the downhill on Sunday , the super-giant slalom originally scheduled for Sunday would likely be abandoned .	end

0	Australia bade farewell to David Campese in spectacular fashion by overwhelming the Barbarians 39-12 in the final match of their European tour at Twickenham on Saturday .	Australia ! location ; David Campese ! person ; Barbarians ! org ; European ! mix ; Twickenham ! location ;
0	The Wallabies ran in five tries with Campese , who has retired from test rugby after collecting 101 caps and a world record 64 tries , adding one last touchdown in a Wallaby jersey before departing the international game .	Wallabies ! org ; Campese ! person ; Wallaby ! org ;
0	The Barbarians included 14 internationals but , with only two pre-match practice sessions behind them , proved no real match for a Wallaby side determined to finish their 12-match tour unbeaten .	Barbarians ! org ; Wallaby ! org ;

0	TIRANA 1996-12-07	TIRANA ! location ;
0	Albanian coach Astrit Hafizi said on Saturday it was important that his players brush aside the country 's short ban by FIFA in order to concentrate on next Saturday'sWorld Cup group nine qualifier against Northern Ireland . 0	World soccer 's governing body reinstated Albania last Tuesday after the Balkan country 's government lifted suspensions on various soccer officials .	Albania ! location ; Balkan ! location ;
0	FIFA had banned Albania indefinitely after its sports ministry had ordered the suspension of Albanian Football Association general secretary Eduard Dervishi and dissolved the executive committee .	FIFA ! org ; Albania ! location ; Albanian Football Association ! org ; Eduard Dervishi ! person ;
0	" We would be very happy with a draw in Belfast , " said Hafizi . "	Belfast ! location ; Hafizi ! person ;
0	Especially if one takes into consideration our difficult post-suspension situation and the fact Northern Ireland is very keen to win . "	Northern Ireland ! location ;

0	CRICKET - JONES HITS CENTURY AS VICTORIA FIGHT BACK .	JONES ! person ; VICTORIA ! org ;
0	HOBART , Australia 1996-12-07	HOBART ! location ; Australia ! location ;
0	Former Australia test batsman Dean Jones hit an unbeaten 130 to lead Victoria 's fightback in their Sheffield Shield match against Tasmania on Saturday .	Australia ! location ; Dean Jones ! person ; Victoria ! location ; Sheffield Shield ! mix ; Tasmania ! org ;
0	Replying to the home side 's first innings 481 for eight declared , Victoria reached 220 for three at close of play on the second day of the four-day match at Hobart 's Bellerive Oval .	Victoria ! location ; Hobart ! location ; Bellerive Oval ! location ;
0	Jones became the fourth century-maker of the match , equalling the feats of Tasmanian trio David Boon , Shaun Young and Michael DiVenuto .	Jones ! person ; Tasmanian ! mix ; David Boon ! person ; Shaun Young ! person ; Michael DiVenuto ! person ;
0	Jones , who took over as captain for the match in the absence of Australia test leg-spinner Shane Warne , added 195 runs for the third wicket with left-hander Laurie Harper .	Jones ! person ; Australia ! location ; Shane Warne ! person ; Laurie Harper ! person ;

0	South Korea made virtually certain of an Asian Cup quarter-final spot with a 4-2 win over Indonesia in a Group A match on Saturday .	South Korea ! location ; Asian Cup ! mix ; Indonesia ! location ;
0	After going four up in the first 55 minutes South Korea allowed Indonesia , newcomers to Asian Cup finals , back into the match , conceding two goals from rare counter attacks .	South Korea ! location ; Indonesia ! location ; Asian Cup ! mix ;
0	Kim Do Hoon opened the scoring for South Korea in only the fifth minute , turning unmarked on the penalty spot to fire a shot into the top corner .	Kim Do Hoon ! person ; South Korea ! location ;
0	It looked like turning into a rout as Hwang Sun Hong rapidly added two more in the seventh and 15th minutes but although the Koreans continued to dominate they failed to add to the score before the interval .	Hwang Sun Hong ! person ; Koreans ! mix ;
0	But they started the second half where they had left off and it was not long before they went four up , Ko Jeong Woon heading in from a free kick in the 55th minute .	Ko Jeong Woon ! person ;
0	The Koreans then appeared to relax , allowing the Indonesians to get back into the match .	Koreans ! mix ; Indonesians ! mix ;
0	Ronny Wabia scored for Indonesia three minutes later direct from a a corner kick that Korean goalkeeper Kim Byung reached with one hand but failed to keep out .	Ronny Wabia ! person ; Indonesia ! location ; Korean ! mix ; Kim Byung ! person ;
0	With 65 minutes gone Indonesia 's Widodo Putra , who scored a spectacular goal against Kuwait on Wednesday , was again on target , breaking through the Korean defence to beat the keeper with a low shot .	Indonesia ! location ; Widodo Putra ! person ; Kuwait ! location ; Korean ! mix ;
0	Indonesian keeper Hendro Kartiko produced a string of fine saves to prevent the Koreans increasing their lead .	Indonesian ! mix ; Hendro Kartiko ! person ; Koreans ! mix ;

0	Galley suffered a concussion and did not return to the game .	Galley ! person ;

0	SOCCER - ENGLISHMAN CHARLTON IS MADE AN HONORARY IRISHMAN .	ENGLISHMAN CHARLTON ! mix ; IRISHMAN ! person ;
0	DUBLIN 1996-12-07	DUBLIN ! location ;
0	Jack Charlton 's relationship with the people of Ireland was cemented on Saturday when the Englishman was officially declared one of their own .	Jack Charlton ! person ; Ireland ! location ; Englishman ! mix ;
0	Charlton , 61 , and his wife , Peggy , became citizens of Ireland when they formally received Irish passports from deputy Prime Minister Dick Spring who said the honour had been made in recognition of Charlton 's achievements as the national soccer manager .	Charlton ! person ; Peggy ! person ; Ireland ! location ; Irish ! mix ; Dick Spring ! person ; Charlton ! person ;
0	" The years I spent as manager of the Republic of Ireland were the best years of my life .	Republic of Ireland ! location ;
0	It all culminated in the fact that I now have lots of great , great friends in Ireland .	Ireland ! location ;
0	That is why this is so emotional a night for me , " Charlton said .	Charlton ! person ;
0	" It was the joy that we all had over the period , that I shared with people that I grew to love , that I treasure most , " he added .	end
0	Charlton managed Ireland for 93 matches , during which time they lost only 17 times in almost 10 years until he resigned in December 1995 .	Charlton ! person ; Ireland ! location ;
0	He guided Ireland to two successive World Cup finals tournaments and to the 1988 European championship finals in Germany , after the Irish beat a well-fancied England team 1-0 in their group qualifier .	Ireland ! location ; World Cup ! mix ; European ! mix ; Germany ! location ; Irish ! mix ; England ! location ;
0	The lanky former Leeds United defender did not make his England debut until the age of 30 but eventually won 35 caps and was a key member of the 1966 World Cup winning team with his younger brother , Bobby .	Leeds United ! org ; England ! location ; 1966 World Cup ! mix ; Bobby ! person ;
1	Good evening , everyone .	evening ! time ;
1	We begin tonight with a couple of urgent questions for the government .	tonight ! time ; a couple ! num ;
1	There 's a man on trial in New York for bombing the American embassy in Kenya two years ago .	New York ! country ; American ! national ; Kenya two years ago ! country ;
1	The FBI says when they questioned him , he told them of another plot to bomb an American ship in Yemen , where the `` USS Cole '' was ultimately attacked .	FBI ! org ; American ! national ; Yemen ! country ; the `` USS Cole '' ! product ;
1	Question one , did the FBI make it clear what the man had told them ?	one ! num ; FBI ! org ;

1	Gao Xingjian arrived in Stockholm this week and when he leaves the Chinese born writer will have something extra in his suitcase , the Nobel Prize for Literature .	Gao Xingjian ! person ; Stockholm this week ! country ; Chinese ! date ; the Nobel Prize for Literature ! national ;
1	Today Gao , who now lives in France , gave the traditional Nobel lecture as part of the festivities leading up to Sunday 's ceremony , and on the same day he collects the prize .	Gao ! person ; France ! country ; Nobel ! art ; Sunday ! date ;
1	Gao 's 1989 novel ` Soul Mountain ' will be published for the first time in America .	Gao ! person ; 1989 ! date ; ` Soul Mountain ' ! art ; America ! country ;
1	If you want to know what Gao Xingjian is all about , as a thinker and as an artist , our international book critic Christopher Meryl says Gao 's masterpiece is an ideal starting point .	Gao Xingjian ! person ; Christopher Meryl ! person ; Gao ! person ;
1	His politics are embedded in his writing and his writing is first and foremost a celebration of freedom .	first ! order ;
1	This novel ` soul mountain ' , which is just being released in the United States this week is in every possible way a celebration of what freedom means .	` soul mountain ' ! art ; the United States this week ! country ;
1	It 's a large novel , full of all kinds of ideas and incidents and stories and tales and a polyphony of voices .	end
1	It is , if you like , the whole world wrapped up in 500 pages .	500 ! num ;
1	It is the world at its most carnival - like , and yet it is virtually impossible , is n't it , for a Chinese artist to do something or to make a statement without its having some kind of either political effect or be political in origin .	Chinese ! national ;
1	I mean this man took the trip on which the novel was based for political reasons , did he not ?	end
1	Certainly .	end
1	He is born in 1940 .	1940 ! date ;
1	He is a product of the Cultural Revolution .	the Cultural Revolution ! thing ;
1	In fact he had to burn up an entire suitcase full of hundreds of poems and plays and stories at the start of the Cultural Revolution in fear of going to prison , and then in 1983 after being diagnosed with lung cancer , which had killed his father three years earlier and being convinced that he himself was going to die , he gets a kind of reprieve .	hundreds ! num ; the Cultural Revolution ! thing ; 1983 ! date ; three years earlier ! date ;
1	He gets a second chest X-ray , discovers that he does n't have lung cancer , recognizes that by virtue of the kinds of things that he is writing , his openness to Western literary ideas , that he is in political trouble again , and so he sets out on an extraordinary odyssey of some 15,000 kilometers , mostly on foot , which he takes through southwestern China .	second ! order ; Western ! national ; some 15,000 kilometers ! measure ; China ! country ;
1	He had survived , if you will , a death sentence , and now in that new freedom of the life in front of him , he takes to the road in the tradition of old Chinese poets and records what he sees , what he hears , the stories that he is told .	Chinese ! national ;
1	The book is filled with marvelous descriptions of the gorges through which he walks , the mountains that he climbs , indeed the book is called Soul Mountain , the mountain on which he hopes in some way or another to get in touch with his soul , his individual soul , as opposed to that mass kind of soul being enforced upon him by the Communist Chinese authorities , the social realism that the cadres would have him write in .	Soul Mountain ! art ; Communist Chinese ! national ;
1	Not only can this fellow write , he can paint too , ca n't he ?	end
1	He is best known among his neighbors in Paris as a painter .	Paris ! country ;
1	He has had more than 30 one - man shows and his paintings are quite delicately done and there he is also very well known as a playwright .	30 one ! num ;
1	I think he has published about 18 plays now and he writes his plays in French .	about 18 ! num ; French ! language ;
1	Just one last thing quoting him and I wonder if you could respond to this , Christopher , he said at the very beginning of his wonderful speech to the Nobel Prize Committee , he said , `` I do not wish to waste this talk on literature by saying too much about politics and history , What I want to do is to use this opportunity to speak as one writer in the voice of an individual . ''	one ! num ; Christopher ! person ; the Nobel Prize Committee ! org ;
1	Is that true basically not only for him that day , today , but of all of his work ?	that day , today ! date ;
1	Well , the work that we have so far in English translation suggests that , and indeed this novel , which is a celebration as well of the self of the individual , goes so far as to even divide up to the self .	English ! language ;
1	Characters proliferate out of the imagination of the narrator so that at a certain point , you have a new he , you have a new she , you have a you , and each one of these characters tells stories , each story of which is designed to give you a deeper sense of the richness and the complexity of life in China .	China ! country ;
1	Christopher Meryl is Director of the International Writing Program at the University of Iowa and our international book citric .	Christopher Meryl ! person ; the International Writing Program ! org ; the University of Iowa ! org ;
1	Thanks , Christopher .	Christopher ! person ;
1	Thank you .	end

1	Jesus called his twelve apostles together .	end
1	He gave them power to heal sicknesses and power to force demons out of people .	end
1	He sent them to tell about God 's kingdom and to heal the sick .	end
1	He said to them , `` When you travel , do n't take a walking stick .	end
1	Also , do n't carry a bag , food , or money .	end
1	Take for your trip only the clothes you are wearing .	end
1	When you go into a house , stay there until it is time to leave .	end
1	If the people in the town will not welcome you , go outside the town and shake the dust off your feet as a warning to them . ''	end
1	So the apostles went out .	end
1	They traveled through all the towns .	end
1	They told the Good News and healed people everywhere .	end
1	Herod the ruler heard about all these things that were happening .	end
1	He was confused because some people said , `` John the Baptizer has risen from death . ''	end
1	Others said , `` Elijah has come to us . ''	end
1	And some others said , `` One of the prophets from long ago has risen from death . ''	end
1	Herod said , `` I cut off John 's head .	end
1	So who is this man I hear these things about ? ''	end
1	Herod continued trying to see Jesus .	end
1	When the apostles came back , they told Jesus what they had done on their trip .	end
1	Then he took them away to a town called Bethsaida .	end
1	There , he and his apostles could be alone together .	end
1	But the people learned where Jesus went and followed him .	end
1	He welcomed them and talked with them about God 's kingdom .	end
1	He healed the people who were sick .	end
1	Late in the afternoon , the twelve apostles came to Jesus and said , `` No one lives in this place .	end

1	They need to find food and places to sleep in the farms and towns around here . ''	end
1	But Jesus said to the apostles , `` You give them something to eat . ''	end
1	They said , `` We have only five loaves of bread and two fish .	end
1	Do you want us to go buy food for all these people ? ''	end
1	There are too many !	end
1	-LRB- There were about 5000 men there . -RRB-	end
1	Jesus said to his followers , `` Tell the people to sit in groups of about 50 people . ''	end
1	So the followers did this and everyone sat down .	end
1	Then Jesus took the five loaves of bread and two fish .	end
1	He looked up into the sky and thanked God for the food .	end
1	Then he broke it into pieces , which he gave to the followers to give to the people .	end
1	They all ate until they were full .	end
1	And there was a lot of food left .	end
1	Twelve baskets were filled with the pieces of food that were not eaten .	end
1	One time Jesus was praying alone .	end
1	His followers came together there , and he asked them , `` Who do the people say I am ? ''	end
1	They answered , `` Some people say you are John the Baptizer .	end
1	Others say you are Elijah .	end
1	And some people say you are one of the prophets from long ago that has come back to life . ''	end

1	Peter answered , `` You are the Christ from God . ''	end
1	Jesus warned them not to tell anyone .	end
1	Then Jesus said , `` The Son of Man must suffer many things .	end
1	He will be rejected by the older Jewish leaders , the leading priests , and teachers of the law .	end
1	And he will be killed .	end
1	But after three days he will be raised from death . ''	end
1	Jesus continued to say to all of them , `` Any of you who want to be my follower must stop thinking about yourself and what you want .	end
1	You must be willing to carry the cross that is given to you every day for following me .	end
1	Any of you who try to save the life you have will lose it .	end
1	But you who give up your life for me will save it .	end
1	It is worth nothing for you to have the whole world if you yourself are destroyed or lost .	end
1	Do n't be ashamed of me and my teaching .	end
1	If that happens , I will be ashamed of you when I come with my divine greatness and that of the Father and the holy angels .	end
1	Believe me when I say that some of you people standing here will see God 's kingdom before you die . ''	end

1	While Jesus was praying , his face began to change .	end
1	His clothes became shining white .	end

1	They were Moses and Elijah .	end
1	They also looked bright and glorious .	end
1	They were talking with Jesus about his death that would happen in Jerusalem .	end
1	Peter and the others were asleep .	end
1	But they woke up and saw the glory of Jesus .	end
1	They also saw the two men who were standing with him .	end
1	When Moses and Elijah were leaving , Peter said , ``	end
1	Master , it is good that we are here .	end
1	We will put three tents here -- one for you , one for Moses , and one for Elijah . ''	end

1	He is the one I have chosen .	end
1	Obey him . ''	end
1	When the voice stopped , only Jesus was there .	end

1	The next day , Jesus , Peter , John , and James came down from the mountain .	end
1	A large group of people met Jesus .	end

1	He loses control of himself and foams at the mouth .	end
1	The evil spirit continues to hurt him and almost never leaves him .	end
1	I begged your followers to make the evil spirit leave my son , but they could not do it . ''	end
1	Jesus answered , `` You people today have no faith .	end
1	Your lives are all wrong .	end
1	How long must I be with you and be patient with you ? ''	end
1	Then Jesus said to the man , `` Bring your son here . ''	end
1	While the boy was coming , the demon threw the boy to the ground .	end
1	The boy lost control of himself .	end
1	But Jesus gave a strong command to the evil spirit .	end
1	Then the boy was healed , and Jesus gave him back to his father .	end

1	The people were still amazed about all the things Jesus did .	end

1	But they were afraid to ask Jesus about what he said .	end

1	And anyone who accepts me is also accepting the one who sent me .	end
1	The one among you who is the most humble -- this is the one who is great . ''	end

1	We told him to stop because he does not belong to our group . ''	end
1	Jesus said to him , `` Do n't stop him .	end
1	Whoever is not against you is for you . ''	end

1	But Jesus turned and criticized them for saying this .	end
1	Then he and his followers went to another town .	end
1	They were all traveling along the road .	end

1	He answered , `` The foxes have holes to live in .	end
1	The birds have nests .	end
1	But the Son of Man has no place where he can rest his head . ''	end

1	Another man said , `` I will follow you , Lord , but first let me go and say goodbye to my family . ''	end
1	Jesus said , `` Anyone who begins to plow a field but looks back is not prepared for God 's kingdom . ''	end
1	Jesus was going through the city of Jericho .	end
1	In Jericho there was a man named Zacchaeus .	end
1	He was a wealthy , very important tax collector .	end
1	He wanted to see who Jesus was .	end
1	There were many others who wanted to see Jesus too .	end
1	Zacchaeus was too short to see above the people .	end
1	So he ran to a place where he knew Jesus would come .	end
1	Then he climbed a sycamore tree so he could see him .	end
1	When Jesus came to where Zacchaeus was , he looked up and saw him in the tree .	end
1	Jesus said , `` Zacchaeus , hurry !	end
1	Come down !	end
1	I must stay at your house today . ''	end
1	Zacchaeus hurried and came down .	end
1	He was happy to have Jesus in his house .	end
1	Everyone saw this .	end
1	They began to complain , `` Look at the kind of man Jesus is staying with .	end
1	Zacchaeus is a sinner ! ''	end
1	Zacchaeus said to the Lord , `` I want to do good .	end
1	I will give half of my money to the poor .	end
1	If I have cheated anyone , I will pay them back four times more . ''	end
1	Jesus said , `` Today is the day for this family to be saved from sin .	end
1	Yes , even this tax collector is one of God 's chosen people .	end
1	The Son of Man came to find lost people and save them . ''	end
1	As the crowd listened to what he was saying , Jesus went on to tell a story .	end
1	He was now near Jerusalem and knew that the people thought it was almost time for God 's kingdom to come .	end
1	So he said , `` A very important man was preparing to go to a country far away to be made a king .	end
1	Then he planned to return home and rule his people .	end
1	So he called ten of his servants together .	end
1	He gave a bag of money to each servant .	end
1	He said , ' Do business with this money until I come back . '	end
1	But the people in the kingdom hated the man .	end
1	They sent a group to follow him to the other country .	end
1	There they said , ' We do n't want this man to be our king . '	end
1	`` But the man was made king .	end
1	When he came home , he said , ' Call those servants who have my money .	end
1	I want to know how much more money they earned with it . '	end
1	The first servant came and said , ' Sir , I earned ten bags of money with the one bag you gave me . '	end
1	The king said to him , ' That 's great !	end
1	You are a good servant .	end
1	I see that I can trust you with small things .	end
1	So now I will let you rule over ten of my cities . '	end
1	`` The second servant said , ' Sir , with your one bag of money I earned five bags . '	end
1	The king said to this servant , ' You can rule over five cities . '	end
1	`` Then another servant came in and said to the king , ' Sir , here is your bag of money .	end
1	I wrapped it in a piece of cloth and hid it .	end
1	I was afraid of you because you are a hard man .	end
1	You even take money that you did n't earn and gather food that you did n't grow . '	end
1	`` Then the king said to him , ' What a bad servant you are !	end
1	I will use your own words to condemn you .	end
1	You said that I am a hard man .	end
1	You said that I even take money that I did n't earn and gather food that I did n't grow .	end
1	If that is true , you should have put my money in the bank .	end
1	Then , when I came back , my money would have earned some interest . '	end
1	Then the king said to the men who were watching , ' Take the bag of money away from this servant and give it to the servant who earned ten bags of money . '	end
1	`` The men said to the king , ' But sir , that servant already has ten bags of money . '	end
1	`` The king said , ' People who use what they have will get more .	end
1	But those who do not use what they have will have everything taken away from them .	end
1	Now where are my enemies ?	end
1	Where are the people who did not want me to be king ?	end
1	Bring my enemies here and kill them .	end
1	I will watch them die . ' ''	end
1	After Jesus said these things , he continued traveling toward Jerusalem .	end
1	He came near Bethphage and Bethany , towns near the hill called the Mount of Olives .	end

1	He said , `` Go into the town you can see there .	end
1	When you enter the town , you will find a young donkey tied there that no one has ever ridden .	end
1	Untie it , and bring it here to me .	end
1	If anyone asks you why you are taking the donkey , you should say , ' The Master needs it . ' ''	end
1	The two followers went into town .	end
1	They found the donkey exactly like Jesus told them .	end
1	They untied it , but its owners came out .	end

1	The followers answered , `` The Master needs it . ''	end
1	So the followers brought the donkey to Jesus .	end
1	They put their coats on its back .	end

1	He was already near the bottom of the Mount of Olives .	end
