1	Jesus came near Jerusalem .	end
1	Looking at the city , he began to cry for it and said , `` I wish you knew today what would bring you peace .	end
1	But it is hidden from you now .	end
1	A time is coming when your enemies will build a wall around you and hold you in on all sides .	end
1	They will destroy you and all your people .	end
1	Not one stone of your buildings will stay on top of another .	end
1	All this will happen because you did not know the time when God came to save you . ''	end
1	Jesus went into the Temple area .	end
1	He began to throw out the people who were selling things there .	end
1	He said , `` The Scriptures say , ' My Temple will be a house of prayer . '	end
1	But you have changed it into a ' hiding place for thieves . ' ''	end
1	Jesus taught the people in the Temple area every day .	end
1	The leading priests , the teachers of the law , and some of the leaders of the people wanted to kill him .	end
1	But they did not know how they could do it , because everyone was listening to him .	end
1	The people were very interested in what Jesus said .	end
1	I really do n't need to write to you about this help for God 's people .	end
1	I know that you want to help .	end
1	I have been bragging about you to the people in Macedonia .	end
1	I told them that you people in Achaia have been ready to give since last year .	end
1	And your desire to give has made most of the people here ready to give also .	end
1	But I am sending the brothers to you .	end
1	I do n't want our bragging about you in this to be for nothing .	end
1	I want you to be ready just as I said you would be .	end
1	If any of those from Macedonia come with me , and they find that you are not ready , we will be ashamed .	end
1	We will be ashamed that we were so sure of you .	end
1	And you will be ashamed too !	end
1	So I thought that I should ask these brothers to come there before we do .	end
1	They will help in getting together the generous gift you promised .	end
1	Then it will be ready when we come , and it will be seen as a blessing you are giving , not as something you were forced to do .	end
1	Remember this : The one who plants few seeds will have a small harvest .	end
1	But the one who plants a lot will have a big harvest .	end
1	Each one of you should give what you have decided in your heart to give .	end
1	You should not give if it makes you unhappy or if you feel forced to give .	end
1	God loves those who are happy to give .	end
1	And God can give you more blessings than you need , and you will always have plenty of everything .	end
1	You will have enough to give to every good work .	end
1	As the Scriptures say , `` He gives generously to the poor ; his goodness will continue forever . ''	end
1	God is the one who gives seed to those who plant , and he gives bread for food .	end
1	And God will give you spiritual seed and make that seed grow .	end
1	He will produce a great harvest from your goodness .	end
1	God will make you rich in every way so that you can always give freely .	end
1	And your giving through us will make people give thanks to God .	end
1	The service you are offering helps God 's people with their needs , but that is not all it does .	end
1	It is also bringing more and more thanks to God .	end
1	This service is a proof of your faith , and people will praise God because of it .	end
1	They will praise him because you are following the message about Christ -- the message you say you believe .	end
1	They will praise God because you freely share with them and with all people .	end
1	And when they pray , they will wish they could be with you .	end
1	They will feel this way because of the great grace that God gave you .	end
1	Thanks be to God for his gift that is too wonderful to describe .	end
1	While Apollos was in the city of Corinth , Paul was visiting some places on his way to Ephesus .	end
1	In Ephesus he found some other followers of the Lord .	end
1	He asked them , `` Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed ? ''	end
1	These followers said to him , `` We have never even heard of a Holy Spirit ! ''	end
1	Paul asked them , `` So what kind of baptism did you have ? ''	end
1	They said , `` It was the baptism that John taught . ''	end
1	Paul said , `` John told people to be baptized to show they wanted to change their lives .	end
1	He told people to believe in the one who would come after him , and that one is Jesus . ''	end
1	When these followers heard this , they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus .	end
1	Then Paul laid his hands on them , and the Holy Spirit came on them .	end
1	They began speaking different languages and prophesying .	end
1	There were about twelve men in this group .	end
1	Paul went into the synagogue and spoke very boldly .	end
1	He continued doing this for three months .	end
1	He talked with the Jews , trying to persuade them to accept what he was telling them about God 's kingdom .	end
1	But some of them became stubborn and refused to believe .	end
1	In front of everyone , they said bad things about the Way .	end
1	So Paul left these Jews and took the Lord 's followers with him .	end
1	He went to a place where a man named Tyrannus had a school .	end
1	There Paul talked with people every day .	end
1	He did this for two years .	end
1	Because of this work , everyone in Asia , Jews and Greeks , heard the word of the Lord .	end
1	God used Paul to do some very special miracles .	end
1	Some people carried away handkerchiefs and clothes that Paul had used and put them on those who were sick .	end
1	The sick people were healed , and evil spirits left them .	end
1	Some Jews also were traveling around forcing evil spirits out of people .	end
1	The seven sons of Sceva , one of the leading priests , were doing this .	end
1	These Jews tried to use the name of the Lord Jesus to make the evil spirits go out of people .	end
1	They all said , `` By the same Jesus that Paul talks about , I order you to come out ! ''	end
1	But one time an evil spirit said to these Jews , `` I know Jesus , and I know about Paul , but who are you ? ''	end
1	Then the man who had the evil spirit inside him jumped on these Jews .	end
1	He was much stronger than all of them .	end
1	He beat them up and tore their clothes off .	end
1	They all ran away from that house .	end
1	All the people in Ephesus , Jews and Greeks , learned about this .	end
1	They were all filled with fear and gave great honor to the Lord Jesus .	end
1	Many of the believers began to confess , telling about all the evil things they had done .	end
1	Some of them had used magic .	end
1	These believers brought their magic books and burned them before everyone .	end
1	These books were worth about 50 , 000 silver coins .	end
1	This is how the word of the Lord was spreading in a powerful way , causing more and more people to believe .	end
1	After this , Paul made plans to go to Jerusalem .	end
1	He planned to go through the regions of Macedonia and Achaia , and then go to Jerusalem .	end
1	He thought , `` After I visit Jerusalem , I must also visit Rome . ''	end
1	Timothy and Erastus were two of his helpers .	end
1	Paul sent them ahead to Macedonia .	end
1	But he stayed in Asia for a while .	end
1	But during that time there was some trouble in Ephesus about the Way .	end
1	This is how it all happened : There was a man named Demetrius .	end
1	He worked with silver .	end
1	He made little silver models that looked like the temple of the goddess Artemis .	end
1	The men who did this work made a lot of money .	end
1	Demetrius had a meeting with these men and some others who did the same kind of work .	end
1	He told them , `` Men , you know that we make a lot of money from our business .	end
1	But look at what this man Paul is doing .	end
1	Listen to what he is saying .	end
1	He has convinced many people in Ephesus and all over Asia to change their religion .	end
1	He says the gods that people make by hand are not real .	end
1	I 'm afraid this is going to turn people against our business .	end
1	But there is also another problem .	end
1	People will begin to think that the temple of the great goddess Artemis is not important .	end
1	Her greatness will be destroyed .	end
1	And Artemis is the goddess that everyone in Asia and the whole world worships . ''	end
1	When the men heard this , they became very angry .	end
1	They shouted , `` Great is Artemis , the goddess of Ephesus ! ''	end
1	The whole city was thrown into confusion .	end
1	The people grabbed Gaius and Aristarchus , men from Macedonia who were traveling with Paul , and rushed all together into the stadium .	end
1	Paul wanted to go in and talk to the people , but the Lord 's followers did not let him go .	end
1	Also , some leaders of the country who were friends of Paul sent him a message telling him not to go into the stadium .	end
1	Some people were shouting one thing and others were shouting something else .	end
1	The meeting was very confused .	end
1	Most of the people did not know why they had come there .	end
1	Some Jews made a man named Alexander stand before the crowd , and they told him what to say .	end
1	Alexander waved his hand , trying to explain things to the people .	end
1	But when the people saw that Alexander was a Jew , they all began shouting the same thing .	end
1	For two hours they continued shouting , `` Great is Artemis of Ephesus !	end
1	Great is Artemis of Ephesus !	end
1	Great is Artemis . . . ! ''	end
1	Then the city clerk persuaded the people to be quiet .	end
1	He said , `` Men of Ephesus , everyone knows that Ephesus is the city that keeps the temple of the great goddess Artemis .	end
1	Everyone knows that we also keep her holy rock .	end
1	No one can deny this , so you should be quiet .	end
1	You must stop and think before you do anything else .	end
1	`` You brought these men here , but they have not said anything bad against our goddess .	end
1	They have not stolen anything from her temple .	end
1	We have courts of law and there are judges .	end
1	Do Demetrius and those men who work with him have a charge against anyone ?	end
1	They should go to the courts .	end
1	Let them argue with each other there .	end
1	`` Is there something else you want to talk about ?	end
1	Then come to the regular town meeting of the people .	end
1	It can be decided there .	end
1	I say this because someone might see this trouble today and say we are rioting .	end
1	We could not explain all this trouble , because there is no real reason for this meeting . ''	end
1	After the city clerk said this , he told the people to go home .	end
1	In Jerusalem Saul was still trying to scare the followers of the Lord , even saying he would kill them .	end
1	He went to the high priest and asked him to write letters to the synagogues in the city of Damascus .	end
1	Saul wanted the high priest to give him the authority to find people in Damascus who were followers of the Way .	end
1	If he found any believers there , men or women , he would arrest them and bring them back to Jerusalem .	end
1	So Saul went to Damascus .	end
1	When he came near the city , a very bright light from heaven suddenly shined around him .	end
1	He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him , `` Saul , Saul !	end
1	Why are you persecuting me ? ''	end
1	Saul said , `` Who are you , Lord ? ''	end
1	The voice answered , `` I am Jesus , the one you are persecuting .	end
1	Get up now and go into the city .	end
1	Someone there will tell you what you must do . ''	end
1	The men traveling with Saul just stood there , unable to speak .	end
1	They heard the voice , but they saw no one .	end
1	Saul got up from the ground and opened his eyes , but he could not see .	end
1	So the men with him held his hand and led him into Damascus .	end
1	For three days Saul could not see ; he did not eat or drink .	end
1	There was a follower of Jesus in Damascus named Ananias .	end
1	In a vision the Lord said to him , `` Ananias ! ''	end
1	Ananias answered , `` Here I am , Lord . ''	end
1	The Lord said to him , `` Get up and go to the street called Straight Street .	end
1	Find the house of Judas and ask for a man named Saul from the city of Tarsus .	end
1	He is there now , praying .	end
1	He has seen a vision in which a man named Ananias came and laid his hands on him so that he could see again . ''	end
1	But Ananias answered , `` Lord , many people have told me about this man .	end
1	They told me about the many bad things he did to your holy people in Jerusalem .	end
1	Now he has come here to Damascus .	end
1	The leading priests have given him the power to arrest all people who trust in you . ''	end
1	But the Lord Jesus said to Ananias , `` Go !	end
1	I have chosen Saul for an important work .	end
1	He must tell about me to other nations and their rulers and to the people of Israel .	end
1	I will show him all that he must suffer for me . ''	end
1	So Ananias left and went to the house of Judas .	end
1	He laid his hands on Saul and said , `` Saul , my brother , the Lord Jesus sent me .	end
1	He is the one you saw on the road when you came here .	end
1	He sent me so that you can see again and also be filled with the Holy Spirit . ''	end
1	Immediately , something that looked like fish scales fell off Saul 's eyes .	end
1	He was able to see !	end
1	Then he got up and was baptized .	end
1	After he ate , he began to feel strong again .	end
1	Saul stayed with the followers of Jesus in Damascus for a few days .	end
1	Soon he began to go to the synagogues and tell people about Jesus .	end
1	He told the people , `` Jesus is the Son of God ! ''	end
1	All the people who heard Saul were amazed .	end
1	They said , `` This is the same man who was in Jerusalem trying to destroy the people who trust in Jesus !	end
1	And that 's why he has come here -- to arrest the followers of Jesus and take them back to the leading priests . ''	end
1	But Saul became more and more powerful in proving that Jesus is the Christ .	end
1	His proofs were so strong that the Jews who lived in Damascus could not argue with him .	end
1	After many days , some Jews made plans to kill Saul .	end
1	They were watching the city gates day and night .	end
1	They wanted to kill Saul , but he learned about their plan .	end
1	One night some followers that Saul had taught helped him leave the city .	end
1	They put him in a basket and lowered it down through a hole in the city wall .	end
1	Then Saul went to Jerusalem .	end
1	He tried to join the group of followers , but they were all afraid of him .	end
1	They did not believe that he was really a follower of Jesus .	end
1	But Barnabas accepted Saul and took him to the apostles .	end
1	He told them how Saul had seen the Lord on the road and how the Lord had spoken to Saul .	end
1	Then he told them how boldly Saul had spoken for the Lord in Damascus .	end
1	And so Saul stayed with the followers and went all around Jerusalem speaking boldly for the Lord .	end
1	He often had arguments with the Greek - speaking Jews , who began making plans to kill him .	end
1	When the believers learned about this , they took Saul to Caesarea , and from there they sent him to the city of Tarsus .	end
1	The church in Judea , Galilee , and Samaria had a time of peace .	end
1	With the help of the Holy Spirit , the groups of believers became stronger and showed their respect for the Lord by the way they lived .	end
1	So the church everywhere grew in numbers .	end
1	Peter was traveling through all the areas around Jerusalem , and he stopped to visit the believers who lived in Lydda .	end
1	There he met a man named Aeneas , who was paralyzed and had not been able to get out of bed for the past eight years .	end
1	Peter said to him , `` Aeneas , Jesus Christ heals you .	end
1	Get up and make your bed ! ''	end
1	He stood up immediately .	end
1	All the people living in Lydda and on the plain of Sharon saw him , and they decided to follow the Lord .	end
1	In the city of Joppa there was a follower of Jesus named Tabitha .	end
1	Her Greek name , Dorcas , means `` a deer . ''	end
1	She was always doing good things for people and giving money to those in need .	end
1	While Peter was in Lydda , Tabitha became sick and died .	end
1	They washed her body and put it in an upstairs room .	end
1	The followers in Joppa heard that Peter was in Lydda , which was not far away .	end
1	So they sent two men , who begged him , `` Hurry , please come quickly ! ''	end
1	Peter got ready and went with them .	end
1	When he arrived , they took him to the upstairs room .	end
1	All the widows stood around him .	end
1	They were crying and showing him the coats and other clothes that Tabitha had made during her time with them .	end
1	Peter sent all the people out of the room .	end
1	He knelt down and prayed .	end
1	Then he turned to Tabitha 's body and said , `` Tabitha , stand up ! ''	end
1	She opened her eyes .	end
1	When she saw Peter , she sat up .	end
1	He gave her his hand and helped her stand up .	end
1	Then he called the believers and the widows into the room .	end
1	He showed them Tabitha ; she was alive !	end
1	People everywhere in Joppa learned about this , and many believed in the Lord .	end
1	Peter stayed in Joppa for many days at the home of a man named Simon , who was a leatherworker .	end
1	The first agreement had rules for worship and a place for worship here on earth .	end
1	This place was inside a tent .	end
1	The first area in the tent was called the Holy Place .	end
1	In the Holy Place were the lamp and the table with the special bread offered to God .	end
1	Behind the second curtain was a room called the Most Holy Place .	end
1	In the Most Holy Place was a golden altar for burning incense .	end
1	And also there was the Box of the Agreement .	end
1	The Box was covered with gold .	end
1	Inside this Box was a golden jar of manna and Aaron 's rod -- the rod that once grew leaves .	end
1	Also in the Box were the flat stones with the Ten Commandments of the old agreement on them .	end
1	Above the Box were the Cherub angels that showed God 's glory .	end
1	These Cherub angels were over the place of mercy .	end
1	But we can not say everything about this now .	end
1	Everything in the tent was made ready in the way I have explained .	end
1	Then the priests went into the first room every day to do their worship duties .	end
1	But only the high priest could go into the second room , and he went in only once a year .	end
1	Also , he could never enter that room without taking blood with him .	end
1	He offered that blood to God for himself and for the sins the people committed without knowing they were sinning .	end
1	The Holy Spirit uses those two separate rooms to teach us that the way into the Most Holy Place was not open while the first room was still there .	end
1	This is an example for us today .	end
1	It shows that the gifts and sacrifices the priests offer to God are not able to make the consciences of the worshipers completely clear .	end
1	These gifts and sacrifices are only about food and drink and special washings .	end
1	They are only rules about the body .	end
1	God gave them for his people to follow until the time of his new way .	end
1	But Christ has already come to be the high priest .	end
1	He is the high priest of the good things we now have .	end
1	But Christ does not serve in a place like the tent that those other priests served in .	end
1	He serves in a better place .	end
1	Unlike that tent , this one is perfect .	end
1	It was not made by anyone here on earth .	end
1	It does not belong to this world .	end
1	Christ entered the Most Holy Place only one time -- enough for all time .	end
1	He entered the Most Holy Place by using his own blood , not the blood of goats or young bulls .	end
1	He entered there and made us free from sin forever .	end
1	The blood of goats and bulls and the ashes of a cow were sprinkled on those who were no longer pure enough to enter the place of worship .	end
1	The blood and ashes made them pure again -- but only their bodies .	end
1	So surely the blood sacrifice of Christ can do much more .	end
1	Christ offered himself through the eternal Spirit as a perfect sacrifice to God .	end
1	His blood will make us completely clean from the evil we have done .	end
1	It will give us clear consciences so that we can worship the living God .	end
1	So Christ brings a new agreement from God to his people .	end
1	He brings this agreement so that those who are chosen by God can have the blessings God promised , blessings that last forever .	end
1	This can happen only because Christ died to free people from sins committed against the commands of the first agreement .	end
1	When someone dies and leaves a will , there must be proof that the one who wrote the will is dead .	end
1	A will means nothing while the one who wrote it is still living .	end
1	It can be used only after that person 's death .	end
1	That is why blood was needed to begin the first agreement between God and his people .	end
1	First , Moses told the people every command in the law .	end
1	Then he took the blood of young bulls and mixed it with water .	end
1	He used red wool and a branch of hyssop to sprinkle the blood and water on the book of the law and on all the people .	end
1	Then he said , `` This is the blood that makes the agreement good -- the agreement that God commanded you to follow . ''	end
1	In the same way , Moses sprinkled the blood on the Holy Tent .	end
1	He sprinkled the blood over everything used in worship .	end
1	The law says that almost everything must be made clean by blood .	end
1	Sins can not be forgiven without a blood sacrifice .	end
1	These things are copies of the real things that are in heaven .	end
1	These copies had to be made clean by animal sacrifices .	end
1	But the real things in heaven must have much better sacrifices .	end
1	Christ went into the Most Holy Place .	end
1	But it was not the man - made one , which is only a copy of the real one .	end
1	He went into heaven , and he is there now before God to help us .	end
1	The high priest enters the Most Holy Place once every year .	end
1	He takes with him blood to offer .	end
1	But he does not offer his own blood like Christ did .	end
1	Christ went into heaven , but not to offer himself many times like the high priest offers blood again and again .	end
1	If Christ had offered himself many times , he would have needed to suffer many times since the time the world was made .	end
1	But he came to offer himself only once .	end
1	And that once is enough for all time .	end
1	He came at a time when the world is nearing an end .	end
1	He came to take away all sin by offering himself as a sacrifice .	end
1	Everyone must die once .	end
1	Then they are judged .	end
1	So Christ was offered as a sacrifice one time to take away the sins of many people .	end
1	And he will come a second time , but not to offer himself for sin .	end
1	He will come the second time to bring salvation to those who are waiting for him .	end
1	I am a free man .	end
1	I am an apostle .	end
1	I have seen Jesus our Lord .	end
1	You people are an example of my work in the Lord .	end
1	Others may not accept me as an apostle , but surely you do .	end
1	You are proof that I am an apostle in the Lord .	end
1	Some people want to judge me .	end
1	So this is the answer I give them : We have the right to eat and drink , do n't we ?	end
1	We have the right to bring a believing wife with us when we travel , do n't we ?	end
1	The other apostles and the Lord 's brothers and Peter all do this .	end
1	And are Barnabas and I the only ones who must work to earn our living ?	end
1	No soldier ever serves in the army and pays his own salary .	end
1	No one ever plants a vineyard without eating some of the grapes himself .	end
1	No one takes care of a flock of sheep without drinking some of the milk himself .	end
1	These are n't just my own thoughts .	end
1	God 's law says the same thing .	end
1	Yes , it is written in the Law of Moses : ``	end
1	When a work animal is being used to separate grain , do n't keep it from eating the grain . ''	end
1	When God said this , was he thinking only about work animals ?	end
1	No .	end
1	He was really talking about us .	end
1	Yes , that was written for us .	end
1	The one who plows and the one who separates the grain should both expect to get some of the grain for their work .	end
1	We planted spiritual seed among you , so we should be able to harvest from you some things for this life .	end
1	Surely that is not asking too much .	end
1	Others have this right to get things from you .	end
1	So surely we have this right too .	end
1	But we do n't use this right .	end
1	No , we endure everything ourselves so that we will not stop anyone from obeying the Good News of Christ .	end
1	Surely you know that those who work at the Temple get their food from the Temple .	end
1	And those who serve at the altar get part of what is offered at the altar .	end
1	It is the same with those who have the work of telling the Good News .	end
1	The Lord has commanded that those who tell the Good News should get their living from this work .	end
1	But I have not used any of these rights , and I am not trying to get anything from you .	end
1	That is not my purpose for writing this .	end
1	I would rather die than to have someone take away what for me is a great source of pride .	end
1	It 's not my work of telling the Good News that gives me any reason to boast .	end
1	That is my duty -- something I must do .	end
1	If I do n't tell people the Good News , I am in real trouble .	end
1	If I did it because it was my own choice , I would deserve to be paid .	end
1	But I have no choice .	end
1	I must tell the Good News .	end
1	So I am only doing the duty that was given to me .	end
1	So what do I get for doing it ?	end
1	My reward is that when I tell people the Good News I can offer it to them for free and not use the rights that come with doing this work .	end
1	I am free .	end
1	I belong to no other person , but I make myself a slave to everyone .	end
1	I do this to help save as many people as I can .	end
1	To the Jews I became like a Jew so that I could help save Jews .	end
1	I myself am not ruled by the law , but to those who are ruled by the law I became like someone who is ruled by the law .	end
1	I did this to help save those who are ruled by the law .	end
1	To those who are without the law I became like someone who is without the law .	end
1	I did this to help save those who are without the law .	end
1	-LRB- But really , I am not without God 's law -- I am ruled by the law of Christ . -RRB-	end
1	To those who are weak , I became weak so that I could help save them .	end
1	I have become all things to all people .	end
1	I did this so that I could save people in any way possible .	end
1	I do all this to make the Good News known .	end
1	I do it so that I can share in the blessings of the Good News .	end
1	You know that in a race all the runners run , but only one runner gets the prize .	end
1	So run like that .	end
1	Run to win !	end
1	All who compete in the games use strict training .	end
1	They do this so that they can win a prize -- one that does n't last .	end
1	But our prize is one that will last forever .	end
1	So I run like someone who has a goal .	end
1	I fight like a boxer who is hitting something , not just the air .	end
1	It is my own body I fight to make it do what I want .	end
1	I do this so that I wo n't miss getting the prize myself after telling others about it .	end
1	The fifth angel blew his trumpet .	end
1	Then I saw a star fall from the sky to the earth .	end
1	The star was given the key to the deep hole that leads down to the bottomless pit .	end
1	Then the star opened the hole leading to the pit .	end
1	Smoke came up from the hole like smoke from a big furnace .	end
1	The sun and sky became dark because of the smoke from the hole .	end
1	Then locusts came out of the smoke and went down to the earth .	end
1	They were given the power to sting like scorpions .	end
1	They were told not to damage the fields of grass or any plant or tree .	end
1	They were to hurt only those who did not have God 's mark on their foreheads .	end
1	They were not given the power to kill them but only to cause them pain for five months -- pain like a person feels when stung by a scorpion .	end

1	They will want to die , but death will hide from them .	end

1	On their heads they wore something that looked like a gold crown .	end

1	Their hair was like women 's hair .	end
1	Their teeth were like lions ' teeth .	end

1	A third of all the people on earth were killed by these three plagues coming out of the horses ' mouths : the fire , the smoke , and the sulfur .	end

1	Their tails were like snakes that have heads to bite and hurt people .	end

1	Whose sin made it happen ?	end
1	Was it his own sin or that of his parents ? ''	end

1	The night is coming , and no one can work at night .	end
1	While I am in the world , I am the light of the world . ''	end

1	He answered , `` He is a prophet . ''	end

1	Amen .	end

1	But only some of the people of Israel are really God 's people .	end
1	And only some of Abraham 's descendants are true children of Abraham .	end

1	Rebecca also had sons , and they had the same father .	end
1	He is our father Isaac .	end
1	But before the two sons were born , God told Rebecca , `` The older son will serve the younger . ''	end

1	He was chosen because he was the one God wanted to call , not because of anything the boys did .	end
1	As the Scriptures say , `` I loved Jacob , but I hated Esau . ''	end
1	So what does this mean ?	end
1	That God is not fair ?	end
1	We can not say that .	end
1	God said to Moses , `` I will show mercy to anyone I want to show mercy to .	end
1	I will show pity to anyone I choose . ''	end
1	So God will choose anyone he decides to show mercy to , and his choice does not depend on what people want or try to do .	end
1	In the Scriptures God says to Pharaoh : `` I made you king so that you could do this for me .	end
1	I wanted to show my power through you .	end
1	I wanted my name to be announced throughout the world . ''	end
1	So God shows mercy to those he wants to show mercy to and makes stubborn those he wants to make stubborn .	end
1	So one of you will ask me , `` If God controls what we do , why does he blame us for our sins ? ''	end
1	Do n't ask that .	end
1	You are only human and have no right to question God .	end
1	A clay jar does not question the one who made it .	end
1	It does not say , `` Why did you make me like this ? ''	end
1	The one who makes the jar can make anything he wants .	end
1	He uses the same clay to make different things .	end
1	He might make one thing for special purposes and another for daily use .	end
1	It is the same way with what God has done .	end
1	He wanted to show his anger and to let people see his power .	end
1	But he patiently endured those he was angry with -- people who were ready to be destroyed .	end
1	He waited with patience so that he could make known the riches of his glory to the people he has chosen to receive his mercy .	end
1	God has already prepared them to share his glory .	end
1	We are those people , the ones God chose not only from the Jews but also from those who are not Jews .	end
1	As the Scriptures say in the book of Hosea , `` The people who are not mine -- I will say they are my people .	end
1	And the people I did not love -- I will say they are the people I love . ''	end
1	And , `` Where God said in the past , ' You are not my people ' -- there they will be called children of the living God . ''	end
1	And Isaiah cries out about Israel : `` There are so many people of Israel , they are like the grains of sand by the sea .	end
1	But only a few of them will be saved .	end
1	Yes , the Lord will quickly finish judging the people on the earth . ''	end
1	It is just as Isaiah said : `` The Lord All - Powerful allowed some of our people to live .	end
1	If he had not done that , we would now be like Sodom , and we would be like Gomorrah . ''	end
1	So what does all this mean ?	end
1	It means that people who are not Jews were made right with God because of their faith , even though they were not trying to make themselves right .	end
1	And the people of Israel , who tried to make themselves right with God by following the law , did not succeed .	end
1	They failed because they tried to make themselves right by the things they did .	end
1	They did not trust in God to make them right .	end
1	They fell over the stone that makes people fall .	end
1	The Scriptures talk about that stone : `` Look , I put in Zion a stone that will make people stumble .	end
1	It is a rock that will make people fall .	end
1	But anyone who trusts in him will never be disappointed . ''	end
1	The Remaking of Linpien	Linpien ! country ;
1	Home of the Black Pearl Wax Apple	end
1	-LRB- Teng Sue - feng / photos by Jimmy Lin / tr. by Christopher MacDonald -RRB-	Teng Sue - feng ! person ; Jimmy Lin ! person ; Christopher MacDonald ! person ;
1	Even if the township of Linpien does n't have a monopoly on the cultivation of " black pearl " wax apples , it was orchards in the Linpien locality that earned black pearls their national renown .	Linpien ! country ; Linpien ! country ;
1	A little town formerly notorious for its ground subsidence problem , Linpien is now turning itself into one of Southern Taiwan 's premier tourist attractions .	Linpien ! country ; one ! num ; Southern Taiwan 's ! location ;
1	The impetus for this change has come chiefly from local historians , along with various voluntary groups .	end
1	Just before Christmas break , the rural township of Linpien , on the Pingtung Plain at the mouth of the Linpien river , held its first ever Wax Apple Festival .	Christmas ! thing ; Linpien ! country ; the Pingtung Plain ! location ; Linpien ! country ; first ! order ; Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
1	The festival , in the town 's riverside park , was held to promote black pearl wax apples and celebrate the local volunteer spirit .	end
1	It was a scorching hot day , and heavily perspiring visitors were to be seen wandering among the stalls , lugging bags of wax apples and commenting on their remarkable sweetness .	end
1	" There 's a lot more than you 'd think to growing wax apples , " says local farmer Chen Sheng - tzung .	Chen Sheng - tzung ! person ;
1	" How you take care of the orchards , which equipment you use - it all has an affect on the shape and texture of the fruit . "	end
1	Prices for wax apples range widely , from around 3 pounds for NT$ 100 to NT$ 150 a pound .	3 pounds ! measure ; NT$ 100 ! money ; NT$ 150 ! money ;
1	Fruit that shows a hint of black through the red color of the skin fetches the best price .	end
1	Huang Wan - fu , whose family farms two hectares of orchard with more than 700 wax apple trees , and who has over 30 years ' experience as a fruit grower , says that while other parts of Pingtung County also grow wax apples , " Linpien stands out for its growing techniques , developed through trial and error by the growers themselves , and for vernalization rates of up to 90 % . "	Huang Wan - fu ! person ; two hectares ! measure ; more than 700 ! num ; 30 years ! date ; Pingtung County ! country ; Linpien ! country ; 90 % ! per ;
1	Ugly duckling no more	end
1	The wax apple is a tropical fruit originating from the Malay peninsula .	Malay ! national ;
1	The Dutch brought it to Taiwan from Java , in the 17th century , and it became commonly grown as a shade - giving tree .	Dutch ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; Java ! country ; the 17th century ! date ;
1	Old folk in the South remember when wax apples were " just something to munch on " - the kind of fruit that grew freely and that you could help yourself to .	South ! location ;
1	But wax apples have increased in value during the past 30 years , thanks to advances in the way that they are grown .	the past 30 years ! date ;
1	For example , the " bag - wrap " method was originally a way of protecting budding fruit from birds , but once it was introduced to Linpien , in around 1994 , farmers found it enabled them to grow more lustrous , shiny - looking wax apples , with less pesticide on the skin .	Linpien ! country ; 1994 ! date ;
1	The method soon caught on throughout the district .	end
1	Another popular technique involves covering the trees with black mosquito nets to improve yields .	end
1	This reduces the amount of sunlight reaching the trees , causing nutrients from the leaves and branches to be diverted into producing fruit .	end
1	The net - covered trees blossom earlier and produce more fruit .	end
1	As a result of this technique , black pearl wax apples are now available throughout most of the year .	most of the year ! date ;
1	The " black pearl " tag did n't originate in Linpien , but it was Linpien wax apples that made the variety famous and prompted the dramatic growth of its market .	Linpien ! country ; Linpien ! country ;
1	In 1983 the then - provincial governor Lee Teng - hui visited the town and praised the quality of its black pearl wax apples , so assuring the renown of the fruit .	1983 ! date ; Lee Teng - hui ! person ;
1	Subsequently , as president , Lee Teng - hui often gave gifts of black pearl wax apples to foreign dignitaries .	Lee Teng - hui ! person ;
1	Green hills	end
1	The success of black pearl wax apples gave Linpien a much - needed boost , bringing some of the younger generation back to the area to grow the fruit .	Linpien ! country ;
1	The credit for putting wax apples at the heart of the town 's revival and for mounting the Wax Apple Festival belongs with a group of volunteer workers - local people committed to the town 's regeneration .	the Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
1	How does a small town like Linpien come to be home to such a well - organized volunteer effort , and just how did the volunteers set about giving their town a make - over ?	Linpien ! country ;
1	The story begins with the town 's riverside park .	end
1	The road linking the town 's main street with the riverside park , where locals like to stroll and chat at the beginning and end of the day , used to be overgrown and lined with trash .	end
1	Now , however , thanks to a coordinated effort involving volunteers , residents and landlords , the verges are planted with sunflowers and lantana , while a former mud patch , donated rent - free by its owner , has been converted into a carp - filled lotus pool .	end
1	The revamping of Linpien started eight or nine years ago , when schoolteacher Tsao Chi - hung - now a DPP deputy in the national legislature - along with fellow members of the Linpien Residents ' Democracy Association launched a program to sweep the streets and keep the riverbank clean .	Linpien ! country ; eight or nine years ago ! date ; Tsao Chi - hung ! person ; DPP ! org ; the Linpien Residents ' Democracy Association ! org ;
1	Wu Wu - ta , a plumber who runs the Democracy Association , says : " People were already doing their bit for the community over ten years ago , but not openly .	Wu Wu - ta ! person ; the Democracy Association ! org ; ten years ago ! date ;
1	They swept the streets before dawn because they did n't want people to see them and call them crazy . "	end
1	It was only three years ago , with the founding of the non-political Linpien Natural History Conservation Association , that residents began to publicly support the project .	three years ago ! date ; Linpien Natural History Conservation Association ! org ;
1	The flood - prone Linpien River has been dyked and dredged since the Japanese colonial era , but the bare concrete embankments never did much for the scenery .	Linpien River ! location ; Japanese ! national ;
1	In 1999 Tsao Chi - hung learned that the Water Conservancy Bureau was planning to renovate the flood defenses , and he proposed a scheme for " greenification " of the riverside area .	1999 Tsao Chi - hung ! date ; the Water Conservancy Bureau ! person ;
1	Objections were raised , however , with some pointing out that the site , if left untended , could easily get overgrown and become a breeding ground for snakes and vermin .	end
1	The issue was discussed and finally the Bureau agreed to let volunteers maintain the riverside area for two years .	Bureau ! org ; two years ! date ;
1	If the scheme did n't work out then the Bureau would concrete over the site as originally planned .	Bureau ! org ;
1	Following the lead of the conservation association and the Democracy Association , various volunteer groups in the district - including the senior citizens ' club , members of Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation , the Presbyterian Church , and followers of the I - Kuan Tao sect - signed up to share responsibility for the riverside park , which was divided into 90 - meter - long plots for the purpose .	the Democracy Association ! org ; Tzu Chi Buddhist Foundation ! org ; the Presbyterian Church ! org ; I - Kuan Tao ! org ; 90 - meter ! measure ;
1	Turf was laid , flower beds appeared , and the embankment soon became a 1.2 km - long " green Great Wall . "	1.2 km ! measure ; Great Wall ! fact ;
1	Dreaming by the river	end
1	" You ca n't go about community work in a standoffish way , and you certainly ca n't operate effectively from behind the scenes - you have to be out there at the front of things .	end
1	When local people see teachers and doctors coming out to collect trash , they feel encouraged to join in , " says Chen Chin - chao , a dentist who chairs the Linpien Natural History Conservation Association .	Chen Chin - chao ! person ; the Linpien Natural History Conservation Association ! org ;
1	Chen frets about the way the media has focused the spotlight on him alone , when numerous other individuals are also involved , all chipping in what they can .	Chen ! person ;
1	" The biggest achievement is that the flowers have n't been stolen , " says Tsao Chi - hung .	Tsao Chi - hung ! person ;
1	" As more people volunteer to help , disruptive behavior becomes less and less likely . "	end
1	The riverside area used to be a teenage hangout , known for its drinking and fighting , but since greenification the town 's residents have been coming here to stroll and enjoy the scenery : green hills to the East , the sunset in the West , and the dreamy river alongside the park .	East ! location ; West ! location ;
1	" The more that people get involved the greater their sense of accomplishment , " says Tsao .	Tsao ! person ;
1	" It 's not just about tidying up the environment .	end
1	We also hope to foster the commercial interests of the community so as to bring practical benefits for people 's lives . "	end
1	This was the thinking behind Tsao 's gathering together of various groups for the Wax Apple Festival .	Tsao ! person ; the Wax Apple Festival ! thing ;
1	According to the archives , 400 years ago Linpien was a plains - aborigine settlement called " Fang - suo - she . "	400 years ago Linpien ! date ; Fang - suo - she ! country ;
1	In the middle of the 17th century the Ming dynasty loyalist Zheng Chenggong -LRB- also known as Koxinga -RRB- brought an influx of settlers to Taiwan from the Fujian and Guangdong regions of China .	the middle of the 17th century ! date ; Ming dynasty ! date ; Zheng Chenggong ! person ; Koxinga ! person ; Taiwan ! country ; Fujian ! country ; Guangdong ! country ; China ! country ;
1	Some of the Fang - suo - she aborigines stayed and intermarried with Chinese , while others moved away .	Fang - suo - she ! person ; Chinese ! national ;
1	The oldest recorded use of the name " Linpien " is on a stele , erected in 1762 , next to the town 's Sanshan King Temple .	Linpien ! country ; 1762 ! date ; Sanshan King Temple ! fact ;
1	The name , which means " beside the forest , " indicates that the early settlers must have had a tough time clearing land for their crops .	end
1	Moving to center - stage	end
1	In the past half century or more Linpien has concentrated on a series of different forms of produce , from rice , to bananas , to prawn and eel farming , to wax apples - today 's main crop .	the past half century ! date ; Linpien ! country ;
1	With Taiwan 's imminent accession to the WTO , the next big change could be just around the corner .	Taiwan ! country ; WTO ! org ;
1	For example , will wax apples lose their market to imported fruit ?	end
1	And what does Linpien have to offer that other districts in the county ca n't easily duplicate ?	Linpien ! country ;
1	Yang Hung - jen , a PhD student at National Taiwan University 's Graduate Institute of Sociology , came to Linpien a year ago to research his thesis on the renewal of the local community .	Yang Hung - jen ! person ; PhD ! art ; National Taiwan University 's Graduate Institute of Sociology ! org ; Linpien a year ago ! org ;
1	" I had come to what was said to be the worst county in Taiwan for factionalism and corruption , " says Yang , " a place where the ground had sunk as much as three meters due to subsidence .	Taiwan ! country ; Yang ! person ; three meters ! measure ;
1	But the contrast between that image and what I actually found here was quite something . "	end
1	For Yang , the way that those most active in the renewal effort routinely pass the credit to others is itself impressive .	Yang ! person ;
1	Linpien rose to prominence on the strength of its celebrated wax apples .	Linpien ! country ;
1	But can it now push its way to center - stage as a tourist attraction ?	end
1	Says Chen Chin - chao : " We ca n't yet say how things will turn out for Linpien .	Chen Chin - chao ! person ; Linpien ! country ;
1	But that 's not to be pessimistic about the town 's prospects ; it 's simply a case of not building castles in the air . "	end
1	Development of the long - promised Tapeng Bay Scenic Area is due to begin , and in 2003 the 2nd Southern Freeway will open .	Tapeng Bay Scenic Area ! location ; 2003 the 2nd Southern Freeway ! date ;
1	Will this bring more prosperity to the area ?	end
1	Construction of a bypass around the town has already boosted property values , but what other benefits may it bring ?	end
1	A golf course is mooted , but will that mean the loss of birdwatching zones and the mangrove woods ?	end
1	Can the wax apple orchards be adapted to serve as a setting for family outings ?	end
1	And can fish farms in the locality be converted to provide housing and accommodation , and a recreation alternative for visitors ?	end
1	Can this little town make an asset of its scenic location and historical roots to attract more visitors ?	end
1	Linpien used to be little more than a brief stop for travelers on their way to the seaside resort of Kenting , but now its residents are wondering if they can turn the town into a destination in its own right .	Linpien ! country ; Kenting ! country ;
1	Linpien Facts and Figures	Linpien ! country ;
1	Linpien Rural Township is in Pingtung County , located on the Pingtung Plain at the mouth of the Linpien River .	Linpien Rural Township ! country ; Pingtung County ! country ; the Pingtung Plain ! location ; the Linpien River ! location ;
1	It is adjacent to the planned Tapeng Bay Scenic Area , and marks the point where the 2nd Southern Freeway will terminate .	Tapeng Bay Scenic Area ! location ; the 2nd Southern Freeway ! fact ;
1	At 15.6 sq. km in area , it is the second smallest of Pingtung County 's 33 townships , and has a population of around 23,000 .	15.6 sq. km ! measure ; second ! order ; Pingtung County 's 33 ! country ; 23,000 ! num ;
1	Wax apples and aquaculture products are the main commodities , with betel nut and coconut also grown .	end
1	One - third of the township 's land is below sea level .	One - third ! num ;
1	Visitors are recommended to try the local seafood and also not to miss the opportunity for bird - watching among the nearby estuaries , wetlands and mangrove woods .	end
1	There are also cultural relics including traces of the original plains - aborigine inhabitants .	end
1	Linpien can be reached along Provincial Highway 17 .	Linpien ! country ; Provincial Highway 17 ! fact ;
1	The town has a railway station and can also be accessed by public and private bus services .	end
1	For more information check out : www.taconet.com.tw/cstudio/	end
1	p. 45	45 ! num ;
1	Using special growing techniques , the farmers of Linpien control the quantity of blossoms on the trees so as to optimize the production of their treasured black pearl wax apples .	Linpien ! country ;
1	p. 46	46 ! num ;
1	Aquaculture provides for full nets and full bellies , but it is also the culprit behind Linpien 's severe subsidence problem .	Linpien ! country ;
1	The acreage of fish farms has halved in recent years , due to the combination of falling profits and environmental degradation .	recent years ! date ;
1	p. 47	47 ! num ;
1	Subsidence has been caused by the over-extraction of ground - water for aquaculture .	end
1	Some of the houses on the Linpien - Chiatung coastal strip have sunk to the degree that their windows are level with the street and their rooves are within easy reach .	Linpien ! country ; Chiatung ! country ;
1	p. 48	48 ! num ;
1	The gardens of the riverside park , laid out and maintained by local volunteers , cover land that used to be overgrown and strewn with rubbish .	end
1	The people of the town now come here to stroll and enjoy their free time .	end
1	p. 48	48 ! num ;
1	The river is blessed with fine scenery , and is good for fishing and birdwatching .	end
1	Linpien residents see this as an important asset for attracting tourism .	Linpien ! country ;
1	Tips for Getting through Middle Age	end
1	-LRB- Laura Li / photos by Hsueh Chi - kuang / tr. by Jonathan Barnard -RRB-	Laura Li ! person ; Hsueh Chi - kuang ! person ; Jonathan Barnard ! person ;
1	Middle age and the changes it brings are like a revolving door .	end
1	Many people peacefully go through it , growing wiser and losing their rough edges .	end
1	A minority do n't know whether to advance or retreat and get caught in it like a trap .	end
1	Middle age is a time where one wears more hats than at any other time in one 's life , when one 's responsibilities are heaviest .	end
1	As a result , the crises experienced by a minority of middle - aged people can involve a lot of other people , so their impact can not be overlooked .	end
1	Middle age , those years between 40 and 60 , is both the time of life of greatest glory and the time of life that 's easiest to overlook .	those years between 40 and 60 ! date ;
1	In comparison to youth or old age , the middle years are often thought of as the time when power , ability , wealth , and physical strength are all at or near their peak , so that one has no excuse for feeling melancholy .	end
1	Even if there are problems , it is commonly thought that one should be able to resolve them by oneself , notes Chiu Chia - li , director of the Hwo Chyuan Pastoral Counseling Center , who has worked on many middle - aged cases .	Chiu Chia - li ! person ; the Hwo Chyuan Pastoral Counseling Center ! org ;
1	Social bias makes many of the middle aged afraid to discuss their problems .	end
1	This is particularly the case for men , who generally find it difficult to talk about their feelings .	end
1	But by keeping everything inside , they may cause irreparable harm to their health .	end
1	In recent years cancer , sudden death and suicide have become all too common during middle age , which shows that the psychological problems of the middle - aged should not be overlooked .	end
1	How do you safely pass through the changes of the middle years ?	end
1	Here are a few suggestions :	end
1	1. Live well at every stage of life	1. ! num ;
1	Li Liang - che , a professor of psychology at National Chengchi University , looks at the question from the angle of developmental psychology .	Li Liang - che ! person ; National Chengchi University ! org ;
1	He points out that the path of life is continuous : everyone moves from infancy and childhood , to youth and middle age .	end
1	Smoothly passing through any period of life helps make getting through the next period easier .	end
1	In other words , the people most at risk during middle age are those who have had difficulties earlier in life .	end
1	Foreign research shows that those with high social and economic status and with ample financial resources bear up better during crisis and have more ways to get out of trouble .	end
1	Is it too late to start talking about these problems when you are already middle - aged ?	end
1	Chang Der - chung , an associate professor in the Department of Living Science at National Open University who worked at a counseling hotline for over a decade , argues that any step in the right direction is worthwhile , no matter when you start .	Chang Der - chung ! person ; Department of Living Science at National Open University ! org ; over a decade ! date ;
1	Middle - aged problems are rather predictable , and they 're not hard to avoid .	end
1	Are you worried that your marriage is growing stale ?	end
1	Then no matter how busy you are , you 've got to set aside some time to be with your spouse .	end
1	Are you worried about losing your job ?	end
1	Then start developing a second skill and get into the habit of saving and managing your money .	second ! order ;
1	Are you worried about how to care for your parents when they get old and sick ?	end
1	Then spend more time with them , and encourage them to get more exercise and take care of themselves .	end
1	There are so many things to be concerned about during middle age that you had better get an early start .	end
1	Otherwise , you 'll end up being overwhelmed .	end
1	2. Start over	2. ! num ;
1	In China it used to be said that middle age was the period when one was " heir to the ancient sages and the teacher of posterity . "	China ! country ;
1	But now times are changing so fast that perhaps the lessons of past experience are no longer suitable for solving today 's problems .	end
1	To assume a posture of superiority based on one 's seniority will make one despised .	end
1	Hence , it is necessary to cast aside one 's old self and start over .	end
1	Chiu notes that many middle - aged who have worked diligently for years to attain management positions look down on the younger generation for being reckless and disorganized , but they do n't realize that creativity and energy may be ready to explode from underneath these flaws .	Chiu ! person ;
1	Stuck in the past and full of bitterness , they may end up getting discarded onto the scrap heap of history .	end
1	With each new era , role models change .	end
1	Until the new role models have been established , it is important to maintain flexibility .	end
1	For instance , today 's middle - aged Chinese women are the first to have obtained advanced degrees and to have come in contact with the women 's liberation movement .	Chinese ! national ;
1	They set high expectations for themselves , but their disappointments are likewise large .	end
1	Many women are torn between conflicting desires : to be good homemakers like their mothers and to have successful careers like their fathers .	end
1	Their candles are burning at both ends , because they are trying to live up to two old role models rather than establishing a new one for themselves .	two ! num ;
1	Then there are men who insist upon being strict fathers and disciplinarians or staying at the same company until they retire .	end
1	And there are women who are determined to play the role of the traditional Chinese wife and mother .	Chinese ! national ;
1	Ignoring the changing times , they place tremendous pressure on themselves .	end
1	3. Turn the focus from outside to inside	3. ! num ;
1	Life is a process that moves from the " outward " to the " inward , " says Alice Lu , director of the International Family Life Education Center , getting to the heart of the matter .	Alice Lu ! person ; the International Family Life Education Center ! org ;
1	Lu explains that as children people yearn for the affection of their parents ; as adolescents they want the affirmation of their peers ; and as adults , they set their sights on educational qualifications , finding a good job , making money , marrying a good spouse and so forth .	Lu ! person ;
1	Everyone puts the emphasis on outward manifestations of success , and this emphasis on the glitter of outward achievement continues up to middle age .	end
1	" By middle age , people have gotten from the outside world just about all they can , " says Lu .	Lu ! person ;
1	" What they have n't attained yet they probably wo n't attain ever , so it 's not worth getting all worked up about it .	end
1	This is the time of life when the doubts set in . "	end
1	Many middle - aged people begin to ask themselves , " Is this really what I want ?	end
1	What has been the point of all my hard striving ? "	end
1	When the doubts come , some people continue trying to find answers from outside , thinking that everything would be fine if they could just change jobs or wives !	end
1	But then they rashly switch jobs or foolishly get involved in an affair only to find that they 've just made things worse .	end
1	" In middle age you start to listen to what 's going on inside , " says Lu .	Lu ! person ;
1	" It 's the time of life when you start to hone your skills at conversing with your soul . "	end
1	People ask themselves : Am I truly happy ?	end
1	Do I like the person I see in the mirror ?	end
1	Why ?	end
1	What dreams can I pursue ?	end
1	At this point , there is no longer any need to try to measure oneself against outside standards .	end
1	Instead it 's more important to accept oneself and attempt to find an inner balance .	end
1	" One need not compare one 's inner achievements with those of other people , " notes Chiu .	Chiu ! person ;
1	Everyone 's circumstances and personalities are different , and they place different expectations on themselves .	end
1	It 's not a matter of being better or worse than anyone else , and there 's no need to follow the currents of fashion .	end
1	Everyone is unique .	end
1	Morris Chang was in his fifties when he became an entrepreneur and founded Taiwan Semiconductor .	Morris Chang ! person ; Taiwan Semiconductor ! org ;
1	Many others at the same time in life have opted to take early retirement and find a guru in India , work as a volunteer , or do whatever else they want to do .	India ! country ;
1	In the modern age when people value different things , you can find a purely personal kind of happiness and success .	end
1	4. Realistically strive for one 's dreams	4. ! num ;
1	When focusing inward , many dreams that have long been discarded will end up floating to the surface .	end
1	At such times , one should remember to ask oneself three questions :	three ! num ;
1	" What do I want ? " " What can I do ? " And " What must I do and have ? "	end
1	Chang Der - chung reminds people to think clearly about their needs , and then think about the costs .	Chang Der - chung ! person ;
1	Will meeting these personal needs necessarily come into conflict with meeting one 's responsibilities ?	end
1	Is there some way that the two can be accomplished simultaneously ?	end
1	When facing problems at work in Taiwan , many people decide to change careers or even to pursue their fortunes in mainland China or Southeast Asia .	Taiwan ! country ; China ! country ; Southeast Asia ! location ;
1	Pursuing some dream of really making it big , many men use up their savings , leaving their wives as the sole source of family support and suffering loneliness in a foreign land .	end
1	There 's no right or wrong here , and there 's no way to guarantee a venture will be successful , but beforehand one must at least be realistic and prepare oneself psychologically for all possible outcomes , so that one wo n't suffer losses larger than one can bear .	end
1	" It is indeed the case that when one is young , one 's quiver is full of arrows and opportunities abound , so that one can shoot at will , " says Chang by way of analogy .	Chang ! person ;
1	" Once you get into middle age , you 've got to make every arrow count . "	end
1	Chang explains that everyone has dreams , and that continually working toward those dreams is an excellent method of relieving stress at any age .	Chang ! person ;
1	Middle - aged people have heavy burdens , and sometimes they may feel as if they are suffocating under them .	end
1	" But accomplishing a lot of little changes can bring about a big change . "	end
1	If you make an effort to do what you can , you will immediately find that your burdens have been lightened .	end
1	Chang cites this example : Say you hate being tied up by your work , and would like to go back to school .	Chang ! person ;
1	Why do n't you try a weekend class ?	end
1	Maybe that would help to alleviate your anxiety .	end
1	Or if you are a housewife , taking care of three generations and resentful that you ca n't go out and get the sense of accomplishment that comes with a full - time job , then maybe you could work as a volunteer in a community organization .	three ! num ;
1	This would both put you into contact with other people and help you gain a sense of accomplishment .	end
1	And you can help to sweat off your middle - aged anxieties by making a habit of regularly exercising .	end
1	What 's more , do n't worry too much about time being short .	end
1	Remember that most modern people live long lives that can be divided up into many stages .	end
1	In middle age , when you discover that your personal desires are coming into conflict with the demands of your family or society , decide which of your problems are the most urgent .	end
1	Do n't try to accomplish all of your dreams at once .	end
1	Maintain an unhurried frame of mind and peacefully wait for opportunities to present themselves .	end
1	5. Change your perspective	5. ! num ;
1	In middle age , one 's life is already half over , and one has already amply tasted of life 's fruits , both the bitter and the sweet .	end
1	" I am thankful for the bad times , for they have given me more insight into life and a better opportunity to understand myself , " says Lin Hung - kuei , an I - kuan Tao devotee , who has studied the Book of Changes and fengshui .	Lin Hung - kuei ! person ; the Book of Changes ! art ;
1	Taking care of your parents , losing your job , illness and even being cheated out of money can be embraced as opportunities to experience life .	end
1	They are lessons that the middle - aged learn from to become more proficient at the art of living .	end
1	" By changing perspective , you can understand the insignificance of your problems , " points out Chiu Chia - li .	Chiu Chia - li ! person ;
1	It is very important to adjust your frame of mind .	end

1	Turning to the Constitution on the " One China " Issue	One China ! num ;
1	Still wrestling with the vexed issue of " one China , " the President 's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations met for its sixth and seventh sessions during November , amid frenzied media attention .	one China ! num ; the President 's Advisory Group ! country ; Cross-Strait ! org ; sixth ! location ; seventh ! order ; November ! order ;
1	The group eventually reached a consensus that the " one China " principle advocated by the mainland should be addressed " in accordance with the constitution . "	one China ! num ;
1	How president Chen Shui - bian responds to this proposal will determine whether or not the " one China " stalemate can be broken , and if there is to be a set timetable for implementing the three direct links .	Chen Shui - bian ! person ; one China ! num ; three ! country ;
1	After assuming the presidency , Chen Shui - bian recruited a number of leading politicians , industrialists , academics and other personages for a non-partisan advisory group , intended to build cross-party consensus on the subject of relations with the mainland .	Chen Shui - bian ! person ;
1	Chaired by Academia Sinica president Lee Yuan - tseh , the Presidential Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations first met in early September .	Academia Sinica ! org ; Lee Yuan - tseh ! person ; the Presidential Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations first ! org ; early September ! order ;
1	Since then the Group has held a series of intensive discussions on Taiwan 's fundamental position regarding the cross-strait relationship .	Group ! org ; Taiwan ! country ;
1	The Group entered the final phase of discussions on the " one China " issue during November , but differences between pro-unification and pro-independence participants continued to stymie the effort to produce a statement acceptable to all .	Group ! org ; one China ! num ; November ! country ;
1	As DPP legislator Shen Fu - hsiung pointed out , the Group had to draft something " palatable both to the pro-unification and pro-independence camps ; something which the DPP ca n't shun and yet which does n't make Beijing wince . "	DPP ! org ; Shen Fu - hsiung ! person ; Group ! org ; DPP ! org ; Beijing ! country ;
1	Clearly no easy task .	end
1	On the evening of November 18 Advisory Group chairman Lee Yuan - tseh , meeting over dinner with DPP faction leaders , described the cross-strait situation as extremely precarious , and said that since time is not on Taiwan 's side we need to step up efforts to resume dialogue with the mainland .	the evening of November 18 Advisory Group ! time ; Lee Yuan - tseh ! org ; DPP ! person ; Taiwan ! org ;

1	In 1988 , the last train on the old Tanshui Line of the railroad chugged into history , taking that old slower pace of life with it .	1988 ! date ; Tanshui Line ! fact ;
1	In 1997 the Tanshui Line of the mass rapid transit system opened , bringing floods of visitors to the town .	1997 the Tanshui Line ! date ;
1	Yet , while these tourists bring a human touch to the streets on weekends and holidays , on ordinary weekdays the silence is accompanied only by leftover garbage , empty shops , and those Huwei people who refuse to leave their old homes .	Huwei ! country ;
1	The golden age of Huwei	Huwei ! country ;
1	There are different explanations as to the origins of the word Huwei , the original name for Tanshui .	Huwei ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
1	Some say it was a transliteration of the place name used by the indigenous people .	end
1	But others say it comes from a long - gone fishing practice , using a shi hu -LRB- " stone pool " -RRB- .	end
1	Early fishermen used stones to carve a long , narrow catchment -LRB- the so - called " pool " -RRB- in the sand , waiting for the tide to carry in fish which they could then easily scoop up .	end
1	Since the place now known as Tanshui was at the tail end -LRB- wei -RRB- of this stone pool , it came to be called Huwei .	Tanshui ! country ; Huwei ! country ;
1	Tanshui occupied an important place in the transport network connecting Taiwan to Southeast Asia .	Tanshui ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Southeast Asia ! location ;
1	Even before the arrival of Westerners in Taiwan , Han Chinese often crossed over from China to Tanshui , which is relatively close to the mainland .	Westerners ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; Han Chinese ! national ; China ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
1	Here they engaged in barter trade with the Pingpu -LRB- meaning " plains " -RRB- aborigines , with deer skins and sulphur being the most coveted products .	Pingpu ! national ;
1	As Western powers turned their eyes to Asia , Tanshui became strategically important .	Western ! national ; Asia ! location ; Tanshui ! country ;
1	In the 17th century , first the Spanish , and then the Dutch , built forts here as symbols of their claims to territorial control .	the 17th century ! date ; Spanish ! national ; Dutch ! national ;
1	In the mid-17th century , China took control of Taiwan , and closed Tanshui to international trade .	the mid-17th century ! date ; China ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
1	Later , as a result of the Sino - French war of 1884 , Tanshui was again opened up to Western access .	Sino - French ! national ; 1884 ! date ; Tanshui ! country ; Western ! national ;
1	During Tanshui 's golden age , large and small boats were constantly coming and going in the harbor , and it was not unusual to see enormous steamships .	Tanshui ! country ;
1	In the latter part of the Qing dynasty , Tanshui was the largest port in Taiwan , and was the " customs headquarters , " also charged with overseeing port activities at Keelung , Tainan , and Kaohsiung .	the latter part of the Qing dynasty ! date ; Tanshui ! country ; Taiwan ! country ; Keelung ! country ; Tainan ! country ; Kaohsiung ! country ;
1	However , during the Japanese occupation , as a result of silting , and because the Japanese invested a huge effort in developing the port at Keelung , Tanshui faded in importance , never again to see the likes of its glory days .	Japanese ! national ; Japanese ! national ; Keelung ! country ; Tanshui ! country ;
1	Tanshui is a place of many historic sites , a place that invites reflection on things past .	Tanshui ! country ;
1	In the " foreign district , " a missionary named George Mackay established the first hospital for Western medicine in Taiwan ; it was here that in 1878 the first case of paragonimiasis in the world was diagnosed .	George Mackay ! person ; first ! order ; Western ! national ; Taiwan ! country ; 1878 ! date ; first ! order ;
1	The old church next to the hospital is a mecca for Tanshui painters .	Tanshui ! country ;
1	The schools , homes , and consulates in the foreign district - some long gone , some still standing - testify to the fact that this was a place of intensive interaction between Chinese and Western cultures .	Chinese ! national ; Western ! national ;
1	If you go up Sanmin Street , you will discover the head of an old and disused water pipe .	Sanmin Street ! location ;
1	This could be a relic left behind by one of the major Japanese infrastructure projects , the first tap water station .	Japanese ! national ; first ! order ;
1	Or you could walk instead next to the MRT station and see another first for Taiwan : the first seaplane landing area , also built in the Japanese occupation era .	the MRT station ! fact ; first ! order ; Taiwan ! country ; first ! order ; Japanese ! national ;

1	Tanshui Facts and Figures	Tanshui ! country ;
1	Tanshui Township -LRB- also spelled Tamsui -RRB- is part of Taipei County .	Tanshui Township ! country ; Tamsui ! country ; Taipei County ! country ;
1	It abuts Sanchih Rural Township to the northeast , the Kuantu area of Taipei City to the southeast , and the Taiwan Strait to the northwest ; to the southwest it faces Pali Rural Township over the Tanshui River .	Sanchih Rural Township ! country ; Kuantu ! location ; Taipei City ! country ; the Taiwan Strait ! location ; Pali Rural Township ! country ; the Tanshui River ! location ;
1	It covers an area of just over 70 square kilometers , and has a population of 115,000 .	over 70 square kilometers ! measure ; 115,000 ! num ;
1	It is the largest paddy - rice producing area in Taipei County .	Taipei County ! country ;
1	In days gone by , because the Kuroshio current passes close by , the waters offshore were rich fishing grounds .	Kuroshio ! location ;
1	However , in recent years , pollution from the Tanshui River and exhaustion of fish stocks have caused the catch to dwindle .	recent years ! date ; the Tanshui River ! location ;
1	Among the more famous tourist sites are Fort San Domingo , Yin Shan Temple , the Lixuetang school -LRB- known in English as Oxford College , founded in 1882 to train missionaries -RRB- , Huwei cannon emplacement , the mangrove conservation area , Shalun beach recreation area , the historic buildings of the Mackay Hospital and Tamkang Middle School , " Antiques Street " -LRB- Chungcheng Road -RRB- , and the ferry pier .	Fort San Domingo ! fact ; Yin Shan Temple ! fact ; the Lixuetang school ! org ; English ! language ; Oxford College ! org ; 1882 ! date ; Huwei ! country ; Shalun ! location ; the Mackay Hospital ! fact ; Tamkang Middle School ! fact ; Antiques Street ! location ; Chungcheng Road ! location ;
1	Public transportation includes inter-city bus service , the Tanshui Line of the Taipei mass rapid transit system , and local buses .	the Tanshui Line ! fact ; Taipei ! country ;
1	For more detailed information visit http://www.tamsui.gov.tw/ .	end
