1	Powerful Tools for Biotechnology - Biochips	Powerful Tools for Biotechnology - Biochips ! art ;
1	-LRB- Chang Chiung - fang / photos by Hsueh Chi - kuang / tr. by Robert Taylor -RRB-	Chang Chiung - fang ! person ; Hsueh Chi - kuang ! person ; Robert Taylor ! person ;
1	The enterovirus detection biochip developed by DR. Chip Biotechnology takes only six hours to give hospitals the answer to whether a sample contains enterovirus , and if it is the deadly strain Entero 71 .	DR. Chip Biotechnology ! org ; only six hours ! time ;
1	Worldwide , biotechnology is a rising star of the industrial stage .	end
1	In Taiwan , in recent years the Ministry of Economic Affairs , the National Science Council and the National Health Research Institutes have been strongly pursuing " biochip " research programs .	Taiwan ! country ; the Ministry of Economic Affairs ! org ; the National Science Council ! org ; the National Health Research Institutes ! org ;
1	In the last two years , three biochip companies have also been set up in Taiwan .	the last two years ! date ; three ! num ; Taiwan ! country ;
1	Just what are biochips ?	end
1	What use are they to mankind ?	end
1	Why do so many people have such confidence in their future ?	end
1	What is the current state of this field in Taiwan ?	Taiwan ! country ;
1	And what are the prospects for future development ?	end
1	Let 's take a closer look .	end
1	In just a few years ' time , or a few decades , the following scenario could become a reality :	a few years ' ! date ; a few decades ! date ;
1	When you 're feeling under the weather , all you need to do is buy a diagnostic biochip from the chemist 's shop , put a drop of urine onto it , and you will find out what is wrong with you - a health check will be as easy as a pregnancy test today .	end
1	Everyone will carry with them a biochip bearing a record and analysis of their own DNA .	end
1	From it one will not only be able to see one 's own physical condition , but even to predict what diseases one will have in the future .	end
1	It will be like an ID card , needed when looking for work , buying insurance or even seeking a partner for love and marriage .	end
1	Laboratories will no longer need all kinds of large instruments , for all stages of their experiments will be carried out on little biochips , saving time , effort and money .	end
1	Today , the scenes outlined above may just seem like pipe dreams .	Today ! time ;
1	But these dreams could yet come true , and the key to that happening is those little biochips .	end
1	A dream come true ?	A dream come true ? ! art ;
1	Developments such as the sequencing of the human genome and the rapid development of genetic engineering have spawned biotechnology industries like bioinformatics , biomaterials and pharmaceutical engineering , which have emerged as the rising stars of 21st - century industry .	21st - century ! date ;
1	As part of the government 's efforts to promote the biotechnology industry in Taiwan , in July 1999 the Industrial Technology Research Institute -LRB- ITRI -RRB- set up the Biomedical Engineering Center -LRB- BMEC -RRB- to actively develop biomedical engineering technologies .	Taiwan ! country ; July 1999 the Industrial Technology Research Institute ! date ; ITRI ! org ; the Biomedical Engineering Center ! org ; BMEC ! org ;
1	Biochips are one of the core technologies in the field .	end
1	BMEC general director Dr. Johnsee Lee says that the ITRI 's four - year R&D program in biochip applications and technology is now in its second year .	BMEC ! org ; Johnsee Lee ! person ; ITRI ! org ; four - year ! date ; second year ! date ;
1	Its initial objectives are mainly focused on developing sensor chips to screen for infectious diseases , while later goals will be to develop technologies to test for genetic diseases and cancers .	end
1	As well as this new research establishment , in the two years since September 1998 three commercial companies have been set up in Taiwan to make biochips : U - Vision Biotech , Taiwan Genome Sciences and DR. Chip Biotechnology .	the two years ! date ; September 1998 three ! date ; Taiwan ! num ; U - Vision Biotech ! country ; Taiwan Genome Sciences ! org ; DR. Chip Biotechnology ! org ;
1	Of these , DR. Chip attracted much attention this year when it developed a chip to detect enteroviruses , a deadly epidemic of which has gripped Taiwan over the last two years .	DR. Chip ! org ; this year ! org ; Taiwan ! country ; the last two years ! date ;
1	Fever chips	Fever chips ! art ;
1	DR. Chip Bio-technology was set up in September 1998 .	DR. Chip Bio-technology ! org ; September 1998 ! date ;
1	Vice president Wang Shin - hwan states that the company successfully applied to the Ministry of Economic Affairs for funding to help it pursue a development program for enterovirus detection chips and test technology .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ; the Ministry of Economic Affairs ! org ;
1	Today , the enterovirus chip is in the testing phase , and DR. Chip is collaborating with Taipei Veterans General Hospital to obtain samples with which to establish the accuracy of the chip .	DR. Chip ! org ; Taipei Veterans General Hospital ! org ;
1	What is so remarkable about the enterovirus detection chip when compared with traditional test methods ?	end
1	There are 68 known forms of non-polio enterovirus .	68 ! num ;
1	The detection chip does not simply determine whether a person is infected with enterovirus , but can also differentiate between different virus groups , for instance showing whether a sample contains the deadly Entero 71 virus , or Coxsackie A16 , which is easily confused with Entero 71 .	end
1	In addition , the chip and its accompanying PCR kit greatly reduce the time required for testing .	end
1	Wang Shin - hwan notes that traditional bacterial and viral cultures take seven to ten days to prepare , and even with the newer molecular biology testing techniques it takes three days to get a result .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ; three days ! date ;
1	But DR. Chip has developed methods to reduce the sample preparation time , which enables a result to be obtained in only six hours when used in combination with their enterovirus chip .	DR. Chip ! org ; only six hours ! time ;
1	Furthermore , the initial results of joint trials by DR. Chip , Chang Gung University and National Cheng Kung University suggest that the chip is over a thousand times more sensitive than traditional test methods .	DR. Chip ! org ; Chang Gung University ! org ; National Cheng Kung University ! org ; thousand ! num ;
1	" In addition to enterovirus , we plan to develop chips to detect other infectious diseases such as hepatitis B , hepatitis C and HIV , " says Wang Shin - hwan .	Wang Shin - hwan ! person ;
1	Apart from the enterovirus chip , which is already at the testing stage , the ITRI 's Molecular Biomedical Technology Division is also conducting research and development on biochip applications and technology .	the ITRI 's Molecular Biomedical Technology Division ! org ;
1	Research program director Pan Chao - chi states that at present they are actively developing a " fever chip " with a wide range of applications .	Pan Chao - chi ! person ;
1	Pan explains that in clinical practice , the causes of fever are difficult to quickly diagnose .	end
1	A " fever chip " bearing the DNA of common fever - causing viruses and bacteria could be used to determine the cause of the fever and the type of pathogen involved would be a valuable tool .	end
1	However , Pan points out that because of the difficulties in substantially reducing the time needed for sample preparation , the usefulness of such a fever chip is still limited , so that it can not yet be widely promoted .	Pan ! person ;
1	Where the real money is	end
1	At present , most applications for biochips are in academic research and the development of new pharmaceutical drugs .	end
1	Demand for them is growing rapidly .	end
1	Johnsee Lee says that according to US market research estimates , the worldwide annual consumption of microarray chips is currently around 250,000 ; in two years this is expected to grow to 1.2 million .	Johnsee Lee ! person ; US ! country ; 250,000 ! num ; two years ! date ; 1.2 million ! num ;
1	Based on a market price per chip of US$ 1,000 , the size of the world market in biochips could grow to US$ 1.2 billion in 2003 , and to US$ 40 billion over the next decade .	US$ 1,000 ! money ; US$ 1.2 billion ! money ; 2003 ! date ; US$ 40 billion ! money ; the next decade ! date ;
1	Thus some people have set their sights on the biochip market , and believe that following Taiwan 's success in the semiconductor field , the island could go on to be a major center for contract manufacture of biochips .	Taiwan ! country ;
1	Be that as it may , the small number of biochip companies so far established in Taiwan still find their market in domestic research establishments and pharmaceuticals manufacturers .	Taiwan ! country ;
1	Although they are also actively developing overseas markets , what interests them most is not biochips per se , nor are they content merely to be contract manufacturers .	end
1	" The chips are only a tool , and the big money is not in chip sales .	end
1	What counts is the R&D behind them . "	end
1	Jerry Huang , executive vice president of U - Vision Biotech , reveals that U - Vision , which was set up in September 1999 , has signed a contract with the US company Zen - Bio to jointly develop human adipocyte cDNA microarray chips .	Jerry Huang ! person ; U - Vision Biotech ! org ; U - Vision ! org ; September 1999 ! date ; US ! country ; Zen - Bio ! org ;
1	Huang states that research in recent years has revealed that adipocytes -LRB- fat cells -RRB- are active regulators of the energy balance in the body , and play an important role in disorders such as obesity , diabetes , osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease .	Huang ! person ; recent years ! date ;
1	Thus it is hoped that research into human adipocytes can help in the search for drugs and other therapies to treat these disorders .	end
1	Apart from this , U - Vision is also conducting a one - year bacterial genome project , which aims to map the genome of a certain drug - resistant bacterium as a basis for developing new vaccines and drugs .	U - Vision ! org ; one - year ! date ;
1	Drug development	end
1	Taiwan Genome Sciences -LRB- TGS -RRB- , which was set up in November 1999 as a joint venture by the Uni-President Enterprises Group , Yuen Foong Yu and Tuntex Groups , only entered the biotechnology fray in April of this year .	Taiwan Genome Sciences ! org ; TGS ! org ; November 1999 ! date ; the Uni-President Enterprises Group ! org ; Yuen Foong Yu ! person ; Tuntex Groups ! org ; April of this year ! date ;
1	CEO Andrew Kuo says the investors came to the view that Taiwan needs to develop its biotechnology industries , and therefore they combined their resources to make a long - term investment in the field .	Andrew Kuo ! person ; Taiwan ! country ;
1	TGS 's strategy is to invest in a number of US genome research companies , and to sign technology transfer agreements and chip production contracts with them .	TGS ! org ; US ! country ;
1	Kuo comments that contract production of chips is merely a service activity and a source of income for the company - TGS 's ultimate goal is in doing R&D work to identify gene sequences as targets for developing new drugs .	Kuo ! person ; TGS ! org ;
1	Kuo states that at present , the number of known target sequences for disease - treating drugs is only around 500 , but as the human genome is mapped out this number can be expected to increase tenfold .	Kuo ! person ; 500 ! num ;
1	Currently , TGS has its sights set mainly on doing research into diseases which are especially prevalent in Asia , such as liver and stomach cancers .	TGS ! org ; Asia ! location ;
1	A chip revolution	A chip revolution ! art ;
1	However , the potential uses for biochips go far beyond the medical applications outlined above .	end
1	Dr. Johnsee Lee , who as well as heading up the Biomedical Engineering Center is also general director of Union Chemical Laboratories , a research institute under the ITRI umbrella , says that due to biochips ' advantages of miniaturization , parallelism , speed and the ability to reveal the " big picture , " they have a very wide range of applications .	Johnsee Lee ! person ; the Biomedical Engineering Center ! org ; Union Chemical Laboratories ! org ; ITRI ! org ;
1	They can not only be used as a research tool in biological , medical and pharmaceutical research and development , and as a clinical diagnostic tool for doing health checks , testing for infectious pathogens , screening blood and so on , but they can also find uses in such areas as defense applications , police forensic work , environmental testing and food testing .	end
1	Biochips come in two main types : the microfluidics chip or " lab - on - a - chip , " and the microarray chip or " DNA chip . "	end
1	Microfluidics chips bring together biotechnology , microelectronics , micromachining and other technologies to integrate the functions of multiple laboratory instruments onto a single chip in miniaturized form .	end
1	Meanwhile on microarray chips , biological molecules such as gene segments , oligonucleotides , proteins or antibodies are bound to the chip surface in an array of tiny spots , and a single chip may carry many tens of thousands of such spots .	end
1	BMEC researcher Pan Chao - chi uses the example of blood screening for a blood bank to illustrate the difference between the two kinds of chips .	BMEC ! org ; Pan Chao - chi ! person ;
1	To test a blood sample using a microarray chip , the sample must first go through many preparatory steps such as purification , nucleotide extraction , copying , amplification and labeling before being put onto the chip where the " hybridization " reaction takes place .	end
1	Finally , the results are analyzed using a detection system .	end
1	Hence these chips are only suitable for use in the laboratory .	end
1	In contrast , with a lab - on - a - chip system , all the laboratory preparation stages will be done on the chip itself , so that the user need only place a drop of blood directly onto the chip to obtain a result .	end
1	At present , microfluidics technology is not yet mature , and no such chips have been launched as commercial products anywhere .	end
1	But , says Pan Chao - chih : " This is the way future biochip development will go . "	Pan Chao - chih ! person ;
1	The poor man 's chip	The poor man 's chip ! art ;
1	Future prospects also seem infinite for microarray chips , which are already widely used in laboratories and research establishments .	end
1	Jerry Huang notes that DNA chips are an indispensable research tool in molecular biology .	Jerry Huang ! person ;
1	On one little biochip , tens of thousands of gene segments can be arranged to simultaneously detect the expression of tens of thousands of genes .	one ! num ; tens of thousands ! num ; tens of thousands ! num ;
1	In other words , whereas in the past researchers had to investigate each gene individually , today , using biochips , they can obtain test results for tens of thousands of genes at once .	tens of thousands ! num ;
1	In particular , biochips not only can speed the pace of research , but can also replace laboratory animals such as rats and rabbits in many experiments , with tests being carried out directly on human genes on the chip .	end
1	Thus as research tools biochips are not only convenient and quick , but also more humane .	end
1	Dr. Konan Peck , an assistant research fellow at Academia Sinica 's Institute of Biomedical Sciences -LRB- IBMS -RRB- , says that biochips need to be made more widely available as a molecular biology research tool .	Konan Peck ! person ; Academia Sinica 's Institute of Biomedical Sciences ! org ; IBMS ! org ;
1	With this in mind , Peck has developed nylon - based biochips which have been called " the poor man 's biochip , " since they cost a third less than glass chips .	Peck ! person ; a third ! num ;
1	Apart from the material itself being cheaper , the nylon chips use a visible - spectrum colorimetric system to display results , so that they can be read using an ordinary optical scanner , which costs 50 - 70 % less than using a special laser detector .	50 - 70 % ! per ;
1	The nylon membrane biochips currently produced by TGS and U - Vision Biotech are all derived from the technology developed by Konan Peck .	TGS ! org ; U - Vision Biotech ! org ; Konan Peck ! person ;
1	Cutting edge	Cutting edge ! art ;
1	Can Taiwan really repeat its success in the semiconductor industry , to become a major production center for biochips ?	Taiwan ! country ;
1	BMEC director Johnsee Lee observes that the level of scientific and technical know - how required for biochip production is very high , so that the opportunities for contract manufacture are limited .	BMEC ! org ; Johnsee Lee ! person ;
1	However , due to Taiwan 's early entry into biochip research and development , and the high state of development of its semiconductor industry , the island is well supplied with relevant technology and skills .	Taiwan ! country ;
1	Thus , says Lee , " Taiwan should have opportunities to enter this field not merely as a contract manufacturer . "	Lee ! person ; Taiwan ! country ;
1	The potential and importance of biochips is plain to see , but in this new , interdisciplinary industry , there are still many obstacles and difficulties to overcome .	end
1	Apart from the fact that the technology is not yet mature , and that generally accepted , mutually compatible international standards have not yet emerged , the biggest bottleneck for biochips at the moment is the many thousands of patents which have been taken out in the field , which limit the avenues available to each player .	end
1	" Because this area is a patents minefield , it 's impossible to create a product which from start to finish does n't infringe on anyone else 's patents , " says Johnsee Lee .	Johnsee Lee ! person ;
1	In his view , this problem may be resolved in the future by the exchange of patented technologies between players .	end
1	In other words , at this stage companies must actively carry out research and development , and obtain international patents , in order to have bargaining chips in future negotiations .	end
1	At present , the BMEC has over 10 patents pending in the areas of microfluidics biochips , chip surface processing technology and probe design and applications .	BMEC ! org ; 10 ! num ;
1	Pushing the envelope	end
1	Although at their present stage of development , biochips are already a great help to researchers , they are still far removed from ordinary people 's lives .	end
1	But one day they will play an important role in all our lives .	end
1	" Applications and commercialization are our goal , " says Johnsee Lee .	Johnsee Lee ! person ;
1	He says that only if research results are commercialized does research produce an economic payback .	end
1	Equally , to have a really broad market biochips need to go beyond the laboratory researcher , and into hospitals , clinics and homes , and to individual users .	end
1	Lee points out that before biochips will be worth commercializing , sample preparation needs to be made convenient , reading results must be simple and easy , the chips ' speed and accuracy must be high , and their cost must be low .	Lee ! person ;
1	He predicts that in one to two years , biochips will be suitable for use in supplemental tests , and after around three years for high - throughput screening ; in five years time it should be possible to develop them into general screening tools which will be as easy to use as the pregnancy test kits on the market today .	one to two years ! date ; around three years ! date ;
1	IBMS associate research fellow Konan Peck agrees that in the foreseeable future , diagnostic chips will enable everyone to learn their current state of health and know what diseases they may develop in the future .	IBMS ! org ; Konan Peck ! person ;
1	But in a situation where testing technology is ahead of medical treatment technology , the medical problems so discovered may not be treatable .	end
1	Mankind is always challenging his limits , and when , in the near future , biochips lift the veil of many diseases , the next challenge will have only just begun .	end
1	Genteel Journalis --	end
1	Thomas Lu	Thomas Lu ! person ;
1	-LRB- Eric Lin / tr. by Robert Taylor -RRB-	Eric Lin ! person ; Robert Taylor ! person ;
1	Thomas Lu is the doyen of the Chinese news media .	Thomas Lu ! person ; Chinese ! national ;
1	Still out on the journalistic front lines at 81 , this spry , forthright veteran has an immense zest for life .	81 ! date ;
1	At 78 , drawing on his astonishingly sharp memory , he completed his reminiscences and " record of emotional regrets . "	78 ! date ;
1	He is not only one of the " wonders " of Taiwan 's journalistic world , but is also recognized by those of his generation as a gentleman and a " good - looking man . "	Taiwan ! country ;
1	A person 's looks change with their age and their state of mind .	end
1	Many friends have told me I look better the older I get .	end
1	People do n't know that when I was young I had dreadful protruding teeth , but now not only do my teeth no longer show , but the lines of my face have also softened .	end
1	People who know me know that there have always been two great loves in my life : the news , and women .	two ! num ;
1	Now that I 'm in my 80s , looking back I think I can say I 've done alright in both respects , and I 've learnt that both reporting the news well , and finding favor with women , depend on your character and conduct .	80s ! date ;
1	Journalism is not just a profession , but should also be a vocation - you have to throw yourself fully into this infinitely broad field of endeavor .	end
1	Intellectually and spiritually , in work and in love , I have gained experience and fulfilment .	end
1	I have always remembered the encouragement which Mr. Yu Youren gave me as a young reporter .	Yu Youren ! person ;
1	He said that to be a fearless champion of social justice , as is expected of a journalist , the most important thing , apart from energy and vitality , is modesty .	end
1	You have to treat everybody the same , and not be overawed by the great and powerful .	end
1	A president or a street sweeper deserve the same respect as a human being , and should both be treated the same way .	end
1	Funnily enough , an unassuming attitude is also advantageous in relations with the opposite sex .	end
1	Chinese society is male dominated , and women are mostly regarded as having a subsidiary role .	Chinese ! national ;
1	In this kind of unfair situation , an upstanding man should cherish and respect women all the more .	end
1	A considerate attitude can be expressed in little things .	end
1	For instance , when you see that a hair has fallen onto a female friend 's shoulder , you should lightly pick it off for her , and throw it away or put it in your pocket .	end
1	If sincere , this kind of action is attractive in a man .	end
1	If a woman expresses her liking for you , then no matter whether she is pretty , or whether you find her attractive , you should respond in the same way , and with the same respect .	end
1	When I was a young reporter stationed in Europe , there was a British woman reporter who liked me very much .	Europe ! location ; British ! national ;
1	Once I was driving her somewhere to report a story when we had an accident , and she suffered some badly broken bones .	end
1	Although I was n't attracted to her in that way , I went to see her every day in hospital , and this left a deep impression on her of how considerate Chinese men can be .	Chinese ! national ;
1	Looking back at my life , I 've hardly had any really bad experiences in my relationships with women , and this is because just as in my professional life , I 've always maintained a self - critical attitude towards my emotions , and always tried to prevent myself acting like a male chauvinist .	end
1	Looks are something you are born with , but character is something you can work on , and it can outweigh your appearance .	end
1	Luo Jialun , one of the leading lights of the May Fourth Movement , is a famous example .	Luo Jialun ! person ; the May Fourth Movement ! thing ;
1	Luo was not good looking , and was even ridiculed as " looking like a cross between a pig , a dog and a bear . "	Luo ! person ;
1	But he was tremendously well - read , had a beautiful writing style , and for a time he was Chinese ambassador to India .	Chinese ! national ; India ! country ;
1	His wife was a universally admired beauty , the envy of all .	end
1	So I say , " handsome is as handsome does . "	end
1	I was imprisoned by both the Kuomintang and the Communists , and at times I might have been killed .	Kuomintang ! org ; Communists ! national ;
1	Perhaps other people in the same situation might have wallowed in self - pity , but I saw it as a rare opportunity in life .	end
1	In 1951 , in a dark prison cell during a big Communist purge , what came into my mind was not fear of death .	1951 ! date ; Communist ! national ;
1	Instead , I wondered what kind of headline my death would merit in the newspapers .	end
1	" 10,000 Rush to See Lu Executed " ?	10,000 ! num ; Lu ! person ;
1	Perhaps it was this eternal optimism which changed my frame of mind and my appearance .	end
1	This is the advice I 'd like to give young people :	end
1	it 's true that good looks can come from external grooming , wearing nice clothes , or wearing earrings ; and perhaps you can get other people 's attention by creating your own special look .	end
1	But do n't overdo it .	end
1	It is appropriate dress , and a temperament developed through study and practice , which really make a man attractive .	end
1	-- basically , it was unanimously agreed upon by the various relevant parties .	end

1	It takes time to prove whether the stock reform can really meet expectations , and whether any deviations that arise during the stock reform can be promptly corrected .	end

1	Children are left at home in the rural areas , after parents leave to work in the city .	end
1	These are called left - behind children .	end
1	The parents are also forced to work in the city .	end
1	In fact , they have no alternatives but to make such a decision .	end
1	There are 120 million farmers who work in the city all year round in China , thus creating nearly 20 million left - behind children .	120 million ! num ; China ! country ; 20 million ! num ;
1	I want to tell them that I miss them a lot .	end
1	Day after day and year after year , they long for love in loneliness and wait for family affection in defect .	end
1	I think that it is especially important to have emotional exchanges with the children .	end
1	Visit the children more often whenever possible .	end
1	-LSB- -RSB-	end
1	In September 2005 , a study report titled " Concern for Left - behind Children " had drawn wide public attention .	September 2005 ! date ; " Concern for Left - behind Children " ! art ;
1	While the situation of peasant workers in the city has repeatedly put society into question , the phenomenon of left - behind children in rural areas has gradually entered the view of the public .	end
1	Ye Jingzhong is the assistant dean of the College of Humanities and Development at China Agricultural University , and team leader of the Left - behind Children Task Force .	Ye Jingzhong ! person ; the College of Humanities and Development ! org ; China Agricultural University ! org ; the Left - behind Children Task Force ! org ;
1	In the last two years , he has led the task force to conduct many field interviews and investigations on left - behind children in numerous rural areas in central and western China , including Shaanxi , Ningxia , Hebei , and Beijing .	the last two years ! date ; China ! country ; Shaanxi ! country ; Ningxia ! country ; Hebei ! country ; Beijing ! country ;
1	Why did you pick the central and western parts of China , and not the south , to conduct this study ?	China ! country ;
1	First of all , for people who work in the city from the central and western regions um , uh , according to their educational level , they generally engage in strenuous manual labor when they leave for the city to work .	First ! order ;
1	They are not in a position to bring their children to the city .	end
1	When we conducted this research study , our focus was to analyze the impact on children when their parents , work in the city .	end
1	, its main impact is the lack of love because of the absence of their parents .	end
1	Therefore , we believe that whether it 's in southern or northern part , no matter which part of the country the research is conducted in , the results should be consistent .	end
1	According to your estimation , how many left - behind children are there in China now ?	China ! country ;
1	This group should be the biggest in number .	end
1	Um , the most conservative statistics for the group of people who leave the country to work in the city in our country is 100 million .	100 million ! num ;
1	Nowadays , um , , um , many places , um , cite a figure of 120 million .	120 million ! num ;
1	Many people quote a figure of 150 million .	150 million ! num ;
1	Let 's think about it this way .	end
1	If we actually use 120 million as the statistic for the group who leave the country to work in the city , , at least half of them are um , married before they work in the city .	120 million ! num ; half ! num ;
1	Of course , families of these married people will usually have children .	end
1	Moreover , they will usually have more than one child in rural areas .	more than one ! num ;
1	So you can imagine .	end
1	I believe the left - behind children group is definitely more than 10 or 20 million .	more than 10 or 20 million ! num ;
1	It , uh , , in my opinion , should be around 50 million .	50 million ! num ;
1	Of course , we have not conducted exact statistical calculations .	end
1	I believe the number of this group should be particularly large .	end
1	According to the study by the task force , at present , the four main types of custody for left - behind children include single - parent custody , skip - generation custody , relative custody , and same - generation custody . Among which , single - parent custody had the highest number , accounting for 79.2 percent of the people surveyed .	four ! num ; 79.2 percent ! per ;
1	The next one was skip - generation custody , accounting for 16.9 percent . While those who lived with relatives or were entrusted to the care of someone else made up 4.1 percent and .9 percent of the total number of left - behind children , respectively .	one ! num ; 16.9 percent ! per ; 4.1 percent ! per ; .9 percent ! per ;
1	According to your study , what do these left - behind children generally do with their daily life if their parents or parent work in the city ?	end
1	Different types of custody have different impacts on their life .	end
1	No doubt , , single - parent custody definitely creates less impact compared to the other types .	end
1	The impact of single - parent custody is smaller because at least the mother is at home .	end
1	There is no major problem in the children 's material life .	end
1	Of course , there are many impacts in other aspects , for instance , peer socialization .	end
1	The one that creates a huge impact is definitely skip - generation custody .	one ! num ;
1	Skip - generation custody means the grandparents look after the children .	end
1	There is also relative or neighbor custody that asks neighbors or relatives to look after the children , and there is a type called self - custody .	end
1	These three types create the biggest and the most impact .	three ! num ;
1	If we want to discuss this in more detail , let 's say , the skip - generation custody .	end
1	First , in skip - generation custody , their material life will no doubt be a lot less taken care of when compared to the usual both parents or one parent at home situation .	First ! order ;
1	This is indisputable .	end
1	This type of family is not as good as the others .	end
1	We had an example of a child in Shaanxi province .	Shaanxi province ! country ;
1	Um , there was a family !	end
1	This family had an older brother and a younger sister .	end
1	Both parents wanted to go to the city to work .	end
1	The father went first , and later the mother wanted to go , too .	first ! order ;
1	What happened to these two children ?	two ! num ;
1	The grandparents were unwilling to take care of them because in rural areas , grandparents also have to work in the field !	end
1	As a result , , this mother sent , these brother and sister , to martial arts school to study .	end
1	After they went to the martial arts school for a while , um , their mother was , um , a little worried , so she went to visit them .	end
1	She went to visit them .	end
1	When she saw them , , the girl cried to her and said , " I really do n't want to stay here .	end
1	I want to go home . "	end
1	Later , the mother was moved and brought , this girl home and had the grandparents look after her .	end
1	Um , she still , ai , left him at the martial arts school .	end
1	Um , um , after the girl returned , the mother continued to work in the city .	end
1	When she came back one time in between work , she found that the girl 's body was dotted with red marks and red swellings .	one ! num ;
1	She then discovered ah , um , the grandparents had not washed her clothes for a very long time .	end
1	The situation you mentioned , is it common or is it a rather extreme example , because generally , people will think that grandparents will particularly love and care about their grandchildren ?	end
1	The situation that I just mentioned regarding skip - generation custody is no doubt common .	end
1	Why is it so ?	end
1	You said that grandparents certainly have special love for the children .	end
1	It is true .	end
1	It is true that they will go out of their way to pamper the children .	end
1	However , for the elderly , with the difference in age and time , , their , ways of taking care and loving the children are different .	end
1	They are influenced by their own habits .	end
1	For instance , there was a child who was sick .	end
1	Um , the grandparents asked him to take , a small pill that was made in Shaanxi .	Shaanxi ! country ;
1	They did not even know what it was made of .	end
1	It was a local method .	end
1	Um , after all , they are different from , um , young people in this respect .	end
1	Instead of sending the child to the hospital as quickly as possible , they are influenced by , some habits in this aspect .	end
1	, they raised this point themselves .	end
1	Another important point they mentioned was that they had to take care of the entire family .	end
1	" Her father and mother are not home , so the entire family falls onto our shoulders , especially when we still have to be responsible for the farm work on the farmland .	end
1	So , all I can do is to feed her and make sure that she is not cold . "	end
1	They also had to face such a reality , one that they could not resolve .	end
1	After all , a family that had so many people in the beginning , , the parents of the children were a very important um , workforce .	end
1	Now it was down to the two grandparents .	two ! num ;
1	No doubt , they could not help .	end
1	In the study of left - behind children , many staff found out by surprise that the biological cycle of the farmers who work in the city , and the inculcation and upbringing cycle of their children , have formed two parallel lines that will never meet .	two ! num ;
1	Farmers who work in the city are generally a young workforce in their prime , while this is the period in which their children attend primary or junior high school .	end
1	Originally , they work in the city out of the hope that their children can receive a better education .	end
1	However , adolescent children need the loving care and guidance of their parents even more .	end
1	During this period , the absence of both or even one parent will create obstacles to the character development of the children .	end
1	This pair of unavoidable contradictions has made the problem of left - behind children in rural areas become more obvious .	end
1	You have seen many kinds of left - behind children .	end
1	Was there a particular case or a particular child who had left an especially deep impression on you that you still remember now ?	end
1	, um , there was a child in Ningxia whose name was Yao Zhengang .	Ningxia ! country ; Yao Zhengang ! person ;
1	This child , um , did not do exceptionally well in school .	end
1	What impressed me the most about him was that he really missed his parents .	end
1	He felt particularly lonely and especially wanted his father to come back .	end
1	He said that he was sick one time .	one ! num ;
1	His father worked in Guyuan , about 40 to 50 kilometers away from home .	Guyuan ! country ; 40 to 50 kilometers ! measure ;
1	After his father learned that he was very sick , he ran back to the village right away .	end
1	After he arrived at the village , he did not say anything , but to put him on his back and carry him to the town to see a doctor .	end
1	He just carried him like that without saying a word .	end
1	When the doctor in the town took a look and told him that they were unable to cure the sickness , he carried the child to the county .	end
1	When Yao Zhengang told us what happened , he said , " My father had never bought me so many tasty foods before .	Yao Zhengang ! person ;
1	On that day , he bought me a lot of tasty food while we were in the county , but he did not eat any himself . "	that day ! date ;
1	I thought about this at that time .	end
1	After I heard this incident , I particularly understood what was in the mind of Yao Zhengang 's father .	Yao Zhengang 's ! person ;
1	He might have felt especially guilty toward his child .	end
1	What he felt was that " I go out to work and leave my child home . "	end

1	He would say , " No problem . You work hard and get a better grade next time , " when I had low grades .	end
1	If he could receive many , such encouragements , he would not have um , um , disliked school sometimes .	end
1	He does not want to go to school now .	end
1	However , in his example , I could imagine what went through his father 's mind at that time .	end
1	I think that he felt very guilty toward his child .	end

1	This is Ruangang village , Bocang town , Yi county , Hebei province .	Ruangang village , Bocang town , Yi county , Hebei province ! country ;
1	Among the 303 households in the village , one - third of the families have people who work in the city .	303 ! num ; one - third ! num ;
1	More than half of the children in the village are left - behind children .	More than half ! num ;
1	Most of the children 's parents are in the southern part of the country .	end
1	Many people want to save some travel expenses and earn some more money , so it is very common for them not to return home for a year or two .	a year or two ! date ;
1	Life is so vast .	end
1	Life is an ocean wherever life exists .	end
1	It has been six years since 14 - year - old Jiang Beiwen was sent by his parents to live with his maternal grandfather in Ruangang village .	six years ! date ; 14 - year ! date ; Jiang Beiwen ! person ; Ruangang village ! country ;
1	His parents rely on selling rice in Guangzhou to support their child 's education .	Guangzhou ! country ;

1	Since they move from place to place in the city to work all year round , parents of left - behind children have little communication with their children .	end
1	While for temporary custodians , they are only limited to providing superficial care , such as making sure the children have food and stay warm , but can not fulfill the responsibility of educating the children .	end
1	The survey found that 36.7 percent of the children had never been to their parents ' workplace .	36.7 percent ! per ;
1	8.2 percent of the parents almost never contacted their children .	8.2 percent ! per ;
1	21.4 percent of the parents contacted their children less than once a month .	21.4 percent ! per ;
1	Since their parents are absent , how can these children communicate and exchange with their parents ?	end
1	Our study found that um , um , the principal means of contact between the left - behind children and their parents was through the telephone .	end
1	However , contrary to our belief that they could talk on the phone for a long time when they called , approximately 50 percent of the left - behind children we surveyed talked on the phone with their parents for three minutes or so .	approximately 50 percent ! per ; three minutes ! time ;
1	What could they talk about in three minutes ?	three minutes ! time ;
1	I think it is hard to say anything meaningful in three minutes .	three minutes ! time ;
1	Of course , we also studied what these children talked to their parents about in these three - minute telephone conversations .	three - minute ! time ;
1	What did the parents who worked in the city talk about with their children ?	end
1	What touched us very deeply was that 70 percent of the content of the children 's conversations with their parents was to ask about their safety and not other things , such as how much they had earned .	70 percent ! per ;
1	As for the content of the parents ' conversations with their children , first , it was school .	first ! order ;
1	Whether they were good and how their schoolwork was .	end
1	Second , it was whether they obeyed their custodians and what they ate and things like that .	Second ! order ;
1	Uh , as for safety matters , in fact , they could not have any emotional exchange .	end
1	We know that sometimes when we talk on the phone , even a pause is a need for emotional exchange .	end
1	However , the parents may not have realized this .	end
1	For instance , the child has stopped talking .	end
1	He stops talking because he needs to pause to consider how to say what is in his mind .	end
1	The parents may not have realized this point , so they hang up the phone immediately .	end
1	Of course , for three minutes , why was it only for three minutes ?	three minutes ! time ; three minutes ! time ;
1	In many cases , it was because they worried about the charge .	end
1	, many left - behind children told us that they especially wanted to call their parents on the phone .	end
1	However , um , they considered that um , one thing , sometimes they did not have a telephone at home .	one ! num ;
1	It was very difficult for children to borrow the phone from their neighbors .	end

1	Some children told me , " I secretly called my parents when my custodians were not home . "	end
1	The children have a great need for this type of telephone exchange .	end
1	Do the left - behind children understand why their parents work in the city ?	end
1	Um , um , we conducted a survey on this question .	end
1	We were very surprised to find that 40 percent of the left - behind children had no idea what jobs their parents held away from home .	40 percent ! per ;
1	How could that be possible ?	end
1	How could that be possible ?	end
1	We interviewed some left - behind children , their custodians , and the people who work in the city .	end
1	Why would n't the children know what they did ?	end
1	First , we can tell from the content of the three - minute telephone conversations we mentioned earlier that children are particularly concerned about the safety of the parents who work in the city .	First ! order ; three - minute ! time ;
1	However , a lot of the work that the parents engaged in is dangerous work , including coalmines , construction , and some others , many of them are dangerous jobs .	end
1	Thus , I believe the parents of these left - behind children also choose not to take the initiative and tell them the nature of their job .	end

1	Eliminate the personal income tax -LRB- Reproduced from Yueguang blog -RRB- .	Yueguang blog ! art ;
1	Dift Wu	Dift Wu ! person ;
1	Official data confirm that in 2004 the total personal income tax for the country amounted to approximately 181 billion , of which 65 % came from the working class , and only 10 % came from the wealthy .	2004 ! date ; approximately 181 billion ! num ; 65 % ! per ; 10 % ! per ;
1	Clearly the personal income tax policy has too little effect on controlling wealth accumulation by the rich , and too little impact on improving the quality of life of wage earners .	end
1	While this type of tax in China has no effect on regulating the income gap or on " taking from the rich to help the poor , " neither is it beneficial in expanding the working class .	China ! country ;
1	If this tax continues to be collected , it will be working against the original intention behind the income tax .	end
1	Clearly the necessity for the personal income tax needs to be challenged .	end
1	I propose eliminating the personal income tax just as the agricultural tax was eliminated , to give people an opportunity to prosper .	end
1	If we think in terms of humanizing the system , i.e. , helping the poor by letting poor people get rich , we should give low - and moderate - income people a chance to improve and raise the quality of their lives ; the threshold for China 's personal income tax should be at least tripled from the starting threshold of 800 yuan per month , i.e. , to 6400 yuan per person .	China ! country ; 800 yuan ! money ; 6400 yuan ! money ;
1	That would take it to a minimally humanized level , and then we could really talk about " people first . "	first ! order ;
1	With a threshold below this level , the poor will always be poor .	end
1	Yesterday CCTV presented a program on adjustment of the personal income tax , emphasized that the main goal of the adjustment was to " take from the rich " and let poor people get wealthy .	CCTV ! org ;
1	If we really want to give poor people a chance to get wealthy , the threshold for the personal income tax should be tripled .	end
1	With anything under this threshold , the poor will have no chance to get rich .	end
1	And if we 're looking at it in terms of " taking from the rich , " the problem to be adjusted is definitely not whether or not to tax income but rather the problem of the actual method for distributing China 's social national income , namely how to eliminate the " unreported income . "	China ! country ;
1	The income of the vast majority of China 's rich people is unreported income , and unreported income is a problem that Chinese society will not be able to solve for quite a long time to come ; it is a characteristic of China , an uncontrollable black hole in China 's social oversight .	China ! country ; Chinese ! national ; China ! country ; China ! country ;
1	This is far from being a tax problem ; it is a deeper systemic problem .	end
1	If China 's personal income tax can not achieve the effect of helping the poor to become rich , neither can it control the excessive incomes of the wealthy , so what is it we expect this personal income tax to do ?	China ! country ;
1	It would be better to eliminate it in one fell swoop , as we did with the agricultural tax .	one ! num ;
1	Below are some of the main reasons :	end
1	1. China 's income tax can not become a tool for keeping the poor perpetually poor ; it can not become a social tool that keeps on producing a penniless proletariat .	1. China ! num ;
1	In China the primary function of the income tax is to increase the state 's financial revenues ; it is not to regulate the income gap .	China ! country ;
1	In 2004 China 's income taxes amounted to approximately 180 billion , accounting for about 6 % of the state 's financial revenues .	2004 China ! date ; approximately 180 billion ! country ; about 6 % ! num ;
1	But of this 180 billion , about 65 % , or 117 billion , was paid by the working class .	180 billion ! num ; about 65 % ! per ; 117 billion ! num ;
1	Less than 10 % was paid by the wealthy .	Less than 10 % ! per ;
1	In China more than 90 % of the people who depend on fully declared total earnings for a living are urban poor .	China more than 90 % ! country ;
1	These poor people , who struggle just to pay for the necessities of life , their children 's education , old age , illness and death , also have to pay income tax .	end
1	In all of China 's cities now , anyone with a monthly income of 2000 yuan or less is considered poor .	China ! country ; 2000 yuan or less ! money ;
1	If a husband and wife have a total monthly work income of 2000 yuan , and if they pay 33 % income tax on anything over 1500 yuan , they have a disposable income of only 1670 yuan .	2000 yuan ! money ; 33 % ! per ; over 1500 yuan ! money ; 1670 yuan ! money ;
1	A household like this can not even continue bearing basic living expenses , and their standard of living will decline .	end
1	And should anyone in the household get sick and have to go to the hospital , the family may well find itself in an economic crisis .	end
1	And if a family like this wants to buy its own home , that will basically be impossible .	end
1	And if only one person in a three - person family is employed , the family will have a very difficult life .	one ! num ; three ! num ;
1	But even so , they have to pay 165 yuan in income tax .	165 yuan ! money ;
1	Clearly , if our income tax threshold is set at 1500 yuan , our society is destined always to produce a proletariat , always to deny hope to the poor or to the masses of ever getting rich .	1500 yuan ! money ;
1	Our production relations are no different from the production relations in Marx 's " Das Kapital , " constantly reproducing a proletariat who can only rely on selling its labor to make a living .	Marx ! person ; Das Kapital ! art ;
1	In short , if the personal income tax threshold is set lower than 6400 yuan , it will be ineffective in helping the poor get rich .	6400 yuan ! money ;
1	Conversely , if the threshold is too low , it will cleanly and quickly inhibit the ability of poor people to get rich .	end
1	2. The personal income tax is absolutely unable to control the accumulation of wealth by the rich .	2. ! num ;
1	We should not entertain any illusions that China 's income tax can in any way regulate income distribution , much less that it can " take from the rich and give to the poor . "	China ! country ;
1	In Chinese society , 20 % of the people hold 80 % of social wealth , and 80 % of the people are able to use only 20 % of the social wealth to suffer through their lives .	Chinese ! national ; 20 % ! per ; 80 % ! per ; 80 % ! per ; 20 % ! per ;
1	In China , freedom , human rights , democracy , happiness and all the other most effective benefits that society can offer refer only to 20 % of the people .	China ! country ; 20 % ! per ;
1	Western countries that attack China for not having human rights , democracy and freedom are quite wrong ; these 20 % of upper - class citizens have broader human rights , democracy and freedom than do Western societies .	China ! country ; these 20 % ! per ;
1	When God looks at China , he sees only these 20 % ; the other 80 % he ca n't see clearly .	China ! country ; these 20 % ! per ; 80 % ! per ;
1	The income of the vast majority of these 20 , of upper - class citizens in China is basically unreported income ; the proportion of their income that comes from fully declared earnings is a negligible part of their wealth .	20 ! num ; China ! country ;
1	Only if China eliminated unreported income would the income tax have an effect on rich people .	China ! country ;
1	And if China wants to eliminate unreported income , to date there is no sign of that , and there is no compelling evidence to explain when China might eliminate unreported income .	China ! country ; China ! country ;
1	Anyhow , it is not something our generation will see .	end
1	That is why the income tax has no effect on regulating the wealth of China 's rich people .	China ! country ;
1	It does however have a highly restrictive effect on the ability of poor people to get rich .	end
1	A very simple explanation is that poor people are all wage earners who rely on fully declared wages for their living ; they do not have unreported income .	end
1	Fully 100 % of their income falls within the income - tax field of vision , so they ca n't escape even if they wanted to .	100 % ! per ;
1	Add to this the fact that the threshold is under the level required to meet the necessary expenditures to maintain the basic necessities of life , and the poor are completely stymied .	end
1	" Dragons give birth to dragons , phoenixes to phoenixes ; the son of a bandit will live in a cave . "	end
1	" The children of poor people are always poor . "	end
1	With the previous 800 yuan income tax threshold , if it were strictly enforced , 80 % of beggars would have to pay .	800 yuan ! money ; 80 % ! per ;
1	With a threshold set below 5000 yuan , this generation of poor people need not think about buying a home or driving a car .	5000 yuan ! money ;
1	They will always be poor .	end
1	Of course , many children of poor people are able to get rich , but this came about because the parents struggled harder , tightening their belts and " skimping on food and clothing " for themselves .	end
1	Now how many university students who have received acceptance notifications are unable to enroll , and how many enrolled university students from the countryside have parents who are living through unimaginably hard times ?	end
1	In Western countries , the personal income tax is the most effective means of controlling excessively high incomes among the rich .	end
1	But these are countries ruled by law , where official income is all recorded , citizen 's incomes are fully transparent , and therefore the personal income tax can easily achieve the effect of regulating income distribution .	end
1	The situation in China is not like that ; if the personal income tax has an effect , it 's to increase financial revenues , and it has absolutely no income - regulating effect .	China ! country ;
1	3. Eliminating the income tax will benefit peasants .	3. ! num ;
1	The vast majority of China 's 900 million peasants are unable to reach the income level for paying income tax .	900 million ! num ;
1	But the peasants have contractual land , they have a low - consumption rural lifestyle and conditions , and they have basic housing .	end
1	But if people in the cities do n't have money , everything is a struggle .	end
1	If they go shopping for food by bike , they have to pay 20 cents for parking .	20 cents ! money ;
1	They ca n't not pay the rent or they 'll have to sleep on the street .	end
1	In terms of macroeconomic law , the distribution of wealth in Chinese society is set at 2/8 , with the 20 % of wealthy people holding 80 % of the social wealth , and the 80 % of poor people holding just 20 % of the social wealth .	Chinese ! national ; 2/8 ! num ; the 20 % ! per ; 80 % ! per ; the 80 % ! per ; 20 % ! per ;
1	The personal income tax threshold is too low , the urban population is too large , and the population participating in the 20 % that goes to peasants is even greater , so the peasants ultimately have to get a reduced share of this 20 % .	the 20 % ! per ; this 20 % ! per ;
1	If we eliminate the personal income tax , the number of poor people in the cities will be reduced , and the people participating in the peasant struggle for this 20 % will be reduced , which will benefit the peasants .	this 20 % ! per ;
1	In China the wealthy will always hold 80 % of the social wealth ; there has never been a softhearted rich person .	China ! country ; 80 % ! per ;
1	4. This will really be beneficial in establishing a soft - landing market economy system .	4. ! num ;
1	In recent years China 's rate of state financial growth has been higher than economic growth ; this is a highly abnormal phenomenon , and in terms of economic theory it is highly adverse for sustained , healthy growth of the national economy .	recent years China ! date ;
1	The blood has all been pumped out of the national economy ; it 's like eating up all the seeds sown in the spring .	end
1	The proportion of financial revenues from the personal income tax is about 6 % .	about 6 % ! per ;
1	If we cancel out this 6 % , we can slow down financial growth .	this 6 % ! per ;
1	And in the Chinese economic cycle , excessive financial investment is not a good thing for economic growth and the establishment of a true market economy system .	Chinese ! national ;
1	Compared to market investment , the efficiency of financial investment is less than half .	less than half ! num ;
1	And when there is too much financial investment , corruption is everywhere , all the time .	end
1	5. It promotes the establishment of a harmonious society .	5. ! num ;
1	Chinese and foreign history amply demonstrates that a harmonious society is an olive - shaped society : the distribution of numbers of poor , middle - class and wealthy people making up the society is small at either end and larger in the middle , with 40 % or more of the society being middle class .	Chinese ! national ; 40 % or more ! per ;
1	Chinese society is 80 % poor people , 20 % wealthy ; there is no stable middle class , or it floats between the lower levels of the wealthy and the upper end of the poor and is highly unstable .	Chinese ! national ; 80 % ! per ; 20 % ! per ;
1	There is no way this " 2/8 " social structure can establish a harmonious society .	2/8 ! num ;
1	Eliminating the personal income tax to accumulate wealth for the people will be beneficial in producing and nourishing a middle class and will promote the creation of a harmonious society .	end
1	In short , if our personal income tax policy can not help the poor get rich , and is unable to limit the excessive increase in wealth among the rich , then it is better not to have this kind of personal income tax .	end
1	We need to adopt this kind of strategic insight when we consider this matter , so as to benefit the country and the people .	end
1	This essay is dedicated to all the hardworking people of the world .	end

1	Advice to Wu Jinglian and Others : Killing the Father -- Does You No Good ! .	Wu Jinglian ! person ;
1	613305	613305 ! person ;
1	Posted by -LSB- Little Peng Zhongyi -RSB- at Jan 3 , 2007 18:53:26 -LSB- SMS -RSB- -LSB- Tables -RSB- .	Peng Zhongyi ! person ; Jan 3 , 2007 18:53:26 ! date ;
1	Advice to Wu Jinglian and Others : Killing the Father -- Does You No Good ! .	Wu Jinglian ! person ;
1	-- Some Thoughts on the Attitude of Benign Inheritance towards Social Reform .	end
1	A glance at the title , people with a little political sensitivity may roughly understand the core topic of this article : the rule of benign interaction between planned economy and market economy , and between public ownership and private ownership -- because only their relationships are those between a father and a son , and it is only between them are there different conflicts involving " human relations , " " rules " and " science , " as well as bloody wrestling between classes , factions and individuals on the basis of morality and interests .	end
1	Comparing planned economy and public ownership to a father is tantamount to comparing market economy and private ownership to a son , which holds water principally and historically no matter you put it this way or another .	end
1	This is because the former two given " fatherhood " are indeed the most essential factors of the national character and institution of the socialist new China , while the latter two dubbed " son " in this article -- are indeed the ideological outcomes derived after the death of China 's founder Comrade Mao Zedong under tremendous international and domestic political pressures on planned economy and public ownership , which grew into today 's para-system after about 30 years of reform and opening up .	two ! num ; socialist ! national ; China ! country ; China ! country ; Mao Zedong ! person ; today ! date ; 30 years ! date ;
1	Regarding this , the factual development process of political civilization that the Marxist ideology has been increasingly marginalized over the past 30 years or so is a strong evidence .	Marxist ! national ; the past 30 years ! date ;
1	By sorting out the essence of the above historical background and conceptual relationships , we will have a pretty thorough , comprehensive and systematic knowledge framework about the benign inevitable trends and development guidelines of the future society dependent on the rule of society , so that the associated impression captured may be more concrete .	end
1	Regarding this , my standpoint is : because the socialism underpinned by planned economy , public ownership and the people 's democratic dictatorship is indeed a really " fresh " systemic thing for China in the mid and late 20th century -- without a model or sufficient experience or theories to refer to , no matter how scientific its kernel is , it is hard not to have certain superficial and local problems .	China ! country ; the mid and late 20th century ! date ;
1	However , this should not provide an excuse to overthrow it by fair means or foul , as he is our father and the common choice of millions of laboring people .	millions ! num ;
1	The fact that it " finally became our national character and main system after over half a century of international and domestic political transformation " is a stronger proof that it is the milestone for a new civilization resulted from the blood and sweat of thousands of proletarian revolutionary martyrs .	half a century ! date ; thousands ! num ;
1	Therefore , no matter from the perspective of average citizens or from the standpoint of the founder of the new government , we should respect and develop her on the basis of inheritance , innovation and improvement .	end
1	Is my opinion above correct ?	end
1	I believe you will naturally obtain a relatively fair and just conclusion if you could understand and treat the above - mentioned " father " system and " son " system with impartiality and sufficient goodwill .	end
1	For example , based on the existing institutional cultural heritage in the human history , we could see : the " father " system mentioned herein has the majority in mind or it is established in the fundamental and long - term interests of the majority , as well as the need for sustainable and sound development of the country , the nation , and the overall society -- while the " son " system mentioned herein is ignorant and sick in the company of such behavioral characteristics as exploitation , fraudulence , pernicious influence and robbery .	end
1	So , we can not urge the son to throttle the essentially healthy and scientific " father " system by fair mean or foul without considering the consequences , because there are problems in its practice and development -- such as state monopoly for purchases and sales , lower efficiency due to centralized management , and inhibition of the will of productivity by undue political pressure resulting from class struggles during the new deal .	end
1	It is because that will not only make the society increasingly ignorant and sick as it violates the rule of benign social development , distorts normal " human relations " and the ethic and prevalent value and the rule of civilization update rooted in it , but the humanity will retrogress as people 's thoughts and behaviors become increasingly ridiculous .	end
1	Yes , this is the case .	end
1	My opinion above is not absurd and delusive at all , because this is true not only in theory , but also to the rule of social development as demonstrated by historical facts , as well as from the perspective of the situation and reality of the country : None of the current " advocates of market economy , private ownership and dictatorship of the bourgeoisie " has established and proposed a new deal " against planned economy , public ownership and dictatorship of the proletariat . "	end
1	All their criticisms are directed at the developmental symptoms such as " lower efficiency due to centralized management " or " inhibition of the will of productivity by undue political pressure resulting from class struggles during the new deal , " all their proclamations are political attacks and instigation aimed to win over the less than 5 % " vested interests , " and their development logic asks the " 95 % " laboring people to stay where they are and willingly endure the hard work -- it speaks for itself how empty , ridiculous , sick , ignorant and anti-government it is .	less than 5 % ! per ; " 95 % " ! per ;
1	That 's why I want to say to the world and the age by the end of the article : when the father 's toes are injured , we should try our best to treat the foot problem , and open up a new life and embrace health in the principle of respecting human relations , obeying people 's wishes , conforming to science and carrying on the legacy -- if the present capitalist followers frantically urge the son to kill him by all means , the result could only be a tragedy !	end
1	And these happen to be the core of the destiny where the capitalist roaders " will inevitably bury themselves due to their ignorance and insanity , and more or less harm the human society ! "	end
1	At last , I would like to admonish sincerely and earnestly those who blindly oppose , hate and even suppress planned economy , public ownership and dictatorship of the proletariat , especially the " mainstream elite scholars " including Wu Jinglian , who insist on smearing the " father " to the end : do not treat the " fathers " on which the new civilization is based barbarously , against your conscience and frantically for immediate gains .	Wu Jinglian ! person ;
1	The result is definitely a tragedy -- because even if you kill the " father , " your felony will be disdained by the age and condemned by the people , which naturally leads to nothing good !	end
1	Independent economic and human studies analyst .	end

1	Note , this gas price includes all taxes .	end

1	In fact , the gas price difference between the two places is larger than 2 mao and 9 fen because China 's gas price does not include so many taxes as in the US ; for example , the highway maintenance fee in China is paid separately .	two ! num ; 2 mao and 9 fen ! money ; China ! country ; US ! country ; China ! country ;
1	Just now , I only narrated a fact .	end
1	But I believe that different persons see different problems in this fact .	end
1	Let me describe people 's two reactions that I can imagine , or the two problems I can see .	two ! num ; two ! num ;
1	1. The US gas price is too cheap .	1. ! num ; US ! country ;
1	In an absolute sense , the US gas price has +already been cheaper than China 's , and in a relative sense , the US gas price is even cheaper .	US ! country ; China ! country ; US ! country ;
1	In the US , the money you pay for a meal at McDonald 's can fill up more than 10 liters of gas , but in Beijing you can get 5 - 6 liters of gas at most .	US ! country ; McDonald ! org ; 10 liters ! measure ; Beijing ! country ; 5 - 6 liters ! measure ;
1	The US low gas price policy has undoubtedly led to this country 's excessive use of and overdependence on energy resources .	US ! country ;
1	However , there is more to this matter , the whole world has to share the various negative effects caused by the US excessive energy consumption : global warming , and wars caused by oil , etc.	US ! country ;
1	It is totally a joke that the US gas price could be cheaper than China 's .	US ! country ; China ! country ;
1	2. China 's gas price is too expensive .	2. China ! num ;
1	Both Americans and Chinese buy gas from the international market , and the technology and cost of oil refinement are not too much different .	Americans ! national ; Chinese ! national ;
1	But with the US gas price including taxes even lower than China 's gas price excluding taxes , you can see how much money Chinese oil companies have made out of this .	US ! country ; China ! country ; Chinese ! national ;
1	If there are no price controls and monopolies , China 's gas price should n't have been this high .	China ! country ;
1	I want to say that I think these two opinions are both correct .	two ! num ;
1	So , on the issue of oil consumption , I think China and the US , the No. 1 and No. 2 oil consumers in the world , are also a funny pair .	China ! country ; US ! country ; 1 ! num ; 2 ! num ;
1	From a global perspective , the US gas price is obviously too low .	US ! national ;
1	So Mankiw at Harvard even formed a " Pigou Club , " gathering social celebrities who support levying higher taxes on gas prices -LRB- hereby raising gas prices -RRB- .	Mankiw ! person ; Harvard ! org ;
1	China 's gas prices are more complicated .	China ! country ;
1	In fact , gas prices in China are probably not very high , but in order to reduce China 's future overdependence on gas , it may be better that China 's gas prices are higher .	China ! country ; China ! country ; China ! country ;
1	But , the direct result of the gas price increase in China will be the increase of monopoly profits of the monopoly companies .	China ! country ;
1	This part of money will not become the government tax revenue , will not be used for public welfare , and on the contrary , will only make the benefits of those people working at the monopoly department even better .	end
1	In other words , the gas price in China is too high in the distributive sense .	China ! country ;
1	It is the price that transfers the entire social resources to a very small number of people .	end
1	But in terms of sustainability , China 's gas price may still be too low .	China ! country ;
1	We need high gas prices to control the overdependence on energy imports .	end
1	Perhaps someone will condemn me , saying further increase of gas prices will make life unbearable for people .	end
1	If you are a taxi driver , my reply is : the reason your life is unbearable is not the gas price , but because of our taxi licensing regulation system .	end
1	If you are a car owner , my reply is : ride the subway and bus more often .	end
1	It saves money , reduces congestion , and also lets you know car owners are not in a position to say " life is unbearable . "	end
1	Compared with most people , your life is already quite good .	end

1	Interprovincial , Canada 's biggest oil pipeline operator and a major transporter of crude to the U.S. , said revised industry forecasts indicate that Canadian oil output will total about 1.64 million barrels a day by 1991 , 8 % lower than a previous estimate . 1	Canadian crude production averaged about 1.69 million barrels a day during 1989 's first half , about 1 % below the 1988 level .	Canadian ! national ; about 1.69 million barrels ! measure ; 1989 's first half ! date ; about 1 % ! per ; 1988 ! date ;
1	`` The capability of existing fields to deliver oil is dropping , '' and oil exploration activity is also down dramatically , as many producers shift their emphasis to natural gas , said Ronald Watkins , vice president for government and industry relations with Interprovincial 's parent , Interhome Energy Inc . 1	Mr. Watkins said volume on Interprovincial 's system is down about 2 % since January and is expected to fall further , making expansion unnecessary until perhaps the mid-1990s .	Watkins ! person ; Interprovincial ! org ; about 2 % ! per ; January ! date ; mid-1990s ! date ;
1	`` There has been a swing of the pendulum back to the gas side , '' he said .	end
1	Many of Canada 's oil and gas producers say the outlook for natural gas is better than it is for oil , and have shifted their exploration and development budgets accordingly .	Canada ! country ;
1	The number of active drilling rigs in Canada is down 30 % from a year ago , and the number of completed oil wells is `` down more than that , due to the increasing focus on gas exploration , '' said Robert Feick , manager of crude oil with Calgary 's Independent Petroleum Association of Canada , an industry group . 1	Mr. Watkins said the main reason for the production decline is shrinking output of light crude from mature , conventional fields in western Canada .	Watkins ! person ; Canada ! country ;
1	Interprovincial transports about 75 % of all crude produced in western Canada , and almost 60 % of Interprovincial 's total volume consists of light crude .	Interprovincial ! org ; about 75 % ! per ; Canada ! country ; almost 60 % ! per ; Interprovincial ! org ;

1	The deficit reduction bill contains $ 5.3 billion in tax increases in fiscal 1990 , and $ 26 billion over five years .	$ 5.3 billion ! money ; fiscal 1990 ! date ; $ 26 billion ! money ; five years ! date ;
1	The revenue - raising provisions , which affect mostly corporations , would :	end
1	-- Prevent companies that have made leveraged buy - outs from getting federal tax refunds resulting from losses caused by interest payments on debt issued to finance the buy - outs , effective Aug. 2 , 1989 .	Aug. 2 , 1989 ! date ;

1	-- Close a loophole regarding employee stock ownership plans , effective June 6 , 1989 , that has been exploited by investment bankers in corporate takeovers .	June 6 , 1989 ! date ;
1	The measure repeals a 50 % exclusion given to banks on the interest from loans used to acquire securities for an ESOP , if the ESOP owns less than 30 % of the employer 's stock .	50 % ! per ; less than 30 % ! per ;
1	-- Curb junk bonds by ending tax benefits for certain securities , such as zero - coupon bonds , that postpone cash interest payments .	zero ! num ;
1	-- Raise $ 851 million by suspending for one year an automatic reduction in airport and airway taxes .	$ 851 million ! money ; one year ! date ;
1	-- Speed up the collection of the payroll tax from large companies , effective August 1990 .	August 1990 ! date ;
1	-- Impose a tax on ozone - depleting chemicals , such as those used in air conditioners and in Styrofoam , beginning at $ 1.10 a pound starting next year .	1.10 ! money ; next year ! date ;
1	-- Withhold income taxes from the paychecks of certain farm workers currently exempt from withholding .	end

1	I thought your editorial was factually accurate and deliberately elucidative .	end
1	2 . That Mr. Lantos supported the rights of the witnesses to take the Fifth Amendment .	2 ! num ; Lantos ! person ; the Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	Yes , he did .	end
1	As I watched him on C - Span , I heard him speak those lovely words about the Bill of Rights , which he quotes from the transcript of the hearings .	C - Span ! org ; the Bill of Rights ! law ;
1	He did repeat those nice platitudes several times as an indication of his support for the Constitution .	Constitution ! law ;
1	He used about 56 words defending the witnesses ' constitutional rights .	about 56 ! num ;
1	Unfortunately , by my rough guess , he used better than 5,000 words heaping scorn on the witnesses for exercising the Fifth .	5,000 ! num ; Fifth ! law ;
1	He sandwiched his praise of constitutional meat between large loaves of bilious commentary .	end
1	As your editorial rightly pointed out , Samuel Pierce , former HUD secretary , and Lance Wilson , Mr. Pierce 's former aide , `` are currently being held up to scorn for taking the Fifth Amendment .	Samuel Pierce ! person ; HUD ! org ; Lance Wilson ! person ; Pierce ! person ; the Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	'' That certainly is not the supposed `` distorted reading '' indicated by Mr. Lantos .	Lantos ! person ;
1	3 . That his `` committee does not deal with any possible criminal activity at HUD .	3 ! num ; HUD ! org ;
1	My colleagues and I fully realize we are not a court ... etc . ''	end
1	Absolute rubbish .	end
1	By any `` reasonable man '' criterion , Mr. Lantos and his colleagues have a whole bunch of people tried and convicted .	Lantos ! person ;
1	Apparently , their verdict is in .	end
1	Right now they 're pursuing evidence .	end
1	That 's not a bad way to proceed , just somewhat different from standard American practice .	American ! national ;
1	How was that practice referred to when I was in school ?	end
1	Ah , yes , something called a Star Chamber .	a Star Chamber ! org ;
1	Of course , Mr. Lantos doth protest that his subcommittee simply seeks information for legislative change .	Lantos ! person ;
1	No doubt that 's partially true .	end

1	No , Mr. Lantos 's complaints simply wo n't wash .	Lantos ! person ;

Journal ! org ; Lantos ! person ; Congress ! org ;
1	-LRB- Of course , we 've also got a judiciary that seeks the same objective . -RRB-	end
