1	I do not by any means defend HUD management .	HUD ! org ;
1	But I think the kind of congressional investigation that has been pursued is a far greater danger to American notions of liberty and freedom than any incompetency -LRB- and , yes , maybe criminality -RRB- within HUD could possibly generate .	American ! national ; HUD ! org ;
1	The last time I saw a similar congressional hearing was when `` Tail Gunner Joe '' McCarthy did his work .	`` Tail Gunner Joe '' McCarthy ! person ;
1	Raymond Weber	Raymond Weber ! person ;
1	Parsippany , N.J .	Parsippany ! country ; N.J . ! country ;
1	I disagree with the statement by Mr. Lantos that one should not draw an adverse inference against former HUD officials who assert their Fifth Amendment privilege against self - incrimination in congressional hearings .	Lantos ! person ; HUD ! org ; Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	The Fifth Amendment states in relevant part that no person `` shall be compelled , in any criminal case , to be a witness against himself . ''	The Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	This privilege against self - incrimination precludes the drawing of an adverse inference against a criminal defendant who chooses not to testify .	end
1	Thus , in a criminal case , a prosecutor can not comment on a defendant 's failure to testify nor can the defendant be compelled to take the stand as a witness , thus forcing him to `` take the Fifth . ''	Fifth ! law ;
1	The privilege , however , has been limited in accordance with its plain language to protect the defendant in criminal matters only .	end
1	The Supreme Court and some states have specifically recognized that `` the Fifth Amendment does not preclude the inference where the privilege is claimed by a party to a civil cause . ''	The Supreme Court ! org ; the Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	Baxter v. Palmingiano , 425 U.S. 308 -LRB- 1976 -RRB- .	Baxter ! person ; Palmingiano ! person ; 425 U.S. 308 ! law ; 1976 ! date ;
1	Thus , in a civil case , a defendant may be called as a witness , he may be forced to testify or take the Fifth , and his taking of the Fifth may permit the drawing of an adverse inference against him in the civil matter .	Fifth ! law ; Fifth ! law ;
1	He may take the Fifth in a civil matter only if he has a good faith and justifiable belief that his testimony may subject him to criminal prosecution .	Fifth ! law ;
1	Allowing the defendant to take the Fifth in a civil matter is not based on a constitutional right to refuse to testify where one 's testimony harms him in the civil matter , but because the testimony in the civil matter could be unconstitutionally used against him in a subsequent criminal prosecution .	Fifth ! law ;
1	Absent the risk of such prosecution , a court may order the defendant to testify .	end
1	Thus , when Mr. Pierce asserted the Fifth in a noncriminal proceeding , particularly after presumably receiving extensive advice from legal counsel , one must conclude that he held a good - faith , justifiable belief that his testimony could be used against him in a subsequent criminal prosecution .	Pierce ! person ; Fifth ! law ; one ! num ;
1	The subcommittee , Congress and the American public have every right to draw the adverse inference and to concur with Mr. Pierce 's own belief that his testimony could help convict him of a crime .	Congress ! org ; American ! national ; Pierce ! person ;
1	Drawing the adverse inference in a noncriminal congressional hearing does not offend the Fifth Amendment shield against self - incrimination .	Fifth Amendment ! law ;
1	Clark S. Spalsbury Jr .	Clark S. Spalsbury Jr . ! person ;
1	Estes Park , Colo .	Estes Park ! country ; Colo ! country ;

1	With economic tension between the U.S. and Japan worsening , many Japanese had feared last week 's visit from U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills .	U.S. ! country ; Japan ! country ; Japanese ! national ; last week 's ! date ; U.S. ! country ; Carla Hills ! person ;
1	They expected a new barrage of demands that Japan do something quickly to reduce its trade surplus with the U.S. .	Japan ! country ; U.S. ! country ;
1	Instead , they got a discussion of the need for the U.S. and Japan to work together and of the importance of the long - term view .	U.S. ! country ; Japan ! country ;
1	Mrs. Hills ' first trip to Japan as America 's chief trade negotiator had a completely different tone from last month 's visit by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher .	Hills ! person ; first ! order ; Japan ! country ; America ! country ; last month 's ! date ; Commerce ! org ; Robert A. Mosbacher ! person ;
1	Mr. Mosbacher called for concrete results by next spring in negotiations over fundamental Japanese business practices that supposedly inhibit free trade .	Mosbacher ! person ; next spring ! date ; Japanese ! national ;
1	He said such results should be `` measurable in dollars and cents '' in reducing the U.S. trade deficit with Japan .	U.S. ! country ; Japan ! country ;
1	But Mrs. Hills , speaking at a breakfast meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan on Saturday , stressed that the objective `` is not to get definitive action by spring or summer , it is rather to have a blueprint for action . ''	Hills ! person ; the American Chamber of Commerce ! org ; Japan ! country ; Saturday ! date ; spring ! date ; summer ! date ;
1	She added that she expected `` perhaps to have a down payment ... some small step to convince the American people and the Japanese people that we 're moving in earnest . ''	American ! national ; Japanese ! national ;
1	How such remarks translate into policy wo n't become clear for months .	months ! date ;
1	American and Japanese officials offered several theories for the difference in approach betwen Mr. Mosbacher and Mrs. Hills .	American ! national ; Japanese ! national ; Mosbacher ! person ; Hills ! person ;
1	Many called it simply a contrast in styles .	end
1	But some saw it as a classic negotiating tactic .	end
1	Others said the Bush administration may feel the rhetoric on both sides is getting out of hand .	Bush ! person ;
1	And some said it reflected the growing debate in Washington over pursuing free trade with Japan versus some kind of managed trade .	Washington ! country ; Japan ! country ;

1	Yet more than one American official who sat in with her during three days of talks with Japanese officials said her tone often was surprisingly `` conciliatory . ''	more than one American ! num ; three days ! national ; Japanese ! date ;

1	I do n't feel either hard or soft .	end

1	Population Drain Ends For Midwestern States	end
1	IOWA IS MAKING a comeback .	IOWA ! country ;
1	So are Indiana , Ohio and Michigan .	Indiana ! country ; Ohio ! country ; Michigan ! country ;
1	The population of all four states is on the upswing , according to new Census Bureau estimates , following declines throughout the early 1980s .	four ! num ; Census Bureau ! org ; the early 1980s ! date ;
1	The gains , to be sure , are rather small .	end
1	Iowa , for instance , saw its population grow by 11,000 people , or 0.4 % , between 1987 and 1988 , the Census Bureau says .	Iowa ! country ; 11,000 ! num ; 0.4 % ! per ; between 1987 and 1988 ! date ; the Census Bureau ! org ;
1	Still , even that modest increase is good news for a state that had n't grown at all since 1981 .	1981 ! date ;
1	Between 1987 and 1988 , North Dakota was the only state in the Midwest to lose population , a loss of 4,000 people .	Between 1987 and 1988 ! date ; North Dakota ! country ; Midwest ! location ; 4,000 ! num ;
1	Six of the 12 midwestern states have been growing steadily since 1980 -- Illinois , Kansas , Minnesota , Missouri , South Dakota and Wisconsin .	Six ! num ; 12 ! num ; 1980 ! date ; Illinois ! country ; Kansas ! country ; Minnesota ! country ; Missouri ! country ; South Dakota ! country ; Wisconsin ! country ;
1	The Northeast has been holding its own in the population race .	Northeast ! location ;
1	Seven of nine states have grown each year since 1980 , including New York , which lost 4 % of its population during the 1970s .	Seven ! num ; nine ! num ; each year ! date ; 1980 ! date ; New York ! country ; 4 % ! per ; the 1970s ! date ;
1	And although Pennsylvania and Massachusetts suffered slight declines earlier in the decade , they are growing again .	Pennsylvania ! country ; Massachusetts ! country ; the decade ! date ;
1	At the same time , several states in the South and West have had their own population turnaround .	South ! location ; West ! location ;
1	Seven states that grew in the early 1980s are now losing population -- West Virginia , Mississippi , Louisiana , Oklahoma , Montana , Wyoming and Alaska .	Seven ! num ; the early 1980s ! date ; West Virginia ! country ; Mississippi ! country ; Louisiana ! country ; Oklahoma ! country ; Montana ! country ; Wyoming ! country ; Alaska ! country ;
1	Overall , though , the South and West still outpace the Northeast and Midwest , and fast - growing states like Florida and California ensure that the pattern will continue .	South ! location ; West ! location ; Northeast ! location ; Midwest ! location ; Florida ! country ; California ! country ;
1	But the growth gap between the Sun Belt and other regions has clearly started narrowing .	the Sun Belt ! location ;
1	More Elderly Maintain Their Independence	end
1	THANKS TO modern medicine , more couples are growing old together .	end
1	And even after losing a spouse , more of the elderly are staying independent .	end
1	A new Census Bureau study of the noninstitutionalized population shows that 64 % of people aged 65 to 74 were living with a spouse in 1988 , up from 59 % in 1970 .	Census Bureau ! org ; 64 % ! per ; aged 65 to 74 ! date ; 1988 ! date ; 59 % ! per ; 1970 ! date ;
1	This does n't mean they 're less likely to live alone , however .	end
1	That share has remained at about 24 % since 1970 .	about 24 % ! per ; 1970 ! date ;
1	What has changed is that more of the young elderly are living with spouses rather than with other relatives , such as children .	end
1	In 1988 , 10 % of those aged 65 to 74 lived with relatives other than spouses , down from 15 % in 1970 .	1988 ! date ; 10 % ! per ; aged 65 to 74 lived ! date ; 15 % ! per ; 1970 ! date ;
1	As people get even older , many become widowed .	end
1	But even among those aged 75 and older , the share living with a spouse rose slightly , to 40 % in 1988 from 38 % in 1970 .	aged 75 and older ! date ; 40 % ! per ; 1988 ! date ; 38 % ! per ; 1970 ! date ;
1	Like their younger counterparts , the older elderly are less likely to live with other relatives .	end
1	Only 17 % of those aged 75 and older lived with relatives other than spouses in 1988 , down from 26 % in 1970 .	Only 17 % ! per ; aged 75 and older ! date ; 1988 ! date ; 26 % ! per ; 1970 ! date ;
1	The likelihood of living alone beyond the age of 75 has increased to 40 % from 32 % .	the age of 75 ! date ; 40 % ! per ; 32 % ! per ;
1	More people are remaining independent longer presumably because they are better off physically and financially .	end
1	Careers Count Most For the Well - to - Do	end
1	MANY AFFLUENT people place personal success and money above family .	end
1	At least that 's what a survey by Ernst & Young and Yankelovich , Clancy , Shulman indicates .	Ernst & Young ! org ; Yankelovich , Clancy , Shulman ! org ;
1	Two - thirds of respondents said they strongly felt the need to be successful in their jobs , while fewer than half said they strongly felt the need to spend more time with their families .	Two - thirds ! num ; fewer than half ! num ;
1	Being successful in careers and spending the money they make are top priorities for this group .	end
1	Unlike most studies of the affluent market , this survey excluded the super-rich .	end
1	Average household income for the sample was $ 194,000 , and average net assets were reported as $ 775,000 .	194,000 ! money ; 775,000 ! money ;
1	The goal was to learn about one of today 's fastest - growing income groups , the upper - middle class .	one ! num ; today ! date ;
1	Although they represent only 2 % of the population , they control nearly one - third of discretionary income .	only 2 % ! per ; nearly one - third ! num ;
1	Across the board , these consumers value quality , buy what they like rather than just what they need , and appreciate products that are distinctive .	end
1	Despite their considerable incomes and assets , 40 % of the respondents in the study do n't feel financially secure , and one - fourth do n't feel that they have made it .	40 % ! per ; one - fourth ! num ;
1	Twenty percent do n't even feel they are financially well off .	Twenty percent ! per ;
1	Many of the affluent are n't comfortable with themselves , either .	end
1	About 40 % do n't feel they 're more able than others .	About 40 % ! per ;
1	While twothirds feel some guilt about being affluent , only 25 % give $ 2,500 or more to charity each year .	twothirds ! num ; only 25 % ! per ; 2,500 ! money ; each year ! date ;
1	Thirty - five percent attend religious services regularly ; at the same time , 60 % feel that in life one sometimes has to compromise one 's principles .	Thirty - five percent ! per ; 60 % ! per ;

1	When the news broke of an attempted coup in Panama two weeks ago , Sen. Christopher Dodd called the State Department for a briefing .	Panama two weeks ago ! country ; Christopher Dodd ! date ; the State Department ! person ;
1	`` They said , ` follow CNN , ' '' he told reporters .	CNN ! org ;
1	That shows how far Ted Turner 's Cable News Network has come since its birth nine years ago , when it was considered the laughingstock of television news .	Ted Turner 's Cable News Network ! person ; nine years ago ! org ;
1	It is bigger , faster and more profitable than the news divisions of any of the three major broadcast networks .	three ! num ;
1	Its niche as the `` network of record '' during major crises draws elite audiences around the world .	end
1	But for all its success , CNN has hit a plateau .	CNN ! org ;
1	Although viewership soars when big news breaks , it ebbs during periods of calm .	end
1	CNN executives worry that the network 's punchy but repetitive news format may be getting stale and wo n't keep viewers coming back as the alternatives multiply for news and information on cable - TV .	CNN ! org ;
1	`` Just the fact we 're on 24 hours is no longer bulletin , '' says Ed Turner , CNN 's executive vice president , news gathering -LRB- and no relation to Ted Turner -RRB- .	24 hours ! time ; Ed Turner ! person ; CNN ! org ; Ted Turner ! person ;
1	`` You ca n't live on that . ''	end
1	So CNN , a unit of Atlanta - based Turner Broadcasting System Inc. , is trying to reposition itself as a primary channel , or what people in the television industry call a `` top of mind '' network .	CNN ! org ; Atlanta ! country ; Turner Broadcasting System Inc. ! org ;
1	Tonight , to kick off the effort , CNN will premiere its first prime - time newscast in years , an hourlong show at 6 p.m . Eastern time to air head - to - head against the network newscasts .	Tonight ! time ; CNN ! org ; first ! order ; years ! date ; hourlong ! time ; 6 p.m . Eastern time ! time ;
1	The show will be co-anchored by Bernard Shaw and Catherine Crier , a 34 - year - old former Texas judge and campus beauty queen who has never held a job in television or journalism .	Bernard Shaw ! person ; Catherine Crier ! person ; 34 - year - old ! date ; Texas ! country ;
1	The new show is perhaps the boldest in a number of steps the network is taking to build audience loyalty by shifting away from its current format toward more full - length `` signature '' programming with recognizable stars .	end
1	To distinguish itself , CNN is also expanding international coverage and adding a second global - news program .	CNN ! org ; second ! order ;
1	It is paying higher salaries -- after years of scrimping -- to lure and keep experienced staffers .	years ! date ;
1	And it is embarking on an expensive gamble to break major stories with a large investigative - reporting team .	end
1	`` The next stage is to get beyond the opinion leaders who use us as a point of reference to become a point of reference at ordinary dinner tables , '' says Jon Petrovich , executive vice president of Headline News , CNN 's sister network .	Jon Petrovich ! person ; Headline News ! org ; CNN ! org ;
1	But that wo n't be easy .	end
1	Networks , like other consumer products , develop images in peoples ' minds that are n't easy to change .	end
1	It also takes money that CNN has been reluctant to spend to make programs and hire talent that viewers will tune in specially to see .	CNN ! org ;
1	And the cable - TV operators -- CNN 's distributors and part owners -- like things just the way they are .	CNN ! org ;
1	The repositioning bid is aimed at CNN 's unsteady viewership -- and what may happen to it as the cable - TV news market grows more competitive .	CNN ! org ;
1	Already , CNN is facing stronger competition from Financial News Network Inc. and General Electric Co. 's Consumer News and Business Channel , both of which are likely to pursue more general news in the future .	CNN ! org ; Financial News Network Inc. ! org ; General Electric Co. 's Consumer News ! org ; Business Channel ! org ;
1	In addition , many cable - TV systems themselves are airing more local and regional news programs produced by local broadcast stations .	end
1	CNN wants to change its viewers ' habits .	CNN ! org ;
1	Its watchers are , on the whole , a disloyal group of channel - zapping `` grazers '' and news junkies , who spend an average of just 26 minutes a day watching CNN , according to audience research .	just 26 minutes ! time ; CNN ! org ;
1	That 's less than one - third the time that viewers watch the major broadcast networks .	less than one - third ! num ;
1	The brief attention viewers give CNN could put it at a disadvantage as ratings data , and advertising , become more important to cable - TV channels .	CNN ! org ;
1	CNN 's viewer habits have been molded by its format .	CNN ! org ;
1	Its strategy in the past has been to serve as a TV wire service .	end
1	It focused on building up its news bureaus around the world , so as events took place it could go live quicker and longer than other networks .	end
1	It filled its daily schedule with newscasts called `` Daybreak , '' `` Daywatch , '' `` Newsday , '' and `` Newsnight , '' but the shows varied little in content , personality or look .	daily ! date ; Daybreak ! art ; Daywatch ! art ; Newsday ! art ; Newsnight ! art ;
1	Now , the push is on for more - distinctive shows .	end
1	`` Our goal is to create more programs with an individual identity , '' says Paul Amos , CNN executive vice president for programming .	Paul Amos ! person ; CNN ! org ;
1	Accordingly , CNN is adding a world - affairs show in the morning because surveys show its global - news hour in the afternoon is among its most `` differentiated '' programs in viewers ' minds , says Mr. Amos .	CNN ! org ; the morning ! time ; its global - news hour ! time ; the afternoon ! time ; Amos ! person ;
1	And it is exploring other original programs , similar to its `` Larry King Live '' and `` Crossfire '' talk shows , which executives hope will keep people tuned in .	Larry King Live ! art ; Crossfire ! art ;

1	John Kenneth Galbraith .	John Kenneth Galbraith . ! person ;
1	`` This is the latest manifestation of the capacity of the financial community for recurrent insanity , '' says Mr. Galbraith , an economist .	Galbraith ! person ;
1	`` I see this as a reaction to the whole junk bond explosion , '' he says .	end
1	`` The explosion of junk bonds and takeovers has lodged a lot of insecure securities in the hands of investors and loaded the corporations that are the objects of takeovers or feared takeovers with huge amounts of debt rather than equity .	end
1	This has both made investors uneasy and the corporations more vulnerable . ''	end
1	Nevertheless , he says a depression does n't appear likely .	end
1	`` There is more resiliency in the economy at large than we commonly suppose , '' he says .	end
1	`` It takes more error now to have a major depression than back in the Thirties -- much as the financial community and the government may try . ''	Thirties ! date ;

1	Just a coincidence ?	end
1	Or is triskaidekaphobia -- fear of the number 13 -- justified ?	13 ! num ;
1	In academia , a so - called Friday the 13th effect has been set up and shot down by different professors .	Friday the 13th ! date ;
1	Robert Kolb and Ricardo Rodriguez , professors of finance at the University of Miami , found evidence that the market is spooked by Friday the 13th .	Robert Kolb ! person ; Ricardo Rodriguez ! person ; the University of Miami ! org ; Friday the 13th ! date ;
1	But their study , which spanned the 1962 - 85 period , has since been shown to be jinxed by an unlucky choice of data .	1962 - 85 ! date ;
1	In the '70s , the market took falls nine times in a row on Friday the you - know - what .	the '70s ! date ; nine ! num ; Friday the you - know - what ! date ;
1	But the date tends to be a plus , not a minus , for stocks , according to Yale Hirsch , a collector of stock market lore .	Yale Hirsch ! person ;
1	Another study found that the 82 Fridays the 13th in the 1940 - 1987 period had higher than average returns -- higher even than Fridays in general , which tend to be strong days for stock prices .	82 Fridays the 13th ! num ; 1940 - 1987 ! date ; Fridays ! date ; days ! date ;
1	On the only other Friday the 13th this year , the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose about four points .	the only other Friday the 13th this year ! date ; about four ! num ;

1	Investors who bought stock with borrowed money -- that is , `` on margin '' -- may be more worried than most following Friday 's market drop .	Friday ! date ;
1	That 's because their brokers can require them to sell some shares or put up more cash to enhance the collateral backing their loans .	end
1	In October 1987 , these margin calls were thought to have contributed to the downward spiral of the stock market .	October 1987 ! date ;
1	Typically , a margin call occurs when the price of a stock falls below 75 % of its original value .	75 % ! per ;
1	If the investor does n't put up the extra cash to satisfy the call , the brokerage firm may begin liquidating the securities .	end
1	But some big brokerage firms said they do n't expect major problems as a result of margin calls .	end
1	Margin calls since Friday `` have been higher than usual , but reasonable , '' a spokesman for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said .	Friday ! date ; Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ! org ;
1	Merrill Lynch & Co. officials `` do n't expect -LCB- margin calls -RCB- to be as big a factor as in 1987 '' because fewer individual investors are buying stock on margin , a spokesman said .	Merrill Lynch & Co. ! org ; 1987 ! date ;

1	The fundamental rule of contract law applied to both cases was that courts will not enforce agreements to which the parties did not intend to be bound .	end
1	In the Pennzoil / Texaco litigation , the courts found Pennzoil and Getty Oil intended to be bound ; in Arcadian Phosphates they found there was no intention to be bound .	Pennzoil ! org ; Pennzoil ! org ; Getty Oil ! org ; Arcadian Phosphates ! org ;

1	All year , energy prices have skewed the producer price index , which measures changes in the prices producers receive for goods .	All year ! date ;

1	A Canadian bank bought another thrift , in the first RTC transaction with a foreign bank .	Canadian ! national ; RTC ! org ;
1	Under these deals , the RTC sells just the deposits and the healthy assets .	RTC ! org ;
1	These `` clean - bank '' transactions leave the bulk of bad assets , mostly real estate , with the government , to be sold later .	end
1	In these four , for instance , the RTC is stuck with $ 4.51 billion in bad assets .	four ! num ; RTC ! org ; $ 4.51 billion ! money ;

1	Not only is Mr. Mason the star of `` Chicken Soup , '' he 's also the inheritor of a comedic tradition dating back to `` Duck Soup , '' and he 's currently a man in hot water .	Mason ! person ; Chicken Soup ! art ; Duck Soup ! art ;
1	Here , in neutral language , is the gist of Mr. Mason 's remarks , quoted first in the Village Voice while he was a paid spokesman for the Rudolph Giuliani mayoral campaign , and then in Newsweek after he and the campaign parted company .	Mason ! person ; first ! order ; the Village Voice ! org ; Rudolph Giuliani ! person ; Newsweek ! org ;
1	Mr. Mason said that many Jewish voters feel guilty toward blacks , so they support black candidates uncritically .	Mason ! person ; Jewish ! national ;
1	He said that many black voters feel bitter about racial discrimination , so they , too , support black candidates uncritically .	end
1	He said that Jews have contributed more to black causes over the years than vice versa .	Jews ! national ; the years ! date ;
1	Of course , Mr. Mason did not use neutral language .	Mason ! person ;
1	As a practitioner of ethnic humor from the old days on the Borscht Belt , live television and the nightclub circuit , Mr. Mason instinctively reached for the vernacular .	the old days ! date ; the Borscht Belt ! location ; Mason ! person ;

1	It probably would , because few or none of the people upset by Mr. Mason 's remarks have bothered to distinguish between the substance of his comments and the fact that he used insulting language .	Mason ! person ;
1	In addition , some of Mr. Mason 's critics have implied that his type of ethnic humor is itself a form of racism .	Mason ! person ;
1	For example , the New York state counsel for the NAACP said that Mr. Mason is `` like a dinosaur .	New York ! country ; NAACP ! org ; Mason ! person ;
1	People are fast leaving the place where he is stuck . ''	end
1	These critics fail to distinguish between the type of ethnic humor that aims at disparaging another group , such as `` Polish jokes '' ; and the type that is double - edged , aiming inward as well as outward .	Polish ! national ;
1	The latter typically is the humor of the underdog , and it was perfected by both blacks and Jews on the minstrel and vaudeville stage as a means of mocking their white and gentile audiences along with themselves .	Jews ! national ;
1	In the hands of a zealot like Lenny Bruce , this double - edged blade could cut both the self and the audience to ribbons .	Lenny Bruce ! person ;
1	But wielded by a pro like Jackie Mason , it is a constructive form of mischief .	Jackie Mason ! person ;
1	Why constructive ?	end
1	Because despite all the media prattle about comedy and politics not mixing , they are similar in one respect : Both can serve as mechanisms for easing tensions and facilitating the co-existence of groups in conflict .	one ! num ;
1	That 's why it 's dangerous to have well - intentioned thought police , on college campuses and elsewhere , taboo all critical mention of group differences .	end
1	As Elizabeth Kristol wrote in the New York Times just before the Mason donnybrook , `` Perhaps intolerance would not boil over with such intensity if honest differences were allowed to simmer . ''	Elizabeth Kristol ! person ; the New York Times ! org ; Mason ! person ;
1	The question is , if group conflicts still exist -LRB- as undeniably they do -RRB- , and if Mr. Mason 's type of ethnic humor is passe , then what other means do we have for letting off steam ?	Mason ! person ;
1	Do n't say the TV sitcom , because that happens to be a genre that , in its desperate need to attract everybody and offend nobody , resembles politics more than it does comedy .	end
1	It is true that the best sitcoms do allow group differences to simmer : yuppies vs. blue - collar Bostonians in `` Cheers '' ; children vs. adults in `` The Cosby Show . ''	Bostonians ! national ; Cheers ! art ; The Cosby Show ! art ;
1	But these are not the differences that make headlines .	end
1	In `` Chicken Soup , '' Mr. Mason plays Jackie , a Jewish bachelor courting Maddie -LRB- Lynn Redgrave -RRB- , an Irish widow and mother of three , against the wishes of his mother -LRB- Rita Karin -RRB- and her brother Michael -LRB- Brandon Maggart -RRB- .	Chicken Soup ! art ; Mason ! person ; Jackie ! person ; Jewish ! national ; Maddie -LRB- Lynn Redgrave -RRB- ! person ; Irish ! person ; three ! national ; Rita Karin ! num ; Michael ! person ; Brandon Maggart ! person ;
1	It 's worth noting that both disapproving relatives are immigrants .	end
1	At least , they both speak with strong accents , as do Jackie and Maddie .	Jackie ! person ; Maddie ! person ;
1	It could n't be more obvious that `` Chicken Soup '' is being made from an old recipe .	Chicken Soup ! art ;
1	And a safe one -- imagine if the romance in question were between an Orthodox Jew and a member of the Nation of Islam .	an Orthodox Jew ! national ; the Nation of Islam ! national ;
1	Back in the 1920s , the play and movie versions of `` Abie 's Irish Rose '' made the theme of courtship between the assimilated offspring of Jewish and Irish immigrants so popular that its author , Anne Nichols , lost a plagiarism suit on the grounds that the plot has entered the public domain .	the 1920s ! date ; Abie 's Irish Rose ! art ; Jewish ! national ; Irish ! national ; Anne Nichols ! person ;
1	And it has remained there , as evidenced by its reappearance in a 1972 CBS sitcom called `` Bridget Loves Bernie , '' whose sole distinction was that it led to the real - life marriage of Meredith Baxter and David Birney .	1972 CBS ! date ; Bridget Loves Bernie ! org ; Meredith Baxter ! art ; David Birney ! person ;
1	Clearly , the question with `` Chicken Soup '' is not whether the pot will boil over , but whether it will simmer at all .	Chicken Soup ! art ;
1	So far , the bubbles have been few and far between .	end
1	Part of the problem is the tendency of all sitcoms , ever since the didactic days of Norman Lear , to preach about social issues .	the didactic days ! date ; Norman Lear ! person ;
1	To some extent , this tendency emerges whenever the show tries to enlighten us about ethnic stereotypes by reversing them .	end
1	For instance , Michael dislikes Jackie not because he 's a shrewd Jewish businessman , but because he quits his well - paying job as a salesman in order to become a social worker .	Michael ! person ; Jackie ! person ; Jewish ! national ;
1	Even more problematic is the incompatibility between sitcom preachiness and Mr. Mason 's comic persona .	Mason ! person ;
1	The best moments in the show occur at the beginning and the end -LRB- and occasionally in the middle -RRB- , when Mr. Mason slips into his standup mode and starts meting out that old - fashioned Jewish mischief to other people as well as to himself .	Mason ! person ; Jewish ! national ;
1	But too often , these routines lack spark because this sitcom , like all sitcoms , is timid about confronting Mr. Mason 's stock in trade - ethnic differences .	Mason ! person ;
1	I 'm not suggesting that the producers start putting together episodes about topics like the Catholic - Jewish dispute over the Carmelite convent at Auschwitz .	Catholic ! national ; Carmelite ! national ; Auschwitz ! fact ;
1	That issue , like racial tensions in New York City , will have to cool down , not heat up , before it can simmer .	New York City ! country ;
1	But I am suggesting that they stop requiring Mr. Mason to interrupt his classic shtik with some line about `` caring for other people '' that would sound shmaltzy on the lips of Miss America .	Mason ! person ; Miss America ! person ;
1	At your age , Jackie , you ought to know that you ca n't make soup without turning up the flame .	Jackie ! person ;
1	Gulf Resources & Chemical Corp. said it agreed to pay $ 1.5 million as part of an accord with the Environmental Protection Agency regarding an environmental cleanup of a defunct smelter the company formerly operated in Idaho .	Gulf Resources & Chemical Corp. ! org ; $ 1.5 million ! money ; the Environmental Protection Agency ! org ; Idaho ! country ;
1	In 1984 the EPA notified Gulf Resources , which was a part - owner of the smelter , that it was potentially liable for sharing cleanup costs at the site under the federal Superfund program .	1984 ! date ; EPA ! org ; Gulf Resources ! org ; Superfund ! org ;
1	The 21 - square - mile area is contaminated with lead , zinc and other metals .	21 - square - mile ! measure ;
1	Gulf Resources earlier this year proposed a reorganization plan that would make it a unit of a Bermuda concern , potentially exempting it from liability for the smelter 's cleanup costs .	Gulf Resources earlier this year ! org ; Bermuda ! date ;
1	The company said that as part of its agreement with the EPA , it `` made certain voluntary undertakings with respect to intercorporate transactions entered into after the reorganization . ''	EPA ! org ;
1	The company , which issued a statement on the agreement late Friday , said that $ 1 million of the payment was previously provided for in its financial statements and that $ 500,000 will be recognized in its 1989 third - quarter statement .	late Friday ! date ; $ 1 million ! money ; 500,000 ! money ; 1989 third - quarter ! date ;
1	The agreement and consent decree are subject to court approval , the company said .	end
1	Gulf Resources added that it `` will seek to recover equitable contribution from others for both the amount of the settlement and any other liabilities it may incur under the Superfund law . ''	Gulf Resources ! org ; Superfund ! org ;
1	Under the agreement , Gulf must give the U.S. government 45 days ' advance written notice before issuing any dividends on common stock .	Gulf ! org ; U.S. ! country ; 45 days ' ! date ;
1	The company 's net worth can not fall below $ 185 million after the dividends are issued .	$ 185 million ! money ;
1	`` The terms of that agreement only become effective the date of Gulf 's reorganization , which we anticipate will occur sometime in early 1990 , '' said Lawrence R. Mehl , Gulf 's general counsel .	the date ! date ; Gulf ! org ; early 1990 ! date ; Lawrence R. Mehl ! person ; Gulf ! org ;
1	In addition , Gulf must give the government 20 days ' advance written notice of any loans exceeding $ 50 million that are made to the Bermuda - based holding company .	Gulf ! org ; 20 days ' ! date ; $ 50 million ! money ; Bermuda ! country ;
1	Gulf 's net worth after those transaction must be at least $ 150 million .	Gulf ! org ; at least $ 150 million ! money ;
1	Separately , the company said it expects to hold a special meeting for shareholders in early 1990 to vote on its proposed reorganization .	early 1990 ! date ;

1	Time magazine , in a move to reduce the costs of wooing new subscribers , is lowering its circulation guarantee to advertisers for the second consecutive year , increasing its subscription rates and cutting back on merchandise giveaways .	Time ! org ; the second consecutive year ! date ;
1	In an announcement to its staff last week , executives at Time Warner Inc. 's weekly magazine said Time will `` dramatically de-emphasize '' its use of electronic giveaways such as telephones in television subscription drives ; cut the circulation it guarantees advertisers by 300,000 , to four million ; and increase the cost of its annual subscription rate by about $ 4 to $ 55 .	last week ! date ; Time Warner Inc. 's weekly ! org ; Time ! date ; 300,000 ! org ; four million ! num ; annual ! num ; about $ 4 to $ 55 ! date ;
1	In a related development , the news - weekly , for the fourth year in a row , said it wo n't increase its advertising rates in 1990 ; a full , four - color page in the magazine costs about $ 120,000 .	the fourth year ! date ; 1990 ! date ; four ! num ; about $ 120,000 ! money ;
1	However , because the guaranteed circulation base is being lowered , ad rates will be effectively 7.5 % higher per subscriber , according to Richard Heinemann , Time associate publisher .	7.5 % ! per ; Richard Heinemann ! person ; Time ! org ;
1	Time is following the course of some other mass - circulation magazines that in recent years have challenged the publishing myth that maintaining artificially high , and expensive , circulations is the way to draw advertisers .	Time ! org ; recent years ! date ;
1	In recent years , Reader 's Digest , New York Times Co. 's McCall 's , and most recently News Corp. 's TV Guide , have cut their massive circulation rate bases to eliminate marginal circulation and hold down rates for advertisers .	recent years ! date ; Reader 's Digest ! org ; New York Times Co. 's McCall ! org ; News Corp. 's TV Guide ! org ;
1	Deep discounts in subscriptions and offers of free clock radios and watches have become accepted forms of attracting new subscribers in the hyper-competitive world of magazine news - weeklies .	end
1	But Time , as part of the more cost - conscious Time Warner , wants to wean itself away from expensive gimmicks .	Time ! org ; Time Warner ! org ;
1	Besides , Time executives think selling a news magazine with a clock radio is tacky .	Time ! org ;
1	`` Giveaways just give people the wrong image , '' said Mr. Heinemann .	Heinemann ! person ;
1	`` That perception takes the focus off the magazine . ''	end
1	Time magazine executives predictably paint the circulation cut as a show of strength and actually a benefit to advertisers .	Time ! org ;
1	`` What we are doing is screening out the readers who are only casually related to the magazine and do n't really read it , '' said Mr. Heinemann .	Heinemann ! person ;
1	`` We are trying to create quality and involvement . ''	end
1	However , Time executives used the same explanation when in October 1988 the magazine cut its guaranteed circulation from 4.6 million to 4.3 million .	Time ! org ; October 1988 ! date ; 4.6 million ! num ; 4.3 million ! num ;
1	And Time 's paid circulation , according to Audit Bureau of Circulations , dropped 7.3 % to 4,393,237 in the six months ended June 30 , 1989 .	Time ! org ; Audit Bureau of Circulations ! org ; 7.3 % ! per ; 4,393,237 ! num ; the six months ended June 30 , 1989 ! date ;
1	Still , Time 's move is being received well , once again .	Time ! org ;
1	`` It 's terrific for advertisers to know the reader will be paying more , '' said Michael Drexler , national media director at Bozell Inc. ad agency .	Michael Drexler ! person ; Bozell Inc. ! org ;
1	`` A few drops in circulation are of no consequence .	end
1	It 's not a show of weakness ; they are improving the quality of circulation while insuring their profits . ''	end
1	Mr. Heinemann said the changes represent a new focus in the magazine industry : a magazine 's net revenue per subscriber , or the actual revenue from subscribers after discounts and the cost of premiums have been stripped away .	Heinemann ! person ;
1	`` The question is how much are we getting from each reader , '' said Mr. Heinemann .	Heinemann ! person ;

1	The thrifts ' lawyers claim that the suits , numbering 700 to 1,000 in Texas alone , should be dismissed as moot because neither the S&Ls nor the extinct Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. has the money to pay judgments .	700 to 1,000 ! num ; Texas ! country ; Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. ! org ;
1	Though the argument may have a common - sense ring to it , even the S&L lawyers concede there 's little precedent to back their position .	end
1	Still , one federal appeals court has signaled it 's willing to entertain the notion , and the lawyers have renewed their arguments in Texas and eight other states where the defense is permitted under state law .	one ! num ; Texas ! country ; eight ! num ;

1	For the first time , the 83 - year - old justice finds his influence almost exclusively in dissent , rather than as a force in the high court 's majority .	first ! order ; 83 - year - old ! date ;
1	This role reversal holds true , as well , for his three liberal and moderate allies , Justices Thurgood Marshall , Harry Blackmun and John Stevens .	three ! num ; Thurgood Marshall ! person ; Harry Blackmun ! person ; John Stevens ! person ;
1	But are these four players , three of them in their 80s , ready to assume a different role after 88 years , collectively , of service on the high court ?	four ! num ; three ! num ; 80s ! date ; 88 years ! date ;
1	Every indication is that the four are prepared to accept this new role , and the frustrations that go with it , but in different ways .	four ! num ;
1	Justices Brennan and Stevens appear philosophical about it ; Justices Marshall and Blackmun appear fighting mad .	Brennan ! person ; Stevens ! person ; Marshall ! person ; Blackmun ! person ;
1	The four justices are no newcomers to dissent , often joining forces in the past decade to criticize the court 's conservative drift .	four ! num ; the past decade ! date ;
1	But always , in years past , they have bucked the trend and have been able to pick up a fifth vote to eke out a number of major victories in civil rights and liberties cases .	years past ! date ; fifth ! order ;
1	Now , however , as the court 's new five - member conservative majority continues to solidify , victories for the liberals are rare .	five ! num ;
1	The change is most dramatic for Justice Brennan , the last survivor of the mid-1960s liberal majority under Chief Justice Earl Warren .	Brennan ! person ; mid-1960s ! date ; Earl Warren ! person ;
1	In the seven Supreme Court terms from the fall of 1962 through the spring of 1967 , the height of the Warren Court 's power , Justice Brennan cast only 25 dissenting votes in 555 cases decided by the court .	seven Supreme Court ! num ; from the fall of 1962 through the spring of 1967 ! org ; Warren ! date ; Brennan ! person ; only 25 ! person ; 555 ! num ;

1	Mao - tai , which is praised as China 's " national alcoholic drink " , has a very long history , and is called one of the world 's three famous distilled spirits , the other two being French Cognac and the UK 's Scotch whiskey . 1	Currently , it has an annual production capacity of 4,000 tons .	end
1	In 1997 , this plant made over 4,400 tons of Mao - tai ; with sales income exceeding 500 million yuan RMB , and profit and taxes reaching 370 million RMB , both being the best levels in history .	Mao - tai ! org ;
1	Mao - tai , which is made in the Chishui river valley area in the northern part of Guizhou Province in southwest China , is known for its extremely special fermentation technique .	Mao - tai ! org ; Chishui river valley ! location ; Guizhou Province ! country ; China ! country ;
1	The water used comes from the Chishui river that flows over cinnabar quality soil and selectively uses such locally produced raw materials as sorghum , high quality wheat , etc. and is fermented during the period from the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival to the Double Ninth Festival .	the Chishui river ! location ;
1	After a total of 10 months fermentation , which requires adding material twice , distilling 7 times , fermenting 8 times , and braising and boiling 9 times , the spirit is then put into specially made earthen jars , sealed and stored for over three years .	end
1	Finally , it is finished by veteran brewers carefully mixing additives .	end

1	Xinhua News Agency , Xi'an , December 30th , by reporter Lianye Zhang	Xinhua News Agency ! org ; Xi'an ! country ; December 30th ! date ; Lianye Zhang ! person ;
1	At next Spring 's " '98 negotiation conference on cooperation between east and west China and investment and trade " , Shaanxi Province will promote public auctioning of a number of small state - owned enterprises to domestic and overseas traveling merchants .	next Spring 's ! date ; '98 negotiation conference on cooperation between east and west China and investment and trade ! date ; Shaanxi Province ! thing ;
1	This province has currently drafted preferential policies to encourage state - owned enterprises , collective enterprises , privately - operated enterprises , individually - owned science and technology enterprises , foreign funded enterprises and average people from inside and outside the province using various methods to participate in Shaanxi 's small state - owned enterprise reforms .	Shaanxi ! country ;
1	It encourages small State - owned enterprises to cross industries , to cross regions and to cross ownership systems to look for co-operation partners and to proactively " become related by marriage " with dominant enterprises and to mutually merge .	end
1	Small state - owned enterprises of Shaanxi account for over ninety percent of the total number of state - owned enterprises , with fixed assets accounting for more than thirty percent , and the number of employees accounting for over fifty percent of the total number .	Shaanxi ! country ; over ninety percent ! per ; more than thirty percent ! per ; fifty percent ! per ;
1	Shaanxi Province states that next year it will basically give more freedom to provincial small state - owned enterprises to do business .	Shaanxi Province ! country ; next year ! date ;
1	Recently issued preferential policies include : appropriate preferences should be granted to enterprises with net assets and relatively good operations , where enterprise assets are sold to lawyers and average people ; for those implementing auctions , related taxes can be reduced or eliminated ; for those implementing shares cooperation system reforms , the state - owned net assets should be first sold to employees of these enterprises .	first ! order ;
1	Income from transferring enterprise property rights should not only be used for settling employees , but also should be collected for re-investment .	end
1	Through evaluation , enterprises whose assets and debt are quite balanced will implement a " zero assets " sale and debt will go with the assets .	zero ! num ;
1	If sold to employees , the form of these enterprise 's ownership system and employee status will be changed at the same time .	end
1	If sold to a legal person or an ordinary person who accepts settling employees , the cost of buying seniority of state - owned employees , can be resolved by adopting the method of reducing or eliminating local taxes .	end
1	If not settling employees , the cost of buying seniority will be paid from the sale income of the state - owned net assets according to the financial affiliation relationship .	end
1	For enterprises whose assets do not offset debt and that are on the verge of bankruptcy , measures can be adopted for reorganization such as reorganizing enterprise management levels , changing methods of enterprise assets operation , and guiding the enterprise organization of structural adjustment , etc .	end
1	For enterprises with no hope of revival , bankruptcy must resolutely be implemented according to law .	end
1	At bankruptcy , income from liquidating assets should be used first to settle employees and insufficiencies should be made up for from the sale of real estate .	end
1	Stock cooperatives are an important form of opening up small state - owned enterprises .	end
1	Enterprises whose system is changed in this form can enjoy preferential policies , such as income taxes being returned when they exceed the base , temporarily not levying business tax on fixed assets , etc .	end
1	For those implementing mergers , the merging party can enjoy policy - type loss subsidies of the merged enterprise , or the enterprise accumulation fund can also be used to compensate for loss , and insufficiencies can be listed as pre-tax expenditures .	end
1	Non-bank debt of reformed enterprises can be transferred from creditor rights to stock ownership ; those having difficulty paying taxes , can implement " temporarily postponing old debt but not owing on new taxes , and suspending taxes and waiving fines , and paying off year by year " .	end
1	-LRB- End -RRB-	end

1	Xinhua News Agency , Beijing , August 31st	Xinhua News Agency ! org ; Beijing ! country ; August 31st ! date ;
1	The main Bureau of Customs recently issued an announcement that Customs would implement protective measures for intellectual property rights at border entry and exit junctions starting on September 15th , 1994 in accordance with currently implemented related laws and the " decision regarding the further strengthening of work protecting intellectual property rights " by the State Council .	Bureau of Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ; September 15th , 1994 ! date ; the State Council ! org ;
1	The announcement clearly pointed out that goods violating intellectual property rights , including exclusive rights of trademarks , copyrights and patent rights , were not allowed to be imported or exported ; when Customs discovers the import and export of goods that are reported as violating rights and other goods that were suspected of violating intellectual property rights , it has the right to ask the people importing and exporting the goods to provide legal proof of use of related intellectual property rights and make additional reports to Customs about the state of the intellectual property rights of goods .	Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ;
1	Customs is entitled to reject shipments of goods that can not provide legal proof ; for importing and exporting laser discs , laser video discs and importing laser disc molds and materials and laser videos as part of processing trade , the consignors and consignees shall complete Customs formalities based on relevant regulations of the country and proof of approval issued by relevant departments concerned with audio and video products ; when importing and exporting goods , if the consignors and consignees falsify conditions of the property rights of the goods , evade supervision of Customs , and smuggle goods that violate rights , Customs will handle them in accordance with the relevant regulations .	Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ;
1	The announcement also made some stipulations about the rights , responsibilities and obligations of the owners of intellectual property rights .	end
1	The owners of intellectual property rights who are protected by China 's law can report to local Customs when they discover that goods that violate their rights are going to be imported or exported .	China ! country ; Customs ! org ;
1	Based on rights certificates of the intellectual property rights -LRB- for example certificates of registration of intellectual property rights or samples of the works that are copyrighted and related materials sufficient to prove their rights -RRB- , they can report to Custom locations where the relevant goods are imported or exported and also request Customs to investigate and deal with the import and export of goods that violate .	Custom ! org ; Customs ! org ;
1	Owners of intellectual property rights , when requesting Customs to investigate and deal with goods that violate rights , should bear responsibility for reporting , assist Customs to develop investigation work and pay the appraisal and investigation of the related goods and other related expenses .	Customs ! org ; Customs ! org ;
1	-LRB- End -RRB-	end

1	In 1997 , Mexico 's total amount of foreign trade broke through 220 billion US dollars , which created a new historical record .	1997 ! date ; Mexico ! country ; 220 billion US dollars ! money ;
1	However , in reviewing Mexico 's foreign trade situation this year , it might be appropriate to say that it is between joy and sorrow .	Mexico ! country ; this year ! date ;
1	The joy lies in that the total amount of foreign trade still maintains a strong growth momentum , and has realized trade surpluses for the third year in a row , whereas the sorrow is that the amount of trade surplus has sharply reversed , and this year , a relatively large deficit may appear .	the third year in a row ! date ; this year ! date ;
1	According to official journals published recently by Mexico 's Treasury Department , Mexico 's foreign trade in 1997 continued to grow rapidly , the total amount of imports and exports reached 220.178 billion US dollars , 18.85 % higher than that of the previous year , and within that the amount of exports was 110.380 billion US dollars , the amount of imports was 109.798 billion US dollars , 15 % and 22.7 % higher than 1996 , respectively .	Mexico ! country ; Treasury Department ! org ; Mexico ! country ; 1997 ! date ; 220.178 billion US dollars ! money ; 18.85 % ! per ; the previous year ! date ; 110.380 billion US dollars ! money ; 109.798 billion US dollars ! money ; 15 % ! per ; 22.7 % ! per ; 1996 ! date ;
1	The trade surplus was 582 million US dollars .	582 million US dollars ! money ;
1	Foreign trade occupies a pivotal position in Mexico 's economy .	Mexico ! country ;
1	At present , exports account for more than 30 % of its GDP , which is one of the primary economic growth forces .	more than 30 % ! per ;
1	After the outbreak of Mexico 's financial crisis in 1994 , Mexico 's currency , the peso was greatly devalued , thus greatly strengthening Mexico 's export competitiveness .	Mexico ! country ; 1994 ! date ; Mexico ! country ; Mexico ! country ;
1	In the last several years , the government has been vigorously supporting exports , and exports grew rapidly .	the last several years ! date ;
1	In 1995 , the situation of successive foreign trade deficit reversed , and up to now , has maintained trade surpluses for three years in a row .	1995 ! date ; three years in a row ! date ;
1	However , in the past three years , Mexico 's foreign trade surplus showed a substantial degradation : 7.889 billion US dollars in 1995 , 6.424 billion US dollars in 1996 , and only 582 million US dollars last year .	the past three years ! date ; Mexico ! country ; 7.889 billion US dollars ! money ; 1995 ! date ; 6.424 billion US dollars ! money ; 1996 ! date ; only 582 million US dollars last year ! money ;
1	Especially deserving to be pointed out is that , after the first monthly deficit in July last year , the rest of the year saw successive monthly deficits with the amounts of deficit almost doubling , roaring from 20 million US dollars in July to 722 million US dollars in December , reducing the 1997 annual accumulative trade surplus amount to a trivial number .	first ! order ; July last year ! date ; the rest of the year ! date ; 20 million US dollars ! money ; July ! date ; 722 million US dollars ! money ; December ! date ; 1997 ! date ;
1	Local economic analysts felt that the trade deficit in the second half of last year was mainly due to an overly high import growth rate , which is even higher than that of exports .	the second half of last year ! date ;
1	In the second half of last year , the average growth rate of imports was 6 % to 7 % higher than that of exports .	the second half of last year ! date ; 6 % to 7 % ! per ;
1	Among import sectors , swift growth comes mainly from imports of consumer products and capital goods , 39.9 % and 38.2 % higher than that of 1996 respectively .	39.9 % ! per ; 38.2 % ! per ; 1996 ! date ;
1	The growth of imports of semi-finished products was up by 18.8 % .	18.8 % ! per ;
1	Secondly , the overly high valuation of the peso is also an indispensable factor .	Secondly ! order ;
1	An overly high peso exchange rate stimulated imports , but hindered exports .	end
1	It is commonly known that in 1994 , before the outbreak of the financial crisis , the trade deficit was once as high as more than 18 billion US dollars .	1994 ! date ; more than 18 billion US dollars ! money ;
1	The huge trade deficit was one of the internal reasons that triggered this crisis .	end
1	Hence , the trade situation last year has caused extreme concern among people from economic circles , who even predicted that in 1998 , foreign trade deficit would revive .	last year ! date ; 1998 ! date ;
1	They pointed out that , this year , except for an overly high peso exchange rate , exports would also face some new unfavorable factors .	this year ! date ;
1	For instance , Asian currency devaluation will decrease export competitiveness , and the fall of oil price will significantly reduce oil revenues .	Asian ! national ;
1	Under these circumstances , if the import growth momentum can not be restrained , this year , a trade deficit of 4 to 5 billion US dollars may appear .	4 to 5 billion US dollars ! money ;

1	Collective industries dropped substantially .	end

1	The analysis of the State Statistical Bureau shows , last year , there were still certain problems during the industrial economy operation , for instance , capital defaults increased , deficits were still serious , fundamental products such as energy resources , raw materials , etc. grew at low rates , the transfer of industrial structure was considerably slow , and all these are restraining factors assailing the further healthy development of an industrial economy .	the State Statistical Bureau ! org ; last year ! date ;
1	This year , the spirit of National Economy Work Conference should be carried through and implemented , while deepening State - owned enterprise reform and continuing to reinforce restructuring , striving to increase effective demands , improving supply quality , promoting the healthy and steady development of an industrial economy . 1	Xinhua News Agency , Beijing , January 3rd	Xinhua News Agency ! org ; Beijing ! country ; January 3rd ! date ;
1	In order to perfect the management of international commercial loans , the National Foreign Exchange Bureau decided to implement a new method of managing international commercial loans borrowed by domestic institutions from January 1st this year .	the National Foreign Exchange Bureau ! org ; January 1st this year ! date ;
1	According to regulations by the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau , international commercial loans indicate loans raised and borrowed by domestic institutions from financial institutions , enterprises , individual or other economic organizations abroad , and from foreign - funded financial institutions within China 's border , whose contractual repayment obligations are in foreign currency .	the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ; China ! country ;
1	Export credits , international financing leaseholds , compensation trades with foreign exchange repayment methods , overseas institution 's and individual 's foreign exchange deposits -LRB- excluding foreign exchange deposits in banks approved for offshore operations -RRB- , project financing , financing under trade projects over 90 days and other forms of foreign exchange loans will all be treated and managed as international commercial loans .	over 90 days ! date ;
1	According to regulations , the People 's Bank of China is the approving authority for international commercial loans borrowed by domestic institutions , the People 's Bank of China has authorized the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau to be specifically responsible for the approval , supervision and management of commercial loans by domestic institutions .	the People 's Bank of China ! org ; the People 's Bank of China ! org ; the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ;
1	All international commercial loans borrowed by domestic institutions should be approved by the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau .	the National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ;
1	International business loans that have not been approved but were signed on their own authority will not be valid , the Foreign Exchange Management Bureau will not process the registration of foreign debts , banks are not allowed to open exclusive foreign debt accounts for them , loan principals and interests are not to be remitted out on their own authority .	the Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ;
1	The National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau clearly stipulated in the new method that , domestic institutions borrowing international commercial loans externally are only limited to : China - capital financial institutions approved by the Foreign Exchange Management Bureau to operate foreign exchange loan business ; juridical people of non-financial corporations approved by the State Department 's Authorization Department .	The National Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ; China ! country ; the Foreign Exchange Management Bureau ! org ; the State Department 's Authorization Department ! org ;
1	Juridical people of non-financial institutions who borrow international commercial loans directly must possess these several conditions , that is , have continual profits for the last three years , have import and export business permission , belong to a national encouraged industry ; possess a complete financial management system ; must have a ratio of net assets to total assets not lower than 15 % for juridical people of trade - type non-financial corporations , must have ratios of net assets to total assets not lower than 30 % for juridical people of non trade - type non-financial corporations ; must have a total sum of international business loans borrowed and foreign guarantee surpluses not exceeding 50 % of net asset 's equivalent foreign exchange worth ; must have total of foreign exchange loan and foreign exchange guarantee surplus not exceeding the amount of exchange created in the previous year .	the last three years ! date ; not lower than 15 % ! per ; not lower than 30 % ! per ; not exceeding 50 % ! per ; the previous year ! date ;
1	-LRB- End -RRB-	end
